fields.headline: Reviews
fields.trailText: Microsoft Encarta DVD Reference Suite 2001 | Encyclopaedia Britannica 2001
fields.body:
Bill Gates's woes made easy as ABC

Microsoft Encarta DVD Reference Suite 2001 (UK and Ireland edition)
CD-rom £99.99 DVD-rom £69.99 Windows 95 or later; 32MB Ram (64MB recommended)
A is for _ "antitrust [ánti trúst] adjective US; opposing business monopoly: intended to oppose trusts and cartels, for example from using monopolistic business practices to make unfair profits."

Not a bad place to start looking at the latest edition of Microsoft's Encarta series, combining dictionaries, encyclopaedia, atlas, thesaurus and quotations on one DVD. And to be fair to Microsoft, it has not tried to duck the big issues.

Looking up "antitrust" in Encarta's dictionary links smoothly to informative examples in the companion encyclopedia. "In a rapidly expanding software market, Microsoft has been subject to allegations of monopolistic business practices," it reads, before going into a detailed exposition of the various charges Microsoft has faced over the years, starting with the first investigations by the Federal Trade Commission back in 1990.

Encarta 2001 also remains bang up to date with current affairs: "In April 2000, the judge ruled that the company had violated antitrust laws by engaging in tactics that discouraged competition. Less than two months later, in June 2000, the judge ordered the company to be broken up into two."

B is for _ "Bill Gates is the chairman, chief executive officer, and co-founder (with Paul Allen) of Microsoft Corporation, the world's leading computer-software development company_. In 1986 Microsoft stock, of which Gates retained 45%, was offered for public sale. With the stock's subsequent growth in value, Gates became one of the wealthiest people in American history."

It is thanks to products like Encarta that Mr Gates has so much money.

In many respects Encarta is a typical Microsoft product: it takes up a heap of memory and offers more options than most people ever contemplate using. It even requires the company's Internet Explorer web browser to be used - it was Microsoft's integrating Internet Explorer with its Windows operating systems that led to the latest damaging round of antitrust actions.

Its parentage aside, Encarta has some nifty features, the most interesting being the "talking" dictionary's ability to pronounce words aloud, and the chance to download monthly encyclopedia updates over the net for free until the end of 2001.

The whole package is easy to use, although it can become slightly baffling when switching between the different features.

The addition of a multiplicity of resources (photographs, sound and video clips) makes the encyclopedia rather more useful in dealing with modern subjects. But this is not the Encyclopedia Britannica: the entries are less than definitive, even if they are comprehensive.

Z is for _ "Zyzomys, genus containing five species of rodents characterized by thick, long tails." (RA)

Dump the discs, keep the wisdom

Encyclopaedia Britannica 2001
CD-rom £49.99 DVD-rom £69.99 Windows 95 or later; 32MB Ram (64MB recommended)

Maybe we've grown too finicky, but it does get boring finding and loading all those CD and DVD-roms every time we want to use them. Now one of the dreams of the information age has arrived - a full Britannica that you can install in memory and open at a click.

If, that is, you have 2.4 gigabytes of spare hard disk space, or can clear it. If not, this facility alone will be, for some people, almost worth upgrading a hard drive for. Otherwise, you can get away with 1.5GB by inserting one CD during use, or take up only 170MB if you use two.

Encyclopaedia Britannica was - and to a large extent still is - the world's greatest reference, self-education and self-improvement work for young people and grown-ups. Owning its 32 handsome book volumes, which once cost £2,000, has been a tan talisingly impossible dream for millions for 200 years.

The full installation facility makes these new editions the first plausible rivals to the exemplary Britannica.com website made free last year. Compared to the website, they are drably designed. But consulting them doesn't clock up online costs and their extra tools are invaluable.

Using the Analyst tool for work, I was able very rapidly to draw up tables comparing individual GDP, literacy and tourist revenue statistics for Maine with those of other US states and other countries. A general search told me the methods by which the artists Dante Gabriel Rossetti and Camille Claudel destroyed their works in grief.

My first full installation confused some background programs and hurled Windows 98 into standby mode. But Hugh on Britannica's free helpline unscrambled that. It's still not quite as satisfying as having the books - but why cry for the moon? (JE)

fields.headline: Games reviews
fields.trailText: Ferrari F355 | Metropolis Street Racer | President for the Day
fields.byline: Greg Howson, Steven Poole and  Hazel Southam
fields.body:
Prepare to work and reap the rewards
Ferrari F355 Sega Dreamcast £39.99 AM2/Acclaim *****
And there I was thinking that videogames were meant to be fun. Sure, some PC games necessitate hours of manual revision, but console titles, and especially those on the Dreamcast, usually let you dive straight in without even a cursory glance at the instructions.

But Ferrari F355 is different: very, very different. Putting it simply, this is one of the most prohibitively tough driving simulators ever. It may be an accurate arcade version (with one, rather than three, screens) but there is no immediate gratification here.

Instead, you must practise until you can visualise the track in your sleep.

Normally untouched, the training mode is crucial for your success. A line is drawn for you to attempt to follow and you can (and should) take computer assistance with your braking and traction.

If console racing fans are dismayed at actually having to use brakes, they will be mortified by the standard of the computer opposition.

Unlike the moving scenery of other games, these drivers will block and cut you up, making tactics even more important.

Thankfully the rewards for all this perseverance soon become apparent.

There may be only one car to drive, but the satisfaction of finishing, let alone winning, a race makes up for any lack of variety.

The six main tracks are all realistically depicted and the game itself looks stunning.

Likewise, the cars themselves are accurately modelled - even though they remain the same when damaged.

Of course, the Ferrari name still exerts a pull over most car enthusiasts and there is little doubt that F355 will appeal to them, and anyone else who is willing to put in the necessary hours of practice.

However, if this all sounds like too much hard work, then it probably is. (GH)

Thrills get left behind in stylish race
Metropolis Street Racer
Sega Dreamcast £39.99 Bizarre Creations/ Sega ***
How about this - a driving game where sheer speed isn't paramount? I know, it sounds like a beat-'em-up where you have to throw little squares of bubblewrap at your opponent instead of kicking his head in, but hear me out.

Here's the deal: in order to progress through MSR, you have to accumulate "kudos" points by winning races stylishly: burning rubber or pumping the handbrake. Drive really fast but boring laps and you are going nowhere.

Penalty points are deducted, however, if you hit the side of the road or another car. The latter rule is diabolical: you lose kudos when the enemy cars ram into you from behind, and they are happy to do this at every opportunity.

At first, the game looks beautiful. You get to race around several carefully digitised square miles of "real" central London, San Francisco and Tokyo. The neon lights of Piccadilly Circus or the pink gravel of Horse Guards' Parade flash past with ultrasmooth rapidity and zero pop-ups. It is exhilarating. Some day, you think, all games will be made this way.

And then a bit later, you think some day, but not right now. Because the first time you are asked to race against other cars, rather than in a solo time trial, the graphics engine gets out its pipe and slippers and starts to peruse the gardening pages of the Daily Telegraph.

More than one other car on screen and the frame-rate wheezes and chugs. Oh dear.

Given that MSR has finally arrived a year late, hotly anticipated by game-starved Dreamcast owners, this is just an insult. And the overall game structure is flawed too. It doesn't offer the instant, designer arcade thrills of, say, Ridge Racer V on the PlayStation2, yet the pointless punishing of minor collisions prevents it from being a really nail-biting hardcore revver like Gran Turismo. MSR does boast a fine two-player mode and it's very pretty, but really - kudos schmudos. (SP)

Make the wrong choice and it's all over
President for the Day
PC CD-Rom £11.75 Damaris ***
Tired of playing against miniature demons or zombies? Try being president for a day, where the bad guys are gun-toting war lords, power-crazed neighbouring countries and the IMF. But cruelly, you are the worst guy of all. In two hours, I managed to start a coup, get shot at my desk, and cripple the economy. Hospitals and schools closed, the people rebelled and no government would lend us anything.

All going well so far?

President for the Day is aimed at sixth formers and first-year university students, but could be played at home.

It is produced by Damaris Publishing, which specialises in late-teen books and websites, in its first link-up with the development agency Tearfund.

The game's notion is simple: you are president of an emerging African nation for one day and the choices you make affect your country.

Advisers put their point of view and an increasingly irate chief of staff fills you in on the status quo. This you can follow with high-quality news footage on your screen.

So, when the coup begins, you can see the men with rocket launchers coming and also watch your people die.

The use of news footage is strong and the problems cause you to think. Click this button and oops, everyone's starving. Make that choice and oh sorry, we've been invaded by our next-door neighbour. Opt to do nothing, and you've got a revolt on your hands. Buy arms to fight back and here comes the IMF.

Floods, droughts, famines, corruption - this game's got the lot and it makes its point.

But it doesn't have strong graphics. Improving a rather static backdrop would have increased my sense of doom as the warlords approached.

Apple Mac owners will have to borrow a friend's PC to play as no Mac version is planned.

Schools can get a licence for 10 CDs for a knock-down rate of £11.75. (HS)

webTitle: Villa undone by Weaver of magic

fields.headline: Villa undone by Weaver of magic
fields.trailText: Aston Villa won the battle but Nicky Weaver won the war. The Manchester City goalkeeper again looked like an England player in waiting last night, immaculate under extreme pressure; David James once again proved vulnerable.
fields.body:
Aston Villa won the battle but Nicky Weaver won the war. The Manchester City goalkeeper again looked like an England player in waiting last night, immaculate under extreme pressure; David James once again proved vulnerable.

With extra-time beckoning the Villa goalkeeper brought down Alfie Haaland in the area and was beaten by Kevin Horlock's penalty. It was enough to give City a place in the fourth round at home to Wimbledon.

With both clubs seeing the much maligned League Cup as their most realistic passport to European competition there was no jiggery-pokery with their team selection. Both managers fielded their strongest available side and recent events suggested the pre-match team talk was brief.

For the Villa manager John Gregory only two words were necessary - Intertoto Cup - a reminder of the penalty his players paid for failing to qualify for Europe this season. And Joe Royle could be even terser; he needed only to mention Rob Styles, the City manager's fall-guy for Saturday's 5-0 thumping at Arsenal.

With Laurent Charvet and Richard Dunne both ineligible, Royle opted for an unfamiliar 3-5-2 formation. But his team were quicker to settle. They created two chances of note in the first half, both the product of sweeping moves down the left.

Kevin Horlock began the first with a long ball that found Danny Tiatto. He picked out Haaland with his cross but Alan Wright blocked the shot before it could reach James.

Paul Dickov began the second move, finding Horlock. The Northern Ireland international's cross found Shaun Goater but his first-time shot flew inches past James's left-hand post.

Villa came more into the game as the half progressed. Wright volleyed over from distance and Dion Dublin had a shot blocked by Spencer Prior.

Darius Vassell, on in the second half after Dublin injured his back, fired wide after being set up by Steve Stone. Then Villa were prevented from going ahead by two fine saves in the space of a minute by Weaver.

Stone, fed by Paul Merson, forced the first with a fierce right-foot shot which Weaver tipped over his crossbar. From the subsequent corner Merson found Gareth Southgate, whose far-post header looked set to break the deadlock before Weaver palmed the ball away for another corner.

fields.headline: Fowler finds finishing touch
fields.trailText: Robbie Fowler's late winner was his first goal since last December but it took extra-time to separate two closely matched sides last night in a match that bristled with commitment, making a mockery of those who take this competition lightly.
fields.body:
Robbie Fowler's late winner was his first goal since last December but it took extra-time to separate two closely matched sides last night in a match that bristled with commitment, making a mockery of those who take this competition lightly.

All those around him may have shown the now traditional disrespect for this particular tournament by sending out young and deliberately weakened line-ups but not the Liverpool manager Gérard Houllier.

The Liverpool side that took the field on a filthy, inclement night was awash with household names - even if the likes of Emile Heskey and Christian Ziege dropped down to the bench - as the good folk of Merseyside were invited to worship at the red altar for a fourth time in 12 days.

The football was neat and tidy, the sweet ebb and flow cunningly disguising the fact that neither side seemed capable of creating anything of merit once over the halfway line.

Indeed, until Liverpool shook the evening out of its lethargy with a lovely goal on 11 minutes the tie held all the appeal and urgency of a testimonial fixture.

However, as any self-respecting manager will tell you, goals can not only change but also make games.

The danger to the Chelsea goal was minimal when the ball fell to the feet of Dietmar Hamann some distance outside the penalty area. But, one flick of Hamann's right boot and the ball was delivered into the path of Danny Murphy who steered a low, precise shot inside Ed de Goey's far post.

The goal hardly seemed to register on those in blue; if there was an injection of pace into Chelsea's hitherto pedestrian football it was negligible.

Dennis Wise did his best to stir things up in his side's spluttering engine room but once again he had placed aggression above productivity. He's an old dog and he simply will not be taught new tricks.

Even so, Chelsea were level by the half-hour, Gianfranco Zola arriving unannounced in between Sami Hyypia and Djimi Traore to head home Celestine Babayaro's cross from the right flank.

A rather ungainly streaker and a chaplinesque tumble by referee Harris apart, the second half was only marginally more appealing than the first although Liverpool's football did gather momentum as the minutes ticked away.

They should have moved back in front two minutes after the restart but, sadly, Robbie Fowler has been restored to health but not potency.

After Vladimir Smicer's shot had been blocked, it fell nicely for Fowler but he mistimed his header from close range and found only De Goey's midrift.

Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink had endured one of his less productive evenings at the sharp end of the Chelsea attack but his delicious volley from 20 yards went within six inches of its intended target.

The Chelsea coach Claudio Ranieri signalled his attacking intentions by sending on the Icelandic striker Eidur Gudjohnsen for Babayaro and the later introduction of Jody Morris for the young centre-back John Terry relieved the team of another natural defender.

However, not even the appearance of Gustavo Poyet could stop the game sliding towards extra-time.

Amid some fierce challenges, Heskey was lucky to stay on the pitch after an atrocious studs-up lunge that caught Mario Melchiot above the knee and Ziege was also fortunate that the refere did not see him elbow Morris in the face. With two minutes left Heskey did walk after an off-the-ball tussle with Winston Bogarde.

webTitle: Ekoku reveals a streak of steel

fields.headline: Ekoku reveals a streak of steel
fields.trailText: Sheffield Wednesday supporters have grown painfully accustomed to embarrassment, but last night their recent traumas dissipated into the south Yorkshire air after emerging with local bragging rights intact following Efan Ekoku's extra-time winner here last night.
fields.body:
Sheffield Wednesday supporters have grown painfully accustomed to embarrassment, but last night their recent traumas dissipated into the south Yorkshire air after emerging with local bragging rights intact following Efan Ekoku's extra-time winner here last night.

Six years had elapsed since the last neighbourly spat in the old steel city and Hillsborough had been transformed for the occasion, the usual cauldron of apathy replaced by a testosterone-fuelled bearpit.

Two bookings inside five minutes set the tone. But in between snapping at each other's heels both sets of players produced a level of fluent attacking football that belied their current league standings.

United had the best early chances but Wednesday were ahead after only nine minutes courtesy of Ekoku's first goal since returning to England after an unhappy spell with Grasshoppers Zurich.

Ekoku was body-checked by Gus Uhlenbeek close to the left touchline and when Owen Morrison swung a teasing free-kick into the penalty area the Nigerian striker got the deftest of touches to flick the ball beyond Simon Tracey.

For the remainder of the first half, however, United were virtually camped in opposition territory and Neil Warnock's team deservedly levelled matters in the 33rd minute.

Paul Devlin's sweeping through-ball was aimed for Marcus Bent but, realising he was offside, he stepped back from the play and Michael Brown ghosted in to drive a low shot past Kevin Pressman.

fields.headline: Celtic wear down resolute Hearts
fields.standfirst:
Hearts 2 Cameron 36pen, 70pen
Celtic 5 Crainey 41, Smith 60, Healy 99, Moravcik 116, McNamara 117
(after extra-time; 2-2 at 90min)
fields.trailText: Celtic go up a gear in extra-time.
fields.body:
Celtic barrelled their way into the draw for the CIS Cup semi-finals after an engrossing affair which was finally decided in overtime. Goals from Colin Healy, Lubomir Moravcik and Jackie McNamara after 120 minutes' play at last separated two sides whose passionate ebb and flow had transfixed a hollering Tynecastle. Celtic now join Rangers, St Mirren and Kilmarnock in tomorrow's semi-final draw.

The match, though, was marred by a dreadful clash of heads involving two Hearts team-mates, Gary Locke and Thomas Flogel, before 15 minutes had elapsed. The severity of the moment became increasingly alarming as the players lay motionless on the grass. Both were carried off on stretchers after a five-minute delay but were later reported to have recovered.

The loss of two men sorely depleted an already vexed Hearts. After their 6-2 hammering at the hands of their city rivals Hibs, Tynecastle has been quaking beneath bruised pride and crippling debts. For Hearts, progress even in this disparagedcompetition was something to be craved.

The game was played at a breakneck pace, with Hearts stealing a lead after 36 min utes and Celtic striking back four minutes before half-time. Without Henrik Larsson, Chris Sutton and Stilian Petrov, Martin O'Neill's team lacked experienced hands, though the youngsters Stephen Crainey and Healy relished the taste of this cup quarter-final.

Colin Cameron swept Hearts into the lead from the spot after a clumsy Vidar Riseth tackle on Juanjo. The seconds prior to that award had also left Robbie Neilson feeling badly hacked by Alan Stubbs near the touchline. Celtic's woe, though, did not last long; Tommy Johnson's cross fell perfectly to the left foot of Crainey, who eyed up his flight-path before whacking the ball low past Antti Niemi.

Jamie Smith's goal was imagined and executed in an instant. Jackie McNamara's pass sped through the heart of the home defence, where Smith had already arrived to delicately measure the ball's pace. In one movement, his shot was sent cleanly and firmly inside Niemi's right post.

Cameron's second penalty arrived nine minutes later. Neilson's trickery inside the box was ended when Joos Valgaeran decided to punch the ball away. Cameron's shot again beat Jonathan Gould from the spot.

fields.headline: Caldwell spares Toon's blushes
fields.trailText: To a flurry of goals and chewed fingernails, Newcastle scraped into a fourth-round home tie with Birmingham City last night.
fields.byline: Dominic Fifield at St James' Park
fields.body:
To a flurry of goals and chewed fingernails, Newcastle scraped into a fourth-round home tie with Birmingham City last night.

Having led 3-0 just after the half-hour mark, the Geordies were pegged back by a rejuvenated Bradford side before the 20-year-old Steve Caldwell, on his full debut, won the day.

Even so, after Bradford's substitute Ashley Ward saw a point-blank shot palmed away by Steve Harper in the dying minutes, Bobby Robson was on edge through three minutes of injury-time.

The Newcastle manager had accused his team of being a "soft touch" after defeats by Charlton, Everton and West Ham. But, with this competition representing the Toon's best route to Europe, a virtually full-strength side of softies awaited the Bantams.

Yet, with the strains of Karl Orff's Carmina Burana still ringing in their ears, it was City's familiar frailties which surfaced early on. Daniel Cordone looped a cross-cum-shot just too high of the unmarked Alan Shearer, and Nolberto Solano's swerving shot was well caught by Aidan Davison.

The visitors, struggling to back-pedal as quickly as Kieron Dyer could charge at them, were then fortunate to see Shearer head Solano's centre firmly against the bar. But their luck did not last. Cordone evaded Gareth Whalley, cut inside David Wetherall and hit a low shot at Davison which the goalkeeper spilled at Shearer's feet. The former England captain thumped the ball into the net to register his first home goal of the season.

City's rearguard then parted to allow Solano and Dyer to test Davison before Stan Collymore's slack pass allowed the Peruvian to advance and cross for Cordone to score.

The Bradford defence had barely adjusted to being two down when the Chilean Calrence Acuna found Solano and Shearer headed in a third.

Some of Shearer's good work was undone minutes later as his back-pass allowed Ian Nolan to nip in and slip a shot beyond Harper. But Dan Petrescu and Peter Atherton soon provided another slapstick moment, the latter clearing the ball and accidentally kicking the Romanian almost as far.

After Dyer was thwarted by Davison's sprawling save, the visitors' new-found industry sparked a revival. With the area cluttered and confused, Petrescu collected Harper's weak punch and crossed for Ward to head into the empty net. Ward latched on to Petrescu's low cross to flick home an equaliser 13 minutes later, but moments later Caldwell found some space in the area to convert Cordone's corner.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Leicester, leaders of the Premiership three weeks ago, were bought down to earth by First Division Crystal Palace at Filbert Street last night. Palace, whose manager Alan Smith had berated his side for their recent lack of commitment, won 3-0.
fields.body:
Leicester, leaders of the Premiership three weeks ago, were bought down to earth by First Division Crystal Palace at Filbert Street last night. Palace, whose manager Alan Smith had berated his side for their recent lack of commitment, won 3-0.

Goals from Clinton Morrison, a 17th-minute header, and Steve Thomson gave them a shock 2-0 lead at the interval and the Latvian Andrejs Rubins added a third early in the second half to dump the holders out of the Worthington Cup.

Leicester were attempting to reach their fourth final in five years.

Fulham, whose 100% league run was ended by Wolves last month, avenged that goalless draw by beating the Midlanders 3-2, recovering from being a goal down to score through Luis Boa Morte (2) and his prolific French partner Louis Saha. Simon Osborn scored for Wolves in the final minute.

At the Britannia stadium Rikhardur Dadason's last-minute goal gave Stoke a 3-2 win over Barnsley. The Icelander, a substitute, had been signed 24 hours earlier and been on the pitch for four minutes. Barnsley had twice equalised through Mateo Corbo and Lee Jones.

The Premiership's bottom club Derby County have at last won a game. Jim Smith's side beat Norwich City 3-0 to help ease the pressure on their manager. Rory Delap, Malcolm Christie and Craig Burley, with a penalty, scored.

In a night of late goals John Eustace scored in the final minute of extra-time to earn Coventry City a 1-0 win at Southampton.

fields.headline: Macari is handed Huddersfield job
fields.trailText: Huddersfield Town have chosen Lou Macari, installed as caretaker manager when Steve Bruce was fired last month, as the man to lead them away from the bottom of the table.
fields.body:
Huddersfield Town have chosen Lou Macari, installed as caretaker manager when Steve Bruce was fired last month, as the man to lead them away from the bottom of the table.

Macari, 51, signed a two-year deal with the First Division club, as did Joe Jordan, a former Manchester United and Scotland team-mate who will work alongside John Deehan, Bruce's former coach.

"We are a three-man management team and Joe and John will not have official titles," said Macari, whose four-match spell as caretaker manager produced one point and no goals. "We will share the workload. We are in a poor position but I do think we can make progress or I would not have taken the job."

Barry Rubery, Huddersfield's chairman, commented: "Lou obviously has a different style to Steve Bruce and as a consequence we didn't expect miracles overnight.

"But I think we have seen something of a minor miracle in the way the players have performed and responded, particularly in the last two games. What we need now is innovative football to get us out of the situation we're in."

Jordan, a former Hearts manager who also managed Stoke in 1993-94, either side of Macari's two spells at the club, was last in charge at Bristol City during 1997, though he was later a coach with Lawrie McMenemy's Northern Ireland.

David Kemp, a former Wimbledon and Portsmouth coach, has been appointed manager of Oxford United. He will be assisted by the former Millwall joint manager Alan McLeary, and Joe Kinnear, Kemp's No1 at Wimbledon, has agreed to be a full-time director of football until the end of the season.

Milan's Taribo West, 26, was expected to watch Derby's game with Norwich last night with a view to signing for County, who earlier in the day completed a deal which brings the former Monaco right-back Lilian Martin from Marseille until June next year.

The United States goalkeeper Brad Friedel is hoping to join Blackburn Rovers after re-applying for a work permit at a hearing which was also attended by the Rovers chief executive John Williams.

The former Liverpool player, who had been denied a permit after failing to play sufficient games for the Anfield club, said: "We are told we should know the outcome in a couple of days."

webTitle: George Armstrong, wing wizard, dies at 56

fields.headline: George Armstrong, wing wizard, dies at 56
fields.trailText: Arsenal and English football are in mourning for George "Geordie" Armstrong, who has died suddenly at the age of 56.
fields.body:
Arsenal and English football are in mourning for George "Geordie" Armstrong, who has died suddenly at the age of 56.

The former Gunners winger, one of the heroes of their 1971 league and cup double side, collapsed at the club's Hertfordshire training ground on Tuesday while taking a training session as reserve-team manager. He was taken to nearby Hemel Hempstead hospital and put on a life-support machine but died of a brain haemorrhage in the early hours yesterday.

Armstrong, born in Heburn, County Durham, joined Arsenal from school in 1961 and made his first-team debut at 17 before compiling 621 appearances, a Gunners record before it was passed by David O'Leary (722) and now Tony Adams (624).

After 15 years at Highbury he joined Leicester and Stockport before taking coaching jobs with Aston Villa, Fulham, Middlesbrough and in Norway and Kuwait. He was brought back to Highbury in 1990 by George Graham, who said he was "devastated" by the news.

"It puts everybody else's problems into perspective," added Graham, now Tottenham's manager. "Geordie was a great player and a wonderful man, and it is a tragedy he's been taken so early."

Frank McLintock, captain of the double side, said: "The world has lost a diamond of a fellow. This has shattered me because I cannot remember George having a day's illness."

Armstrong, who leaves a wife, Marje, and a son and daughter, was a hugely energetic old-fashioned winger who could operate on both flanks and also score goals. He hit 70 in his Highbury career.

He shared in Arsenal's success when they won the Fairs Cup - now Uefa Cup - in 1970. Then, in the double season, he played in every one of Arsenal's matches.

webTitle: No end in sight to cricket's millennium anguish

fields.headline: No end in sight to cricket's millennium anguish
fields.trailText: Frank Keating on a lamentable saga which now envelopes every nook and cranny of the international game.
fields.body:
Not our Alec ... Not good ol' Micky's boy... Mind you, it was only a matter of time till the whole (still almost) incredible saga caught up with an Englishman.

Of just about any current England player, the scrupulously upright patriot Stewart - he readily answers to the name "Squeaky" as in squeaky-clean - is the most unlikely one to have been fingered. He denies any wrongdoing whatsoever. The England and Wales Cricket Board is happy with that. He remains in the England team. There the matter should rest.

But it won't. The foggy swirl of nudge-nudge hints and crude conjecture, of blank, unchallenged charges and counter-charges, will only be broadened by yesterday's "latest revelations". The whole lamentable saga now envelopes every nook and cranny and country of the international game.

Stewart's boss Lord MacLaurin had seemed dopily to have made himself a hostage to fortune, or at least to have painted himself into a corner last month when he called for stronger penalties to be imposed on Pakistan's true-great performer and former captain Wasim Akram, named and fined "by association" in Judge Qayyum's inquiry but against whom no proof was found. MacLaurin was quoted as saying that if an English player "was under suspicion he would be removed from the game till his case was heard and his innocence proved".

Three weeks on, as yesterday's new brouhaha excitedly winged round the world's wires, MacLaurin said he had been misquoted and that after the word "suspicion", his crucial qualifying phrase "and if he refuses to co-operate" had been omitted. The journalist in question at once accepted his Lordship's addition.

Nevertheless the tenor of Englishman MacLaurin's holier than thou suggestion inflamed not only Wasim but all Pakistan cricket - and it was an untimely slice of diplomacy, to be sure, coming on the very eve of the England team's first, and so obviously ultra-sensitive, tour to that country in 13 years. There was the hint of Empire conveyed in such a statement as well, that consorting with bookmakers was something only devious brown foreign johnnies did and it was quite absolutely preposterous, dammit, that an England cricketer and blue-eyed white man could remotely be tarred by such a brush.

MacLaurin in September was re-elected unopposed as ECB chairman for a third two-year term. In fairness, the niceties of diplomacy might have seemed small beer and he could have been excused if he had, in fact, taken his eye momentarily off the ball. For some might think the English game is collapsing around his ears, what with threats of county players striking next spring and the sport's two major sponsors - Cornhill for Tests and PPP for the championship - drastically pulling out with no hint of any substitutes in place.

Not that smooth diplomacy had ever been MacLaurin's strength since he came from Tesco supermarkets to cricket to general, if continuingly over-shrill, applause. He was obviously, and probably rightly, appointed in the first place to be muscly un-diplomatic in a tiredly cosy old Lord's set-up.

And unquestionably this summer his forthright reaction was wholly admirable when he grabbed by the scruff and determined to shake the whole world game once the ongoing five-year-old betting scandals on the sub-continent turned from occasionally aired wishy-washy flim-flam and on-off passing innuendo of a sub-continent betting culture into the appallingly unambiguous admissions by South Africa's since utterly disgraced Hansie Cronje.

Nobody seemed more of a straight-backed unimpeachable "white man" than Cronje. Where were you when you heard that news? It was only six months ago. It seems like an age. It certainly has been for cricket's irredeemably sullied reputation, and it has mired the international game for a long time to come, if not for ever.

How can a simple and good game - uncomplicated by such matters for a century and a half - police, judge, jury, and sentence the guilty in these criminally sordid matters, where innocents, no doubt, will get charged and the guilty get off scot-free and smirking. Cricket is not the high court. I daresay cricket will never, ever, get to the bottom of its tragedy of the year 2000. Tragedy it will remain.

webTitle: Solid Hoggard upstages so-so England spinners

fields.headline: Solid Hoggard upstages so-so England spinners
fields.trailText: The difference a few days can make. On Monday, for the final one-day international of this tour, the stadium here and its environs saw a heaving unruly mass subjected to tear-gas grenades and lathi charges, the broken windows of the Arts Centre a few hundred yards away a testament to an evening of mob violence.
fields.body:
The difference a few days can make. On Monday, for the final one-day international of this tour, the stadium here and its environs saw a heaving unruly mass subjected to tear-gas grenades and lathi charges, the broken windows of the Arts Centre a few hundred yards away a testament to an evening of mob violence.

Yesterday, by contrast, for the first of the two warm-up games that lead into the first Test starting on November 15 in Lahore, the ground was echoingly empty, the police presence comfortably out-numbering spectators.

Everyone had other things on their minds. In the England camp this was scarcely surprising given the allegations against Alec Stewart and the possibility, for much of the day, that his tour was over.

Stewart stayed away from the ground, as did Nasser Hussain, Darren Gough and Andy Caddick, leaving the team in the hands of Graham Thorpe, who fiddled around with his new bowling toy all day - eight used in all, including himself but, oddly, not Graeme Hick - without making much headway against the Pakistan Board Patron's XI.

Pick of the bunch was Matthew Hoggard, who in 19 good burly overs concentrated well on the demands of the new ball on a grassy pitch - if England thought they might get a sniff of a turner on which to practise, they were sadly deluded - and some testing field placings that loaded the off-side early on and left acres of unprotected land on the leg-side, to finish with three for 33.

Good catches were held by Hick, low to his right at second slip, and Thorpe, chest-high at third, with Craig White, whose own bowling relied too much on an ineffective bouncer, clinging on to a nifty one plunging forward at point. Hoggard, though, is down the pecking order of pace bowlers, and it was to Ian Salisbury and Ashley Giles that England were looking to produce more than a token offering of spin during the coming series.

Giles bowled his 18 overs tidily in unhelpful conditions and collected the wicket of the Test batsman Mohammad Wasim with a nicely flighted delivery that found the outside edge as he drove vigorously.

Salisbury, though, despite numerous pleas for lbw that went unheeded, looked unremarkable. If any tremors were to be felt from the Pakistan team then it can only have been Inzamam-ul-Haq practising his skipping, and the real comparison will come when the opposition's highly rated young spinners get their chance later in the match.

The day's most assured batting came from the wristy young left-hander Qaisar Abbas. He came to the crease after Hoggard's new-ball stint had done for Imran Abbas and Kamran Ali, and Marcus Trescothick, bowling first-change, induced an edge from the opener Naved Ashraf, another Test batsman, as he chased a wide swinging ball. In three hours Qaisar hit nine boundaries in an unbeaten 71 as the home side reached 188 for five.

webTitle: Baby's death prompts call for midwife review

fields.headline: Baby's death prompts call for midwife review
fields.standfirst: Midwives "exhausted and demoralised" by extra workload caused by staff shortages.
fields.trailText: Midwives' leaders have called for an urgent review of shift patterns in maternity units after a coroner ruled that neglect contributed to the death of a baby at Heartlands hospital in Birmingham.
fields.byline: John Carvel, social affairs editor, The Guardian
fields.body:
Midwives leaders called yesterday for an urgent review of shift patterns in maternity units after a coroner ruled that neglect contributed to the death of a baby at Heartlands hospital in Birmingham.

The Royal College of Midwives said its 38,000 members were often required to work double shifts because of staff shortages, leading to exhaustion and demoralisation.

Their working hours were described as "horrifying and astounding" by Richard Whittington, the Birmingham coroner, when he recorded a verdict of death by natural causes aggravated by neglect in the case of Thomas Harris.

The baby died 35 minutes after birth in August 1998 due to lack of oxygen. The midwife helping to deliver him had already worked an 11-hour shift and went on to complete a 16-hour day.

"The extraordinarily long hours being worked by midwives at any one time causes me considerable concern," Dr Whittington said.

"Isn't it true every midwife has two lives to concern her - the baby and the mother? Should we be submitted to the care of people that are shattered after a 16-hour shift? Is this right?

"If you were on an aircraft would you want the pilot of your plane to have been working for 12 hours or more non-stop?"

The coroner's call for a review of procedures in maternity units was supported by the royal college. A spokeswoman said members were routinely required to do back-to-back shifts because of staff shortages.

Although this was the first known case of a verdict of neglect being linked to excessive hours, staff were being put under unacceptable strain.

"Midwives throughout the country work under extreme pressures. They work long shifts followed by night shifts for very little money ... If you want to bring back staff who have left the service because they are fed up with the NHS then better working conditions are a must," she said.

The college has told the pay review body that 10,000 qualified midwives who left the service could be attracted back with incentives such as a proper on-call allowance, flexible shift patterns, family-friendly contracts, a better career structure and continuing professional development.

Jon Skews, the college's director of employment relations, said the service in England needed at least 5,000 more midwives. The college is trying to get the Department of Health to fund an analysis of the staffing needs of every NHS trust following a study in Derby showing that the midwifery service was about a third under strength.

It has also warned that staff shortages were depriving women of one-to-one care and pushing up the rate of caesarean sections and other medical interventions.

Birmingham Heartlands and Solihull NHS trust last night expressed deep regret about the baby's death and said several members of hospital staff had been disciplined.

"Our sympathies go out to Mr and Mrs Harris, though we appreciate that nothing we say will bring Thomas back. We have had a full investigation carried out by the head of midwifery services as well as a separate investigation carried out by a supervisor of midwives.

"These investigations resulted in disciplinary action against several members of staff in the midwifery department and where appropriate retraining has taken place. In addition, important changes in management of staff have been made.

"Guidance has been given to staff on shift patterns and the amount of hours above the contract hours each midwife can work and we have employed more midwives. Doctors are now permanently available in the delivery suite."

fields.headline: Every click you make
fields.standfirst: Most people now use the internet in the office as they would an office telephone. But, writes  Bill Thompson , the easy access days are over
fields.trailText: Most people now use the internet in the office as they would an office telephone. But, writes Bill Thompson , the easy access days are over
fields.body:
We have all done it. At the end of a particularly irritating meeting we send off an email to our close friends at the office telling them exactly what we think of the new manager's dress sense, nasal hair growth and corporate vision. Or we come across a particularly juicy photograph of two people locked in an embrace, one of whom just happens to look like the new photocopier engineer, and email a copy to one or two select colleagues.

It is part of the net culture in many offices. But, as 40 people fired from mobile phone company Orange in September for exchanging 'inappropriate' material over the internal email system found out, it can also get you into a lot of trouble.

It has always been possible to monitor staff email. Now, regulations which came into force on October 24 permit your employer to read your email and monitor which websites you have been visiting. And they can use that information against you.

The Telecommunications (Lawful Business Practice) (Interception of Communications) Regulations have been drawn up by the Department of Trade and Industry under the Regulation of Investigatory Powers (RIP) Act mean that employers can also listen in to and record phone calls, check who you are calling on your mobile phone and search the hard drive of your laptop, if these items are provided through work. And they can do all of this without asking or telling you they are doing it, if they think you are committing a crime or doing something 'unauthorised', like sending personal emails or booking your holiday online.

According to e-minister Patricia Hewitt, the new rules must "strike the right balance between protecting the privacy of individuals and enabling industry and business to get the maximum benefit from new communications technology". They have been welcomed by employers' organisations such as the Confederation of British Industry, which believes that routine monitoring of email is both normal and acceptable.

But for trades unions or civil liberties organisations, the main concern is the imbalance between the rights of employers and those being monitored. "We have been calling for the regulation of surveillance for some time now,"said John Wadham, director of human rights group Liberty, "but these regulations do not go far enough to protect people's privacy."

Yaman Akdeniz, director of online civil liberties pressure group Cyber-Rights and Cyber-Liberties, calls the regulations "very vague" and fears "anything is justified under them". Caspar Bowden, director of the Foundation for Internet Policy Research, says: "The DTI has given bullying bosses carte blanche to pry and exploit knowledge of the private lives of employees."

But, there is a general acceptance that some degree of monitoring of email and web use is legitimate. If an employee is on holiday, ill, on a delayed train or away at a conference, it is important that email is dealt with and working documents can be accessed. In these cases, says Akdeniz, employers should be obliged to tell staff what they are doing, since "whatever policy they use it should be open and transparent to the employees". Wadham wants employees to ensure that "everyone knows that their communications are going to be under surveillance and under what circumstances".

The new regulations state clearly that only "communications relevant to the system controller's business" can be monitored and recorded. Yet people may send and receive emails which reveal office affairs or health problems, and these could be being read by managers and systems administrators.

One solution is for staff to be told that personal use of the system is not allowed, although this would be hard to enforce. Wadham believes workers should be provided with guaranteed privacy in some areas, perhaps through a separate personal email account for non-work matters. Employers could also agree not to restrict staff use of web-based email, limiting their interest to communications from work email addresses.

Even with an agreed policy, there are still problems when monitoring is secret, perhaps because an employee is suspected of criminal activity or breaking their contract. It is also highly likely that monitoring will uncover personal information which is not relevant to the job.

Nigel Wildish, an expert in IT law at London law firm Field Fisher Waterhouse, thinks "the issue is to what extent an employer can intercept or block employee email that is not to do with the business". He cites the need to stop viruses or block obscene material as legitimate.

Journalists are worried because many have confidential sources who use email from their workplaces. Milverton Wallace, organiser of the annual NetMedia conference for online journalists, has arranged a seminar on legal ways around the regulations. He says: "Unless we can find ways of guaranteeing that our communications with sources are really confidential, we will not be able to expose wrongdoing or investigate government or business effectively."

The new regulations do not address the issue of how an employer uses the information obtained. If personal data is being read then the Data Protection Act (DPA) comes into force. This requires that personal data should be obtained legally and used fairly - a provision absent from RIPA.

The Data Protection Registrar has just published a draft code of conduct on the use of personal data in employer/ employee relationships which deals with monitoring email. It accepts that "not all monitoring necessarily falls within the scope of the Act", but argues that "systems that involve the interception of personal electronic communications such as email will almost certainly be covered". Employers would have to ensure "monitoring operates in such a way that it does not intrude unnecessarily on employees' privacy or autonomy".

Phil Jones, assistant commissioner in the registrar's office, says this could mean an employer who acquires personal information by surveillance under the RIPA regulations could still be prosecuted by the DPR. "We are saying that when there is going to be any form of monitoring of email or phone calls then the fair thing to do is to be open with individuals. There should be clear policies", he says.

Rod Armitage, head of legal affairs at the Confederation of British Industry, has criticised the draft code for not acknowledging the needs of employers. "It has failed to recognise the context in which business email systems work," he says. However, Jones feels that the possible conflict has been rather overstated. "The code is a draft that covers lots of employee and personnel issues", he said, "and interception is a minor part." But he admits that "we may see legal challenges to how interception is carried out, although not to the fact of doing it".

Wildish says that "the RIPA powers are wider and more helpful to employers than the Data Protection Registrar's code of practice", and he is critical of the DTI and the DPR for "not talking together before they launched this".

Article 8 of the European Convention on Human Rights, which became part of UK law on October 1, guarantees respect for private life, while Article 10 gives a right to freedom of expression. Judges are now bound to consider all legislation within the context of this act. This means that intrusive, excessive or unreasonable surveillance could be illegal, despite the RIPA regulations.

Wildish says: "it is difficult to see how the Human Rights Act will be interpreted. For one thing, companies have human rights too, including the right not to have viruses infect systems". When employers do not clearly state their policies, employees will be forced to act on the basis that their email is being read and their web visits logged.

The only hope for those concerned for civil liberties comes from Nigel Wildish, who points out that "an employer needs a system that complies with all three acts, so the one most favourable to employees will determine how much employers can intercept". At present that means that the Data Protection Registrar's draft code of conduct offers the best way of stopping snooping employers. We can therefore expect to see intensive lobbying of the Registrar before the code is finalised in January, as employers attempt to make it easier to monitor their staff.

What employees can do
Perhaps the most useful thing you can do is to try to make your employers issue guidelines on how and why they will monitor email and internet use. If they refuse, assume the worst -they are reading everything.

There are limits to how secure you can make yourself when using a work computer on a work network, simply because whoever owns the hardware and internet connection controls almost everything. They can read cached web pages, look at your mail boxes, log messages at the server, tap into the physical network, grab all data passing through the router or firewall and even log every key press and mouse click you make.

Use your own mobile phone at work for personal calls (assuming your desk is not wired for sound) and your own laptop for all personal files or emails. You could even bring a laptop and modem into work and dial up your own ISP - although you may get into trouble for making 'personal' calls.

The latest handheld computers or top of the range mobile phones will let you surf the web and send email - and you don't have to limit yourself to the low-tech Wap services.

If this is not possible, stop using work computers for private email or Web surfing. Find the local cybercafe and head there at lunchtimes instead of having a sandwich at your desk.

If you really have to be online for your friends while you are at work, think carefully about what you are doing.

Web-based email services such as HotMail may seem secure because your messages are stored on their computers and sent over their connections, but the web pages you are looking at still have to come into (and go out of) your work network and this means they can be monitored. Since you are using the work computer and internet connection, this is even allowed under RIPA.

You can get secure web email - Hushmail.com offers the best-known service and the British campaigning group Cyber Rights and Cyber Liberties has just set up its own Hushmail service at www.cyber-rights.net This will give you private email, although the fact that you are using an encrypted mail service may attract attention.

So you also need to use Anonymiser to hide the web pages you are visiting from any curious systems administrator.

Unfortunately if your employers have installed keystroke logging software not even this will help as they will still be able to find out what you are typing.

And if MI5 or the police want to monitor your activities in cyberspace, you stand very little chance of keeping things from them unless you invest significant time and effort in it.

Posting hand-written letters may be your only option.

http://freenet.sourceforge.net

The latest handheld computers or top of the range mobile phones will let you surf the web and send email - and you don't have to limit yourself to the low-tech Wap services. If this is not possible, stop using work computers for private email or Web surfing. Find the local cybercafe and head there at lunchtimes instead of having a sandwich at your desk. If you really have to be online for your friends while you are at work, think carefully about what you are doing. Web-based email services such as HotMail may seem secure because your messages are stored on their computers and sent over their connections, but the web pages you are looking at still have to come into (and go out of) your work network and this means they can be monitored. Since you are using the work computer and internet connection, this is even allowed under RIPA. You can get secure web email - Hushmail.com offers the best-known service and the British campaigning group Cyber Rights and Cyber Liberties has just set up its own Hushmail service at www.cyber-rights.net This will give you private email, although the fact that you are using an encrypted mail service may attract attention. So you also need to use Anonymiser to hide the web pages you are visiting from any curious systems administrator. Unfortunately if your employers have installed keystroke logging software not even this will help as they will still be able to find out what you are typing. And if MI5 or the police want to monitor your activities in cyberspace, you stand very little chance of keeping things from them unless you invest significant time and effort in it. Posting hand-written letters may be your only option. See also... fields.standfirst: Ofsted chief Woodhead resigns
fields.trailText: Education and Employment Secretary David Blunkett thanked Chris Woodhead for his contribution to raising standards in schools during his six years as Her Majesty's Chief Inspector, as Mr Woodhead today announced his resignation from his current post to pursue a new career.
fields.body:
Education and Employment Secretary David Blunkett thanked Chris Woodhead for his contribution to raising standards in schools during his six years as Her Majesty's Chief Inspector, as Mr Woodhead today announced his resignation from his current post to pursue a new career.

Mr Blunkett said:
"Chris Woodhead has made a significant contribution to the Government's drive to raise school standards. In recent years, Ofsted has developed a robust system of school inspections. Its remit has been expanded to include Local Education Authorities, further education colleges, the right to inspect teacher training institutions and nurseries.

"The Government's decision to confer these extra responsibilities on Ofsted demonstrates its confidence in the inspectorate's professionalism and independence.

"In recent years, we have worked together to:
 ensure the co-ordination of inspections of every school in England, which provides essential data as a pre-requisite for raising standards for all pupils;
 inspect all Local Education Authorities in a programme which will be completed by Autumn 2001; and
 put in place a more flexible inspection regime, including short inspections for successful schools from January 2000.

David Blunkett added:
"In particular, under his stewardship, Ofsted has played an important role in backing up the Government's decision to introduce daily literacy and numeracy hours in schools and our decision to introduce a clearer timetable for turning around failing schools, which recent figures have shown to be clearly successful. "I wish Chris Woodhead well for the future."

fields.headline: Clinton condemns Jerusalem car bomb
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Israel & Middle East
 Two dead in explosion
 Blast follows ceasefire agreement
 Both sides standing by truce
 Israel withdraws tanks from friction points
 Siege of Nablus is lifted
fields.trailText: President Bill Clinton has condemned a fatal car bombing in west Jerusalem today. "This morning, we were reminded once again in Jerusalem that there are those who seek to destroy the peace through acts of terror," said the president at the White House.
fields.body:
President Bill Clinton has condemned a fatal car bombing in west Jerusalem today. "This morning, we were reminded once again in Jerusalem that there are those who seek to destroy the peace through acts of terror," said the president at the White House.

The powerful car bomb, which has reportedly been claimed by a group calling itself the military wing of the Islamic Jihad, went off today near Jerusalem's outdoor Mahane Yehuda market, killing two people, apparently Jewish bystanders, just as Israel and the Palestinians were preparing to announce a truce.

A witness told Israel radio: "Police spotted a car loaded with explosives and gave chase. It turned into a side street and blew up."

Eleven people were injured, most of them lightly, paramedics said. The bomb went off in a narrow side street of a working-class area lined with apartment buildings.

The crowded market, less than 200 yards away, has been the scene of several bomb attacks in the past.

Mr Clinton said: "This cannot be permitted to prevail. It's now time for those who believe in peace to stand together, to stop this violence and to work against the terrorists."

Israeli officials said that they were standing by the truce reached the night before with the Palestinians.

The blast came a few hours after Israel pulled back tanks and troops from some friction points in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, after Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat and former Israeli prime minister Shimon Peres agreed on a truce.

The ceasefire was to take hold at midday GMT, with simultaneous announcements by Mr Arafat and Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak.

In the hours leading up to the deadline, a 17-year-old Palestinian was killed in a rock-throwing clash with Israeli troops in the West Bank village of Hizme, near Jerusalem, and Palestinian gunmen fired on Israeli positions in the West Bank town of Hebron, drawing return fire.

Clashes also erupted in the Gaza Strip. However, in at least two locations, near the Jewish settlements of Kfar Darom and Netzarim in Gaza, Palestinian police pushed back rock throwers for the first time in several weeks. Near Netzarim, police bundled several dozen stone throwers in trucks and drove them away.

Previous ceasefire agreements, including one brokered by Mr Clinton last month, did not hold, and Israeli officials said that they were sceptical about prospects for calming the situation this time.

Palestinian media made no mention of a ceasefire agreement, and Palestinian officials were unavailable for comment.

Mr Peres and Mr Arafat met at Mr Arafat's Gaza City office for two hours late yesterday in the first high-level meeting since the conflict erupted on 28 September.

At least 162 people have been killed in the fighting, most of them Palestinians.

Mr Peres said that, according to an understanding he reached with Mr Arafat, "we will have at least a day or two without funerals".

If the truce holds, "then we will enter into a discussion on other subjects that are on the agenda," such as easing Israel's closure of Palestinian areas and reducing economic hardship, Mr Peres told Israel radio.

"There is a detailed timetable which specifies that the two leaders will call on their own forces on the ground to stop, to cease fire, to stop the violence, to go home, to stop the incitement," said Gilead Sher, the chief Israeli peace negotiator.

Israel said that, as a result of the understandings reached by Mr Peres and Mr Arafat, it has frozen retaliatory measures that it planned for the killing of three Israeli soldiers in clashes with armed Palestinians yesterday.

webTitle: Downing St forces BBC retreat on health poll

fields.headline: Downing St forces BBC retreat on health poll
fields.standfirst:
Campbell sends protest letter after Today programme row

Special report: the future of the BBC
fields.trailText: The goverment yesterday accused the BBC of deliberate distortion in its reporting of the readiness of the NHS to cope with a winter crisis.
fields.body:
The goverment yesterday accused the BBC of deliberate distortion in its reporting of the readiness of the NHS to cope with a winter crisis.

The prime minister's official spokesman, Alastair Campbell, forced its flagship Today programme to tone down claims that the NHS faces a more severe beds crisis than last year after insisting that the BBC's own hospital survey showed just the opposite.

In a foretaste of election tussles to come on a critical political battleground the Department of Health first intervened to protest about the way the survey was being reported after monitoring the earliest bulletins of the day on Radio 4.

After getting replies from 81 of the 123 UK health authorities the BBC concluded that 73 expected this winter to produce "the same or more pressure" on the NHS.

In fact 47 of the authorities had said it would be the same and 71 reported they were now "very or fairly confident" that they were better placed to deal with winter pressures.

The answers which justified the gloomy tone of the BBC's report - "most hospital administrators feel there are some very difficult months ahead" - came when 31 authorities said they expected to cancel non-urgent surgery (29 did not) and 22 said they expected greater pressure than last winter.

Though the Today programme stuck to its guns and interviewed both Dr Liam Fox, the Tory health spokesman and Nigel Crisp - on his first day as the NHS's new chief executive and Department of Health permanent secretary - the BBC's initial claims were qualified as the morning wore on.

Mr Crisp's officials had seen the survey overnight and he took it into the Today studio.

"I have got your survey in front of me which I must say I think is encouraging because it is saying that people are planning for winter," he declared. No 10 called the BBC line "an outrage".

By midday the BBC's website presented the survey in more emollient terms, with an opening paragraph revealing that "health authorities expect to face severe pressure this winter - but believe they will cope better this time around".

"It became less bad, but it was still wrong right up to 9 o'clock when it was being reported that the Department of Health spokesman was saying that 90% of health authorities questioned (71) thought they were better off, though it was actually their own survey which said that," said a senior health official.

"In effect they were reporting the positive news as if it was spin and spinning news that did not really exist. The substance of the survery was good, it was the BBC spin that was bad."

Downing Street remained angry.

Mr Campbell later fired off a letter of protest which was being studied at the BBC last night prior to a formal reply

No 10 wants an investigation of what Tony Blair's spokesman called "sad and totally unacceptable (behaviour) by the BBC's flagship programme" in seeking to copy the Tory tabloids in generating a sense of winter crisis again as the expected May election looms. The issue is hyper-sensitive to both sides at Westminster because the government has belatedly commited billions of extra cash to NHS reform and better delivery of services to sceptical voters.

The health secretary, Alan Milburn, on Tuesday signed a "concordat" with the private sector to buy their services for NHS patients. In his letter to Tony Hall, the BBC's chief executive, Mr Campbell complained that reporting that "highlights and over-dramatises selective information from surveys and which underplays other equally, if not more significant findings should have no place in BBC News".

fields.headline: Ofsted chief Woodhead quits
fields.standfirst: DFEE press release on Woodhead's resignation
fields.trailText: Chris Woodhead resigned unexpectedly this afternoon as head of Ofsted, the schools inspectorate, to join the Daily Telegraph newspaper.
fields.body:
Chris Woodhead resigned unexpectedly this afternoon as head of Ofsted, the schools inspectorate, to join the Daily Telegraph newspaper.

Mr Woodhead's departure follows angry clashes with MPs in the Commons yesterday. Education select committee chairman Barry Sheerman rebuked him for being "offensive" towards another MP. Mr Sheerman also accused him of making"flip remarks" about important issues.

The Ofsted head has also been criticised recently after attacking the rise in A-level passes and the proliferation of new degree subjects - areas that were considered beyond his remit.

NUT general secretary Doug McAvoy said: "There will be no tears, only cheers from teachers at Mr Woodhead's departure. "Everything he has done has demoralised teachers. I hope the prime minister's loss will be David Blunkett's gain. Whatever teacher readership the Daily Telegraph had will disappear overnight."

Mr Blunkett paid tribute to Mr Woodhead, saying they had worked together on the drive to inspect all local education authorities, put in place a more flexible inspection regime and ensure co-ordination of inspections across England. "In particular, under his stewardship, Ofsted has played an important role in backing up the government's decision to introduce daily literacy and numeracy hours in schools and our decision to introduce a clearer timetable for turning around failing schools, which recent figures have shown to be clearly successful."

But teachers' leaders were remorseless in their criticism of Mr Woodhead's term. John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, said: "I think it is a good day for teaching and indeed for education.

"The education service needs teachers with high morale and Chris Woodhead has done more than anybody to emphasise the negative and play down the positive." Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Union of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, said: "It's good news for teachers - it is long overdue. I think over the last few months he was on a suicide mission and teachers will breathe a sigh of relief." Graham Lane, Labour's education chairman at the Local Government Association, said it was now time for the government to have a "proper system of appointment" for the top job at Ofsted and to make the position fully accountable to parliament."

webTitle: Equality watchdog urges end to all-night Commons sittings

fields.headline: Equality watchdog urges end to all-night Commons sittings
fields.trailText: The equal opportunities commission yesterday backed plans to modernise the House of            Commons , saying scrapping all-night sittings would lure more women to Parliament.
fields.body:
The equal opportunities commission yesterday backed plans to modernise the House of Commons , saying scrapping all-night sittings would lure more women to Parliament.

Ending all debates at 10pm will prove more "family friendly", the commission believes, while reforms to introduce timetabling of debates will make Parliament more efficient and effective.

The commission's unequivocal support for the plans - which would form part of the most radical shake-up of Parliament in 20 years - was outlined in a letter from its chairwoman, Julie Mellor, to Margaret Beckett, leader of the Commons and chairwoman of its modernisation committee , which will be released to MPs today in preparation for their debate on modernisation on Tuesday.

In the letter, Ms Mellor con gratulates the modernisation committee on approving the plans, and notes: "I am sure these changes will pave the way for further changes to make the House of Commons more efficient, effective and family friendly".

She adds that the proposals would "make the job of an MP more attractive to a greater variety of women and men".

She suggests even more could be done to make Parliament more efficient, including ensuring MPs manage their work more efficiently, and the development of a culture that supports "the professionalism of politicians".

Support from the commission is likely to be seized on by Labour backbenchers who have been pressing for more civilised hours.

One MP said: "It's important because it shows many people outside are watching how modernisation progresses and want to see an efficient and modern house."

Conservative politicians are still expected to oppose the end of late night sittings, claiming it will weaken the ability of the Opposition to hold the government to account and amounts to a cynical attempt to stifle them.

Forcing MPs to sit through the night is an old tactic to disrupt the governement's timetabling of Commons business, and was used by Labour MPs throughout the eighties.

The committee, which has already initiated reforms ensuring backbenchers can hold more debates in the mornings and allowing MPs to leave the Commons earlier on Thursdays, suggests debates end at 10pm from Monday to Wednesday, allowing MPs to escape from Westminster after voting at 10.30pm.

But it also offers an olive branch to the Conservatives and Lib Dems by proposing a cross-party committee to agree on how the government timetables Commons debates.

fields.headline: Thompson suffers as London Live ratings plummet
fields.trailText: 4.15pm: BBC director of television Mark Thompson suffered a blow as the London radio station he relaunched saw its ratings collapse. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
He has been spoken of as Greg Dyke's successor, but today BBC director of television Mark Thompson suffered a major blow as the London radio station he decided to relaunch saw its ratings collapse.

The closure of London radio station GLR and its replacement by London Live has proved disastrous with listenership halving during the summer.

Despite opposition from listeners and presenters, GLR's eccentric mix of music and talk was dropped in March to make way for the more news-oriented London Live.

According to Rajar listening figures unveiled today, between June 26 and September 17 London Live's share of listening in the capital was just 0.6%, compared with 1.2% in the previous three months.

The station's weekly reach has also dropped by 25% - or 76,000 listeners - to 234,000, over the last quarter.

Last summer GLR had a weekly audience of 295,000 and a 1.3% share. In its final three months on air, the old BBC London station had a reach of 404,000 and a 1.3% share.

A BBC spokeswoman said it was "inevitable that there would be troughs in the first months of a new station". She added that it usually took 18 months for a radio station relaunch to show "positive results".

"It's only the second quarter of the new station, so it's really far too early to take any trends out of it at all."

The spokeswoman added that London Live was part of a "tri-media" brand, alongside TV and online services, which would not be in place until the relaunch of the BBC's regional TV service for London was completed next spring.

Mr Thompson masterminded the streamlining of BBC London TV and radio services in his previous incarnation as head of nations and regions.

It is understood thatBBC South East will also be rebranded London Live as part of the plan.

The spokeswoman added that the London Live website was already one of the BBC's most popular websites.

It is understood thatBBC South East will also be rebranded London Live as part of the plan. The spokeswoman added that the London Live website was already one of the BBC's most popular websites.

webTitle: Ex-polys match old universities in teaching inspections

fields.headline: Ex-polys match old universities in teaching inspections
fields.trailText: The results of the latest round of teaching inspections of university departments in England show that colleges and former polytechnics match up to the standards of the established universities - a testament to the depth of teaching strength in higher education.
fields.body:
The results of the latest round of teaching inspections of university departments in England show that colleges and former polytechnics match up to the standards of the established universities - a testament to the depth of teaching strength in higher education.

This pattern emerges in the findings, published here by Guardian Unlimited for the first time. For medical subjects, the sciences and the arts, departments in former polytechnics and specialist colleges consistently match the old universities in securing maximum scores in their teaching inspections.

Departments scoring 24 out of 24 in the biosciences include those based at Kingston, Nottingham Trent, Sunderland and the West of England universities as well as Cambridge, Oxford, Durham and York.

In pharmacology, courses at the Aston, Portsmouth and Derby rub shoulders with the Manchester department, all boasting maximum points in their assessments.

And in maths, City and Coventry universities secure 23 out of 24 points, the same score as that for Cambridge.

In physics, the Nottingham Trent and Sheffield Hallam departments score 24 out of 24, out-performing their older neighbouring departments at Nottingham and Sheffield universities respectively.

And in art and design, the top performers include the Central school of speech and drama, the Falmouth college of arts and Oxford university.

One of the strengths of the assessments is that as they judge departments on how well they are meeting their own aims, not absolute or nationally set standards.

Kingston's biosciences department, reviewed in March 2000, for example, lists its central aim as providing "access to up-to-date life sciences courses for students from a variety of academic and social backgrounds". In its report Cambridge, on the other hand, says it aims to "produce intellectually self-reliant graduates of the calibre sought by the professions, public service, industry and the providers of postgraduate education".

Nearly 900 students taking a range of arts degrees were covered in the assessment for the Falmouth college of arts meanwhile, compared to only 60 undergraduates on the bachelor of arts degree inspected at Oxford university.

The inspections, often a sore point among academics as they create much paperwork, cover six broad areas: curriculum design; teaching and learning assessment; student progression; student support; learning resources; and quality management. The Quality assurance agency, which oversees the inspections, is currently drafting plans for new style assessments that promise a 'lighter touch' for institutions.

The latest raft of results would help justify such a move: only three cases from hundreds of inspections emerge where departments actually failed. Liverpool university's nursing department, Derby's medical course and Wigan and Leigh college's art and design courses managed to score only one out of four in one of the six sections assessed - a result leading automatically to a re-inspection.

Yet there are many concerns that the assessments should not be turned into an exercise either too vague or jargon-ridden that it is of no benefit to the customers of higher education: students.

In keeping with the widely used practice within the academic sector, we list here the total cumulative scores for the assessments so far made available by the QAA. These provide a good guide to the teaching quality at the department. Those interested in the detailed results, should access the reports available on the QAA website
