webTitle: Motorists try to bypass looming fuel protest

fields.headline: Motorists try to bypass looming fuel protest
fields.standfirst:
Businesses invest in storage tanks and workers buy bicycles to minimise disruption when 60-day deadline for government to cut duty ends

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Britain has rediscovered the blitz mentality as it faces the threat of another fuel crisis. This week, the spending began in earnest, with consumers snapping up anything that could help them through another blockade.
fields.body:
Britain has rediscovered the blitz mentality as it faces the threat of another fuel crisis. This week, the spending began in earnest, with consumers snapping up anything that could help them through another blockade.

The 60-day deadline that fuel protesters set for the government to reduce petrol prices is nearly up. But oil companies, other businesses and the general public are determined not to be caught out again by mass action.

One council is even thinking of buying a petrol station to ensure its staff can get to work.

Halfords, the car accessories chain, reported soaring sales of petrol cans as the deadline draws nearer. The products manager, James Byatt, said that sales were up 500% on the same period last year.

Cycle accessories such as puncture repair kits, helmets and sales of bicycles themselves were also taking off as Britons looked to alternative sources of transport.

The freight company TNT has installed 10 additional 45,000 litre fuel tanks at depots across the country to keep its 3,000-strong fleet of vehicles on the road. The company, one of Britain's biggest hauliers, delivers products ranging from newspapers, girocheques to DSS offices and even human organs for transplant, including corneas for eye operations.

"Our vehicles use 1.5m litres of fuel a week - enough to fill 37,000 Ford Mondeos," said spokesman David Hare. "We reckon in the next fuel crisis we will have near enough three weeks' supply of fuel as opposed to one and a half last time round.

"We have leased two 28,000 litre tanker vehicles at a cost of £350 a week for five weeks to move fuel around the country. Last time the problem for us wasn't lack of fuel, it was lack of fuel in the right places."

Mr Hare said that the cost of the extra fuel tanks combined with the rented tankers represented a £150,000 investment to tackle the crisis head-on.

The threat of blockades has led to a sudden boom for a Birmingham fuel storage tank manufacturer, Joseph Ash, which experienced a 50% rise in orders this week.

Since the fuel crisis started the firm has been swamped with orders for 45,000 litre storage tanks from hospitals and haulage firms wanting to set up emergency fuel depots, said the technical sales engineer, Jim Galloway.

"We usually turn these carbon steel tanks out in four weeks but we are so busy we are quoting 10 at the moment," said Mr Galloway. "Demand has rocketed this week. We normally have quite a lot of stock but our yard is empty. It's ridiculous."

In Nottinghamshire, county councillors said they may use more than £400,000 of taxpayers' money to buy a petrol station to ensure staff can drive to work if there is another fuel crisis.

The council's acting chief executive, Roger Latham, insisted that the idea was a serious proposal, adding that during the last crisis five schools closed, staff could not reach work, roadworks were suspended and transport for the disabled and school buses ceased.

Last night, the supermarket chain Safeway said it had made secret contingency plans. "The government has made it clear that keeping the food supply chain going is one of their top priorities," said spokesman Kevin Hawkins.

"If our depots do get blockades we expect action from the police. We have been feeding into ministries the lessons we learned from the last crisis and they clearly have learned some lessons themselves.

"Last time round we kept the supply chain going because the depot operation that we run was undisrupted but we could only have lasted out another four to five days. Protest leaders have been talking openly about targeting food distribution centres."

Ferry companies also reported a surge in day trippers travelling to the continent to fill up with cheap fuel.

At Dover, electronic signs warned passengers it was illegal to take full jerry cans on vessels.

webTitle: Straw: no concessions to fuel protesters

fields.headline: Straw: no concessions to fuel protesters
fields.standfirst: Full text: Jack Straw's speech
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, today outlined to MPs the government's contingency plans to protect essential supplies and services in the event of disruption by fuel protesters later this month.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, today outlined to MPs the government's contingency plans to protect essential supplies and services in the event of disruption by fuel protesters later this month.

He told the Commons that the government is unlikely to make concessions to fuel protesters when their deadline for a cut in petrol tax expires in 10 days. He also said that the government has a responsibility to minimise the risk of essential services grinding to a halt.

"The consequences of such disruptions are obvious - and they would hit the weakest and most vulnerable first," he said, adding: "The right to argue, to complain, and to protest is an essential feature of our democratic society. Preventing law abiding people from going about their business and threatening the wellbeing of the country is not."

Mr Straw said that preparations had been made to protect food depots, keep major roads open, and protect potential targets other than oil terminals. Military drivers are being trained to drive petrol tankers.

Earlier today, Tory leader William Hague accused the government of creating a "climate of anxiety" over fuel protests. He also urged protesters not to allow themselves to be provoked by the government's tough tactics, warning that they would lose public support if they broke the law or caused disruption on a massive scale.

"The government are making the situation worse by talking so much about bringing in the Army and by holding the pre-Budget statement so close to the 60-day deadline - they could have had it already and ended the uncertainty - and by talking about stockpiling fuel," said Mr Hague.

Mr Straw said the government action on fuel duties was limited by the need to keep interest rates at their present low levels, the need to support pensioners, and the need to preserve essential investment in key public services.

webTitle: Blair takes fight to fuel protesters

fields.headline: Blair takes fight to fuel protesters
fields.standfirst:
Warning over 25,000 trucks threat

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Tony Blair last night braced the country for a second confrontation with the fuel protesters by ruling out a big across-the-board cut in fuel duty next week and promising that the police would take vigorous action to crush unlawful disruption.
fields.body:
Tony Blair last night braced the country for a second confrontation with the fuel protesters by ruling out a big across-the-board cut in fuel duty next week and promising that the police would take vigorous action to crush unlawful disruption.

The leader of the fuel protesters, David Handley, responded by vowing that some 25,000 drivers would converge on London in a fortnight. They are demanding a 26.2p cut in duty.

Likening the protesters to a cornered rat with no option but to fight, Mr Handley said the hauliers would stay in the capital "as long as it takes". He also claimed protesting fishermen would sail a flotilla of boats up the Thames.

Mr Handley, chairman of Farmers For Action and the People's Fuel Lobby, was furious at attempts by Treasury ministers to claim that next Wednesday's pre-Budget report was a choice between cuts in fuel duty and extra cash for pensioners and public services. He said: "They are using a lot of very serious spin without addressing the real issues."

The prime minister went on the offensive in the Commons, saying the government would "do what it could" on fuel prices, but "it cannot be at the expense of people's mortgages going up, help for pensioners or cuts in public services".

Sensing the protesters had erred in the battle of public opinion by threatening fuel suppliers, Mr Blair said: "However strongly the protesters feel, it cannot be right to try and demonstrate their feelings by either interfering with the food supplies of the country or bringing the country to a halt."

He added: "I'm sure that the police will act quickly and decisively, but it is wrong that they have to be put in a situation like this."

The police have been ordered to prevent drivers staging mass go-slows on the motorways aimed at bringing Britain to a standstill. Details of the government's plans to prevent a repeat of the disruption will be announced today.

In a sign that Mr Handley is aware he may be losing the war of nerves, he said he was willing to hold back protests due to start on November 10, so long as the chancellor set out the stepping stones to a big cut in duty next Wednesday. The call for a 26.2p cut in fuel duty was a negotiating position, he said.

The People's Fuel Lobby is planning a four-day crawl from Jarrow to London in an attempt to pick up support from the public and draw comparisons with the Jarrow march by the unemployed in the 1930s.

Questioned by the Commons trade select committee yesterday, Mr Handley said: "We are in a new millennium now and you are seeing people who have finally had enough. People are losing their homes and they are losing their employment. You can't ask a man to wait when he can't afford to buy shoes for his child."

Mr Handley suggested he was willing to lead sit-down protests, and asked whether the government was going to force soldiers to drive through the protesters.

His bellicose rhetoric came amid the first signs that the public is starting to stock up on emergency food supplies and petrol in advance of a second crisis. Retailers reported record sales of petrol cans.

Some ministers were aghast at the decision by the home secretary, Jack Straw, earlier in the week to advise essential users and industry to stock up on petrol.

The director of the Petrol Retailers' Association, Ray Holloway, said the government had not done enough to help petrol stations identify essential users, or to ensure that their underground reserves were full.

The Treasury yesterday concentrated on trying to lever middle-class support away from the protesters. Stephen Timms, the financial secretary, said a 26.2p cut in fuel duties would cost £11.8bn and result in economic instability, force up inflation and interest rates and lead to higher mortgage costs and joblessness.

Such a duty cut would mean either a 4p rise in income tax, or cuts in public services, including losing thousands of doctors, nurses and teachers.

webTitle: Logging into Silicon Valley's internet world

fields.headline: Logging into Silicon Valley's internet world
fields.standfirst: As more of us get connected, Jane Martinson looks at how the web is changing life
fields.trailText: As more of us get connected, Jane Martinson looks at how the web is changing life.
fields.body:
What difference has the internet made to our lives? Spend a few days in Silicon Valley and the answer seems all-pervasive.

The web has changed the way that people work, communicate and speak with each other in the area of the world that adopted it earlier and more enthusiastically than any other.

If you take away the wealth created by the internet and the widespread obsession with the stock market (difficult, even after the recent downturn), you are still left with a society that cannot imagine a time spent completely offline.

While Silicon Valley provides a welter of anecdotal evidence about the influence of the web, academic researchers are increasingly looking at what the web has meant to the rest of the US and the world.

The first annual study of how the web influences the way Americans behave has just been released by the centre for communication policy at the University of California in Los Angeles.

The report, based on interviews with a cross-section of more than 2,000 people, is a work-in-progress.

Broad rather than focused, it aims to provide a snapshot of a nation at the start of a revolution that its authors believe "could equal the influence of the printing press".

The study, Surveying the Digital Future, is funded by some of the world's largest technology companies as well as non-profit research foundations.

One founder of a media website said that, when his company suffered an electricity blackout last week, his employees wandered around unable to think what to do.

"I had to point out that they could still use the phones," he said. More and more public places, from lifts to train stations, provide real-time news updates on electronic screens to city dwellers that turn to handheld computers for maps and timetables and traffic updates.

The internet has also changed the way people speak when they do communicate verbally. Valleyspeak is a whole new dialect.

"To aim" is no longer just an alternative verb for strive, for example. It now means to communicate through instant messaging in the same way that Hoover came to mean vacuum to an earlier generation.

Jeffrey Cole, who is behind the report, said that he expects 15 other countries to carry out a similar study next year, including the UK.

The founder of the World Internet Project, Mr Cole is looking for a British university to mastermind a domestic study.

As a diverse array of countries start domestic studies, the first postcard from the US edge provides an interesting glimpse into what the web has already done.

What it has not yet achieved is universal coverage. While Silicon Valley represents the perfect demographic mix for internet users - white, male and urban - it is not representative of the nation as a whole.

Some 32% of the study participants had no access to the internet at all. More than half of these (many over 45) said they had no plans to get connected any time soon. The rest said they wanted access but had no computer at home and the new technology was too expensive.

The study makes a positive comment about this divide between the technological haves and have-nots by pointing out that it took television 46 years to reach two-thirds of US households, compared with seven for the fast-moving web. One of the most surprising findings in the survey is the element of common ground between the views of constant internet users and the non-users.

Both groups - from those who proclaimed themselves unable to live without the web to those who had no desire to live with it - shared a common mistrust of the technology.

Some 64% of regular users and even more non-users cited the lack of privacy as their biggest single concern, with credit card fraud coming second.

"The extraordinary degree of concern over privacy and credit card information goes across all levels," says Cole. "That's surprising."

Specifically, Americans are worried about how and why companies are gathering information about them and what they are doing with that information.

Other recent surveys have also underscored the fact that the usual concerns about an overzealous big brother government have been replaced by fears about money-grubbing businesses and a lack of security.

Cole believes that increased familiarity will ease some of these concerns over time. What is clear is that the extent of the concerns could hinder the sorts of ambitions for the web that would make it both an international passport and wallet.

Perhaps unsurprisingly, users and non-users alike were keen to communicate and find things out over the web.

For those worried about the impact this brave new world of aims and synchs will have on human interaction, the survey offers hope. Most participants said that communication with colleagues, friends and family had increased, not decreased, as a result of the web.

fields.bodyText: What difference has the internet made to our lives? Spend a few days in Silicon Valley and the answer seems all-pervasive. The web has changed the way that people work, communicate and speak with each other in the area of the world that adopted it earlier and more enthusiastically than any other. If you take away the wealth created by the internet and the widespread obsession with the stock market (difficult, even after the recent downturn), you are still left with a society that cannot imagine a time spent completely offline. While Silicon Valley provides a welter of anecdotal evidence about the influence of the web, academic researchers are increasingly looking at what the web has meant to the rest of the US and the world. The first annual study of how the web influences the way Americans behave has just been released by the centre for communication policy at the University of California in Los Angeles. The report, based on interviews with a cross-section of more than 2,000 people, is a work-in-progress. Broad rather than focused, it aims to provide a snapshot of a nation at the start of a revolution that its authors believe "could equal the influence of the printing press". The study, Surveying the Digital Future, is funded by some of the world's largest technology companies as well as non-profit research foundations. One founder of a media website said that, when his company suffered an electricity blackout last week, his employees wandered around unable to think what to do. "I had to point out that they could still use the phones," he said. More and more public places, from lifts to train stations, provide real-time news updates on electronic screens to city dwellers that turn to handheld computers for maps and timetables and traffic updates. The internet has also changed the way people speak when they do communicate verbally. Valleyspeak is a whole new dialect. "To aim" is no longer just an alternative verb for strive, for example. It now means to communicate through instant messaging in the same way that Hoover came to mean vacuum to an earlier generation. Jeffrey Cole, who is behind the report, said that he expects 15 other countries to carry out a similar study next year, including the UK. The founder of the World Internet Project, Mr Cole is looking for a British university to mastermind a domestic study. As a diverse array of countries start domestic studies, the first postcard from the US edge provides an interesting glimpse into what the web has already done. What it has not yet achieved is universal coverage. While Silicon Valley represents the perfect demographic mix for internet users - white, male and urban - it is not representative of the nation as a whole. Some 32% of the study participants had no access to the internet at all. More than half of these (many over 45) said they had no plans to get connected any time soon. The rest said they wanted access but had no computer at home and the new technology was too expensive. The study makes a positive comment about this divide between the technological haves and have-nots by pointing out that it took television 46 years to reach two-thirds of US households, compared with seven for the fast-moving web. One of the most surprising findings in the survey is the element of common ground between the views of constant internet users and the non-users. Both groups - from those who proclaimed themselves unable to live without the web to those who had no desire to live with it - shared a common mistrust of the technology. Some 64% of regular users and even more non-users cited the lack of privacy as their biggest single concern, with credit card fraud coming second. "The extraordinary degree of concern over privacy and credit card information goes across all levels," says Cole. "That's surprising." Specifically, Americans are worried about how and why companies are gathering information about them and what they are doing with that information. Other recent surveys have also underscored the fact that the usual concerns about an overzealous big brother government have been replaced by fears about money-grubbing businesses and a lack of security. Cole believes that increased familiarity will ease some of these concerns over time. What is clear is that the extent of the concerns could hinder the sorts of ambitions for the web that would make it both an international passport and wallet. Perhaps unsurprisingly, users and non-users alike were keen to communicate and find things out over the web. For those worried about the impact this brave new world of aims and synchs will have on human interaction, the survey offers hope. Most participants said that communication with colleagues, friends and family had increased, not decreased, as a result of the web. webTitle: Comment: Continentals run the economy and football

fields.headline: Alas, the British care more about symbols than reality
fields.standfirst: We let continentals run the economy and football. Yet we hate 'Europe'
fields.trailText: We let continentals run the economy and football. Yet we hate 'Europe'
fields.body:
Sven-Goran Eriksson is the latest evidence that there's a limit to English nationalism. Could there be richer proof? In the absence of war, no British activity generates nationalistic feelings more ferocious, more bloodily visceral, than soccer. Opera, where the resident maestro at Covent Garden is Dutch, is everywhere a haven for globalists. Cricket, now in the hands of a Zimbabwean, is a Commonwealth club. But to put a Swede in charge of the modern substitute for battle is a startling tribute to the broadmindedness of the English. It signifies a neglected but contradictory truth about national character, a resonant paradox of our time.

In some respects, the British care little about nationality. They're extraordinarily unexcited by questions of ownership or control. They seem unlike any other people, even Americans, in their indifference to the economic consequences of globalisation. A benchmark moment was 1994, when Rolls-Royce agreed to sell itself to BMW. The most potently British industrial brand passed into the hands of the Germans with hardly a murmur of regret. Among both politicians and the public, disinterested maturity prevailed.

This persisted down the decade. Most big players in the City of London are now foreign-owned. The famous merchant banks, many of which came from the continent, have gone back there, or to America. Hambros, Warburgs, Schroders, Lazards, Barings, all these pillars of what makes up financial London have been ceded to foreigners. The stock exchange itself is ripe for plucking by a Swedish group. Some people in the City don't like that, but only on financial grounds. They just think Germans or the French or the New York Nasdaq might give them a better deal.

At no stage has there been national angst about this. Neither Conservative nor Labour governments took much interest, and outside the financial community such developments are barely noticed. Britain sits at the top of the UN list of national businesses investing overseas, but also shows an inexorable increase in foreign ownership of British enterprises, 10% of it, last year, being German. Around 9,000 UK companies are owned by Americans. The British accept this with nonchalance. When BMW swallowed Rover, the only political concern was about preserving jobs. The idea that the nation is a lesser place if foreigners own major slices of the means of production, distribution and exchange never seems to cross anyone's mind. In France or Germany it would be as unimaginable for Brits to buy the motor industry as for an Italian to coach the national team.

This pragmatic indifference reaches wider. Not long ago a survey found that only 27% of British consumers thought British products excellent or good, compared with 38% who thought that of German products. Contrast that with Japan, where 75% think domestically produced goods are excellent or very good, and France where that figure is 45%. Likewise, Chelsea don't lose support for fielding a team of continentals, and the English Football Association is run by a Scotsman. So there are zones where the English and/or British seem capable of taking a realistic view of their own limitations. We have the mentality to be the world's aptest globalisers. Unresentful and unalarmed, we watch the old citadels crumble in the interest of a better result.

But wait. Something is wrong here. All this clear-sighted realism, this stoical self-confidence, also has its limits. Our character is strangely split. Alongside such exceptional breadth goes a neurotic narrowness, a panicky phobia. Confident enough to let Germany have Rolls-Royce, we regard the geopolitics of Europe as filled with menace not opportunity. Superbly contemptuous of the notion that a Europe-owned City could diminish our national identity, we think Brussels will destroy it. Glad to put a Swede in charge of our peacetime proxy army, we're urged by many politicians and most newspapers to curl a quivering lip at the damage a European defence organisation might do to that fragile, tottering construct, the selfhood of Britain.

How to explain this personality disorder? It is not a madness. There are sane reasons to object to the way the European Union is going. It is rational, if contentious, to see Brussels as a malign bureaucracy against which we should be ever watchful. There are cool, defensible, logical arguments against further integration. But these do not fully encompass the emotional turbulence of British opinion, which has as much to do with heart as mind, with viscera as neurones. The insouciance that enables Brits to ride over every assault on their economic heartland seems entirely to desert them in face of any adjustment, however minor, resulting from our 27-year membership of the EU.

The contrast, I suggest, is between substance and symbol. Substance we can evidently sign away, as long as the economics add up. This is not always a reliable test, by the way. The BMW takeover of Rover ended in tears, and foreign-owned banks may survive a recession less readily than if British interests still controlled them. But we blithely swallow that. Symbol, on the other hand, must be defended at all costs. The part of Britain/England the EU mainly threatens are her symbols not her substance.

Passports are a symbol. The half-baked idea for an EU passport is silly and gratuitous, but in a hard-headed world not worth the hysteria vented on it. The pound sterling is another item that's more symbol than substance: icon of nation much more, in a borderless trading world, than unique guarantor of economic success. Parliament itself, while capable of its historic tasks, now seldom performs them. Under all parties it is a tool of executive government, just as all countries face interlinked complexities of political and economics that none can alone control. Though parliament can't be destroyed by the EU, it is in truth as much symbol as reality. The British condition - the preoccupation of an old country - is to be moved more by challenges to its symbols than anything else.

One question now is where in the British mind football is allocated. If Mr Eriksson wins the World Cup he will become an English hero. He'll be seamlessly received. The pragmatic decision to dispense with the national symbol of a native-born coach will be no more worth discussing than the sale of Rolls-Royce. Along the way, even some of the self-aggrandising thuggery that passes for English soccer nationalism could be dispersed. If he fails, on the other hand, soccer will go back to the place where defeatism is endemic, and nationalism the only haven from chronic insecurity. The empty symbols that the English really care about will resume their thrall.

A more serious question is whether the British can be persuaded to reconsider the sterile absurdity of their political passions. Uniquely adult in disclaiming the nationalism of ownership, they are uniquely puerile in their fearful attachment to symbols that impede rather than advance the state of their nation.

fields.headline: The best last words scene
fields.standfirst: Hollow Man
fields.trailText: Hollow Man
fields.body:
In his underground laboratory, Sebastian Caine (Kevin Bacon) is strapped to a table, preparing to be rendered invisible. His body is covered in IV tubes. His assistant Linda (Elisabeth Shue) approaches, checking equipment.

"How're you feeling?"

He takes a deep breath.

"Fine."

Sarah (Kim Dickens) checks his vitals.

"Pulse 88, BP 140 over 95. A bit elevated."

Sebastian glances up at his colleagues.

"Hey, it's going to be OK."

Inside the observation booth, Janice (Mary Randle) pushes buttons.

"We're hot. All systems normal, Houston."

"OK, kids," remarks Frank (Joey Slotnick) over the PA. "Let's make some history."

Linda consults her clipboard.

"Subject - male, age 29, weight 166 lbs."

Matt (Josh Brolin) jabs a hypodermic needle into a small vial of liquid.

"Ready."

Linda takes the needle.

"If the tests are any indication, it should work quickly."

Sebastian catches her eye.

"I'll inject myself. If anything goes wrong, they can't blame you."

She hands him the needle. Sebastian stares at the liquid. Matt stands beside the table.

"Any last words?"

"Yeah. If I'm killed, pretend I said something deep and clever."

See also: Repo Man, The Man Who Knew Too Much

Don't see also: Last Action Hero

Pointless trivia: Hollow Man director Paul Verhoeven has compared his work to that of various Dutch artists. "The example I like to use," he once remarked, "is a marvellous painting by Bosch, called The Prodigal Son. It's a painting of a brothel, and in the corner is a man pissing against a wall."

fields.headline: Amnesty warns of war crimes
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Amnesty International said yesterday that Israeli troops were using excessive force in battles with Palestinians, and that violations of human rights during recent weeks could constitute war crimes.
fields.body:
Amnesty International said yesterday that Israeli troops were using excessive force in battles with Palestinians, and that violations of human rights during recent weeks could constitute war crimes.

After returning from a visit to the Middle East, Claudio Cordone, a researcher for the human rights group, urged both sides to show restraint, but reserved his harshest criticism for the Israelis.

"It tends to be children and others flinging stones, even Molotov cocktails, and the Israeli forces seem to have a pretty short fuse in their answer," he said. "They therefore tend to react with combat reflexes as opposed to proper policing methods."

More than 150 people, almost all of them Palestinians, have been killed in the latest outbreak of violence.

Mr Cordone quoted an Israeli official as telling Amnesty that forces had been on a virtual war footing since the flare-up began, and that investigations into deaths at the hands of Israeli forces had been called off.

One of only two cases being looked into was that of a Palestinian boy, whose death in his father's arms was captured by the world's media.

Amnesty called for an independent inquiry into the crisis in order to study individual cases of human rights abuses and bring the guilty to justice. "There is a pattern of gross human rights violations that may well amount to war crimes," Mr Cordone said.

He urged both sides to react to attacks with proportionate force, saying Israeli troops had appeared to move from firing tear gas to live rounds too quickly. "If a kid is throwing stones at you, but is not putting any lives at risk, then you do not shoot him," he said.

Amnesty slammed the use of helicopters against Palestinian targets, and urged America and Britain to refrain from exporting to Israel equipment used for their maintenance.

Palestinian authorities also came in for criticism for failing to stop children joining street battles. And Mr Cordone added that Palestinians had also used guns, meaning their opponents often had little choice but to fire back.

"In that situation we would not object to the Israeli forces defending themselves and using whatever force, including lethal force, is necessary as long as it is proportionate."

He added that a promised Palestinian inquiry into the mob killing of two Israeli soldiers last month was moving ahead slowly, if at all.

fields.headline: Chief executive quits Eidos
fields.standfirst: Shift from entrepreneurial to 'focused management' welcomed by City MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Eidos, the troubled computer games publisher, yesterday lost its second director in a matter of weeks when chief executive Charles Cornwall announced his intention to quit.
fields.body:
Eidos, the troubled computer games publisher, yesterday lost its second director in a matter of weeks when chief executive Charles Cornwall announced his intention to quit.

Michael McGarvey, who will step up from chief operating officer to take Mr Cornwall's place, said his departure had been a mutual decision.

"There was no boardroom scuffle and neither was this out of the blue," Mr McGarvey said. "This is a management succession from the kind of entreprenerial attitude needed to get the business off the blocks to a more strategic and focused approach."

Eidos, which owns the popular Tomb Raider franchise featuring Lara Croft, has suffered a turbulent 12 months during which its share price has plunged from a peak of £12 last year. Yesterday the shares climbed 5p to 285p.

The company has issued successive profit warnings and a subsequent takeover approach from Infogrames of France was abandoned last month after lengthy discussions. Jeremy Lewis, chief financial officer at Eidos, left the company three weeks ago.

Eidos has not been helped by weak market conditions, with game players waiting for the next generation of consoles to hit the shops before spending cash on new titles.

Mr McGarvey yesterday warned Eidos's fortunes were unlikely to show much improvement until the next financial year.

"In the short term it is very difficult to put your finger on what the market will do and conditions will remain challenging for the balance of the financial year," he said. "Next April to March 2002 will provide the platform for growth."

Mr Cornwall, who was on a six month contract, first raised his intention to leave at the start of the year and will not receive a pay-off. But he will keep options worth around £1.8m at current share prices.

Mr Cornwall in effect engineered the creation of Eidos in its present shape through the merger of a series of small technology companies during the mid-1990s. He had been a director of the business since 1993, prior to which he was a corporate financier at Chartered West LB.

In a statement Mr Cornwall said he intended to devote more time to his other technology and mining interests in the US and South Africa.

Julian Morse, a games analyst at broker Beeson Gregory, said Eidos could be ready to turn the corner, and changed his stance from hold to buy.

"The stock has come back a long way because there has been a lack of investor confidence. But this is still one of the biggest publishers of computer games in the world," he said. "The games market will take off and the largest companies will be poised to take advantage of that."

webTitle: New offer puts Channel 4 in the driving seat

fields.headline: New offer puts Channel 4 in the driving seat
fields.standfirst: Carlton refuse to give up in battle for media rights
fields.trailText: Channel 4, having withdrawn its media rights offer of £250m in the summer because racing "could not get its act together", yesterday made a joint submission with BSkyB and Arena worth a projected £750m over 10 years.
fields.body:
Channel 4, having withdrawn its media rights offer of £250m in the summer because racing "could not get its act together", yesterday made a joint submission with BSkyB and Arena worth a projected £750m over 10 years.

The "Go Racing" consortium formed by the three companies has offered the Racecourse Association a guaranteed £400m (£80m for marketing) with £50m guaranteed in cash in year one.

But the real strength and attraction of the offer resides in a share of revenue generated through worldwide TV and internet betting which is expected to be in excess of £750m.

With a rival offer from Carlton worth £400m, plus possible extra revenue of £150m from global income having already been made but not taken up by the RCA, this new submission seems to be favourite.

Channel 4 are very keen to win this contract, but in the official statement yesterday said they "will make no assurances of continued racing coverage outside this proposal".

This means they will not cooperate with Carlton in their bid, as was suggested in some quarters, and that if the consortium's bid is not accepted then racing will be off Channel 4 screens for the foreseeable future.

The BBC are included in the "Go Racing" offer and will be able to buy the rights to their existing portfolio of racing coverage, worth at the moment around £7m per year.

There will be a dedicated Go Racing channel produced by Channel 4 and running nine hours a day, seven days a week, with four to six races per hour.

There will be an interactive TV service including on-screen betting, a comprehensive website allowing international betting on UK racing, more meetings from the less fashionable tracks on terrestrial TV, a daily lunchtime racing programme on Channel 4 and improved coverage on Sky Sports with 60 programmes a year.

David Brook, Channel 4's director of strategy, said: "The consortium can demonstrate a long-term commitment to British horseracing that our rivals cannot begin to match. Carlton do not agree, however, and an insider commented: "We believe we are still very much in the game. Go Racing are offering a guaranteed £320m in cash, whereas our offer is £350m in cash plus £50m for marketing. When people look at both offers we are in a very favourable position."

fields.headline: TV ads target discrimination against over-50s
fields.trailText: 8am: The government is launching a TV campaign to combat age discrimination in the workplace, reports Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
The government is launching a campaign to combat age discrimination in the workplace.

It is particularly concerned that small business owners are turning their backs on the over-50s.

A 60-second national TV campaign created by D'Arcy is due to hit the screens next week using the line, "Age prejudice - you're old enough to know better".

Although the campaign will target all employers, small business owners are seen as the worst offenders, cutting back employee numbers according to age and worrying about the over-50s fitting in.

David Farrow, marketing director at D'Arcy, said: "This campaign is necessary because age is not an issue in many companies' minds.

"They all have policies on race, sex and disability. Now age needs to become a topic of discussion, particularly in light of the skills shortage and the population getting older."

The ad was written by Steve Meredith and directed by Ric Hawkes.

fields.headline: Media scramble sees regulators relaxed
fields.standfirst: Clear signals on ownership rules MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The trade secretary, Stephen Byers, yesterday listed a series of areas in the country which could be hit by Gannett's proposed takeover of rival regional newspaper group Regional Independent Media. He also voiced certain concerns about the further concentration of regional newspaper ownership.
fields.body:
The trade secretary, Stephen Byers, yesterday listed a series of areas in the country which could be hit by Gannett's proposed takeover of rival regional newspaper group Regional Independent Media. He also voiced certain concerns about the further concentration of regional newspaper ownership.

Nevertheless Gannett, which owns Newsquest in the UK as well as a raft of assets across the Atlantic such as USA Today, received the green light. Johnston Press and Guardian Media Group, which publishes the Guardian, were also told they could go ahead and bid.

The move was interpreted by analysts and industry figures alike as the government taking a more relaxed view of the rules governing mergers and takeovers - and frankly, there seems a lot of it around in the media sector.

Recent decisions on deals by the competition authorities seem to have one eye very firmly fixed on the communications white paper, which is widely expected to rip up much of the existing regulation.

The explosion of new platforms for media companies has made the existing rules in many circumstances seem archaic, and the decisions are taking a pragmatic line. That was the argument that allowed the ITV companies to bend the albeit self-imposed rules designed to limit the powers of individual franchise owners. There seemed no need for the government to curtail their ambitions when it is so widely accepted that the white paper will allow the formation of a single ITV company.

Add to that the government's eagerness to develop national champions which have the capacity to compete in a market dominated by vast American and European companies, and arguments over local newspapers or ITV ownership seem trivial.

What, then, does all this say about the Daily Mail & General Trust's bid to acquire Express Newspapers?

The newspaper market is subject to different rules to those in any other industry due to the perceived importance of maintaining a plurality of views. Some argue that tycoons like Rupert Murdoch already own too much.

The assurances given by DMGT that it will maintain the left-wing editorial line of the Daily Express are unlikely to convince anybody of its long-term intentions; and the idea of a single company dominating the mid-market tabloid press has many commentators frothing at the mouth.

The question, however, is that while journalists in particular are exercised by the thought of the two titles being in the same group, will the government really block the deal? Given recent trends it may take a more relaxed view than many expect.

Game over

Sitting by his pool in Los Angeles this morning, Charles Cornwall, the South African corporate financier who resigned yesterday as the chief executive of computer games group Eidos, may allow himself a sly chuckle as he contemplates the lifestyle he has enjoyed during the past seven years - building a substantial personal fortune along the way.

The rest of us might wonder how he survived for so long.

From the unlikely beginnings of a shell company with a small loss-making data storage business - primarily with the help of the Tomb Raider heroine Lara Croft - Mr Cornwall turned Eidos into what was said at one point to be the fastest growing company in the world. That was before the techno-logjam in the gaming console market clobbered profits and finally blew the froth off Eidos's fancy share rating.

But weaker executives might have opted to spend more time pursuing private interests long before Mr Cornwall. There was the extraordinary occasion back in 1997, for example, when the company's auditors Coopers & Lybrand suddenly resigned, citing poor corporate governance at Eidos.

There seem to have been problems ever since, with everything from the composition of the Eidos board to directors' expenses. There was also the embarrassing revelation that a Norwegian firm in which Eidos had invested heavily was run by former stockbrokers at TC Coombs, a London brokerage closed by the serious fraud office a decade ago. The two men involved had done nothing wrong, but it did not look good.

In truth, the corporate wellbeing of Eidos has never been clear. Yet while the money was flowing in from Ms Croft, investors were ready to keep pumping money in, creating a cash pile which Mr Cornwall spent an enjoyable five or six years back and forth across the Atlantic disposing of.

It may be that Mr Cornwall has happened across some jewels during this deal spree. But followers would be wise to wait and see what the new boss, Michael McGarvey, finds when he takes a real look at this company. They should also ask why the old chief executive is leaving without a payoff.

webTitle: Way cleared for carve-up of Yorkshire Post group

fields.headline: Way cleared for carve-up of Yorkshire Post group
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Regional Independent Media, owner of the Yorkshire Post, is facing imminent carve-up after competition authorities yesterday gave clearance to all three of its potential suitors.
fields.body:
Regional Independent Media, owner of the Yorkshire Post, is facing imminent carve-up after competition authorities yesterday gave clearance to all three of its potential suitors.

US group Gannett, Johnston Press and Guardian Media Group, publishers of the Guardian, have agreed in principle to divide the regional newspaper group's assets. RIM, which owns 72 titles, is valued by analysts at about £550m.

Gannett will make an offer for the business and if successful will sell certain titles on to the other two. A statement from the three companies described the approach as the "most practical and expeditious way forward".

Initial talks had established that certain titles represented a better commercial fit for each of them, it added, although exactly which newspapers end up with which company is still under discussion.

The trade secretary, Stephen Byers, gave the green light for bids from the trio following a mandatory three-month investigation by the competition commission.

The three were forced to disclose their alliance after the commission mentioned their talks in the small print of its report.

RIM is one of the few independent regional newspaper publishers left of any size. According to figures from the Newspaper Society, it is the sixth largest in Britain.

At the end of last week Southnews, the seventh largest, was snapped up by Trinity Mirror for £285m and admitted it had little option left in a market characterised by consolidation other than to join a larger group.

Trinity Mirror was given clearance to acquire certain of RIM's newspapers in the north-west of England if any are shaken loose during the break up. Chris Oakley, chief executive of RIM, said there remained no pressure to sell.

RIM was formed in February 1998 through the buyout of the regional newspaper business of United News & Media. The £360m buyout was backed by venture capital group Candover.

Mr Byers raised some concerns about the further concentration of power in fewer hands and said there were "potential dangers".

Risks posed to advertisers, readers and competitors though were not felt to be strong enough to block any of the three companies from making an approach.

fields.headline: Web poses threat to primetime TV
fields.trailText: 8am: The first real signs that the internet is presenting a threat to prime-time TV emerged today, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The first real signs that the internet is presenting a threat to prime-time TV emerged today.

New figures show that as much as 50% of regular internet users are going online between 6pm-9pm.

After 9pm usage falls off sharply with as little as 2% accessing internet during the small hours.

The survey by Nielsen//NetRatings will set alarm bells ringing at TV networks.

Contrary to common belief, the biggest usage of the internet is not during office hours - the second highest peak of the day is breakfast when 32% of active surfers go online.

David Day, director of analytical services at ACNielsen eRatings.com, said: "The internet increasingly presents powerful competition to traditional media when it comes to share of people's leisure time.

"Clearly, these trends have implications for both TV broadcasters and advertisers as convergence becomes a reality."

Nielsen//NetRatings derived the data from its panel-based internet measurement data, which covers more than 175,000 panelists in 14 countries.

Ratings for September showed that users were spending an average of 28 minutes online at a time and use the internet on average about 10 times a month.

Users access an average of 16 unique sites over a monthly period.

webTitle: Labour close to meeting promise on class sizes reduction put

fields.headline: Labour close to meeting promise on class sizes reduction put
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government yesterday hailed a "radical" reduction in the number of pupils in infant school classes of more than 30, and announced £73m to ensure that smaller class sizes are continued in the subsequent, junior age group.
fields.body:
The government yesterday hailed a "radical" reduction in the number of pupils in infant school classes of more than 30, and announced £73m to ensure that smaller class sizes are continued in the subsequent, junior age group.

Figures published by the Department for Education showed that in September this year only 30,000 children aged five to seven were in classes of more than 30 pupils - a significant fall from the 171,000 the same time last year.

Labour's promise to cut class sizes for five, six and seven- year-olds was one of its key manifesto pledges. Following its victory, the party promised no infant class would have more than 30 pupils by 2002, later brought forward to September 2001.

Publishing the statistics, the education secretary, David Blunkett, said: "Today's figures show a further huge drop in the number of infants in large classes. This is excellent news for children and shows not only that this government is delivering on a key election pledge, but that we are doing so early ... this government is the first to achieve such radical reductions".

Class sizes for eight to 11-year-olds are also starting to fall, as are those for primary classes overall, after rising year on year since 1990. But Mr Blunkett said that to maintain the benefits of smaller class sizes when children moved from infant to junior classes, he was making available £73m next year to ensure that eight to 11-year-olds who had been in smaller classes would continue to benefit.

"This is a decisive answer to our critics who wrongly predicted that smaller classes for infants would inevitably lead to larger classes for junior pupils," he said.

The new money for key stage 2 classes is in addition to the £620m package for the infant, key stage 1 classes, which includes £310m previously used by the Tories for its assisted places scheme.

This funded school places for talented youngsters from families unable to afford fees but was scrapped by Labour. Mr Blunkett again ruled out the prospect of limits imposed for classes at secondary level, as ill advised and impractical.

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, welcomed the news and hoped the government "goes on to meet its election manifesto commitment to get all class sizes below 30 for this age group within the next year".

"The only reservation we harbour is the fact that the government has spent considerably more than originally planned through the savings achieved by the abolition of the assisted places scheme (£135m a year) to achieve this objective.

"Several hundred million pounds of additional money has been pumped into the exercise pandering unduly to parental choice allowing popular schools to expand, while others had surplus places."

But the shadow education secretary, Theresa May, said: "One of Labour's key election pledges was to cut infant classes to 30 or under, but at what cost to other pupils?

"The fact that David Blunkett is having to put money into classes for eight to 11 years to cut class sizes is an admission that his policy is creating problems for older children".

webTitle: Busy parents bid goodnight to bedtime story

fields.headline: Busy parents bid goodnight to bedtime story
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Most parents have neither the time nor the inclination to read their children a bedtime story regularly, according to a survey published today.
fields.body:
Most parents have neither the time nor the inclination to read their children a bedtime story regularly, according to a survey published today.

Aric Sigman, a psychologist, found 93% of parents remembered having a bedtime story read or told to them at least twice a week. But only 40% did the same for their children.

Dr Sigman said reasons parents gave included lack of time and the distraction of television or video.

Although mothers regarded a bedtime story as quality time with their children, many said they often felt torn by the need to spend "grown-up time" with their partners. Fathers reported falling asleep while reading.

The survey, based on a panel of 84 parents with 150 children aged between two and eight, was commissioned by the utility company Powergen after it received calls requesting information about the best light and temperatures for getting children to sleep.

"Listening to a bedtime story is conducive to the child falling asleep - it provides closure to the day," Dr Sigman said. The lack of a goodnight story could affect children's brain development, attention span and behaviour patterns in later life, he said.

With the exception of that man for all programmes, the endlessly versatile and incessantly available John Prescott, it sometimes seems that cabinet ministers have taken a vow of silence. fields.body:
The difficulties of persuading ministers to appear on current affairs programmes have been well documented. With the exception of that man for all programmes, the endlessly versatile and incessantly available John Prescott, it sometimes seems that cabinet ministers have taken a vow of silence. Or a vow, at least, never to submit to questioning on Newsnight, nor on The World at One, nor, unless great tragedy or triumph beckons, on the Today programme.

This elusiveness, Alastair Campbell explained, in the days before he too disappeared from view, was because our ministers are very busy men. "Given the remarkable expansion in BBC programmes it would not be impossible for ministers to spend their entire time at 4 Millbank answering interview requests, and none at all doing their job," he wrote to the Times in 1998, when Tony Blair was first accused of preferring a nice bit of anecdotage on a comfy sofa to being asked a series of connected questions about his government. "Of course this means we can pick and choose, and we do," Campbell continued. "Very few people - in politics or the media - take The World at One seriously, so such regular appearances are less likely. Newsnight is on late, with a dwindling audience."

On the other hand, the great communicator pointed out, appearances on daytime chat shows introduced ministers to "millions of people, many of whom do not follow politics closely, and it is important that elected politicians continue to find ways of engaging them in the political process." This reasoning, or something like it, must explain why those two very busy men, the secretary of state for Northern Ireland and the prime minister, both appeared on BBC2 last Saturday, being interviewed on a programme made by and for children called Pass the Mic.

If they were hoping to reach an audience which does not follow politics closely, then the pair could not, if you discount Tweenies, have chosen better. So unpolitical were these young programme makers, that they decided to approach Mandelson and Blair as visiting celebrities: the former arrived on the set by crashing through a paper screen, followed a few minutes later (and through a fresh piece of paper), by his dog, a golden retriever called Bobby, "Bobs" for short. In the circumstances, it might have been something of an anticlimax to learn that this ebullient dog-cuddler was the secretary of state for Northern Ireland, and so we duly didn't.

"I think the best interviewers are those who are very relaxed, charming, not confrontational, not going at you hammer and tongs," he confided, "because an interviewer who just, you know, beats up on you the whole time, you just go back like that [he mimed timorous recoil]; you're immediately very careful about what you say, the shutters go down, the drawbridge comes up, and you just want to survive and you don't actually want to say very much."

There was a fake moustache, which Mandelson gamely put on: "Don't you think I look younger than I did in the 1980s?" A copy of Peter Rabbit (for whom Mandelson was named) was flourished. "You know what my middle name is, don't you?" His buddy, Tony, to whom he chose to Pass the Mic, was almost, but not quite as polished in his guilelessness, confiding that while his sons were into music, his daughter favoured Pokémon. Sensibly, perhaps, neither minister spoiled the celebrity joshing with tedious allusions to current politics, nor did the children feel any duty to pipe up with Blue Peterish inquiries about the prospects for world peace or retirement homes for dolphins. The aim, so far as one could be discerned, was not to interest teenagers in politics but to flatter their indifference.

This was a striking joint prostration, even for an administration which has always been eager to ingratiate itself with the under-16s, to the point of crashing a three-year-old's birthday party, referring to something called a "Euan test", and in Blair's case, acknowledging his oldest son as a source of political enlightenment: "I had never heard my boy talk about politics before, ever, and suddenly he got on to the environment."

Only last month, the government used a poem by an 11-year-old to alert the nation to the merits of the Human Rights Act. "I am not very old/But I think I understand/How the new Human Rights Act/Would work throughout the land.

I am quite old, but I think I understand how sucking up to 11-year-olds might work throughout the land. If there is something in all the reports about the proliferation of "kidults", those unwieldy, 35-ish, Harry Potter-reading, Stuart Little-watching, trainer-wearing scooter riders who feel no shame in sharing a hobby with Po from the Teletubbies, then perhaps there are kidult voters, too, who want kidult politicians who understand about PlayStations.

Even if the arrival of this type has been overstated by label-loving journalists, there is persuasive evidence that children are now directing their parents' choice of food and homes, cars and holidays. Maybe, if Blair and Mandelson succeed in impressing the audiences of Pass the Mic and similar teen rallies, the children will ordain a parental vote for the party of Pokémon-aware pet-lovers, the pester-power politicians. Let's just hope they never get to hear Blair's views on the loving slap.

Who will protect our peeresses?

The appointment of Sir Thomas More, the keen heretic burner, as the patron saint of politicians has had a mixed reception, but the pontiff's choice of saint is surely less dismaying than the revelation that politicians have never until now had a martyr to call their own. According to Catholic Online, which boasts "the largest collection of facts and information concerning Saints and Angels on the Internet", virtually every profession - many of them much more despised than politics - already has a saint to call upon for help or intercession.

Journalists, for instance, benefit from the guidance of Francis de Sales. Advertisers and accountants, lawyers and cab drivers - each guild has its dedicated saint or seraphim. Even arms dealers have their own protector: Adrian of Nicomedia. Moving up the evolutionary scale, geese have been allotted Martin of Tours (not, admittedly, that he has been a conspicuous success in the job).

And yet, until this week, politicians were on their own. This could explain a lot, couldn't it? Everything from the choice between Gore and Bush to the disappointing turnout at the last European elections; from the shrivelling of the Commons to the existence of William Hague. Still, miracles can happen. Some already believe that the simultaneous appointment of a Catholic speaker and a new patron saint of politicians is more than just a coincidence.

But if the spiritual renewal of Westminster as a whole is to be accomplished it will require another patron saint to intercede on behalf of the Labour peeresses, that stern sorority whose high calling must needs set them apart from temporary, elected politicians.

Although the most obvious candidate for the job, Baroness Margaret Jay, is regrettably ineligible, being not formally canonised, there is no shortage of choice.

Inevitably most of the more impressive candidates have already been bagged by other professions, but it would be a pity if this stopped the baronesses considering St Ferdinand III of Castile, the patron saint of rulers, or Saint Anne, the patron saint of good housekeeping. Or my final suggestion, St Michael the Archangel, who being both "one of the chief princes" and the heavily armed patron saint of paratroopers, would seem to be the ideal entity to take Blackstone's battalion under his wing.

fields.headline: Banks 'very angry' after knifepoint robbery
fields.standfirst: Gang leaves former minister with swollen eye
fields.trailText: The former sport minister, Tony Banks, described yesterday how four youths pinned him against a wall and robbed him at knifepoint as he walked home from work.
fields.body:
The former sport minister, Tony Banks, described yesterday how four youths pinned him against a wall and robbed him at knifepoint as he walked home from work.

The incident in east London on Tuesday left the 57-year-old MP "very angry", nursing a swollen eye, and £50 poorer.

But it had not dimmed his renowned ebullience. "I hope I bump into them in rather different circumstances," said the MP for West Ham. "I am looking forward to renewing my acquaintance with them... without knives involved. Four yobs are not going to force me off the streets."

Mr Banks was surrounded minutes after he left Forest Gate mainline station at 9.45 after taking the train from Liverpool Street.

Four teenagers he had spotted loitering outside a supermarket followed him. One of them asked him for the time.

"It was the oldest cliche," Mr Banks said. "He might just as easily have said 'we're going to rob you'. I knew that would happen. I gave him the time and he just whacked me in the face."

Still reeling from the blow to his left eye, Mr Banks was bundled to the other side of the road and held against a wall.

"Then I felt a knife in the side of me. I decided the best thing to do was to keep the whole thing cool."

The gang leader told him he had five seconds to hand over his wallet.

Mr Banks told them he did not carry one, but had £50 in one of his pockets. "It was lucky I had it otherwise I would have had nothing to give them."

The gang ran off and Mr Banks, who has lived in the area for 18 years, called the police from home.

Later he joined officers for a tour of the neighbourhood in a squad car but they could not find the muggers. Three were black, and the fourth chinese.

Forest Gate is one of the poorer areas of the capital and muggings are a constant problem for police.

By coincidence, Mr Banks was assaulted on the first day of a campaign by Newham council, called Respect, to stamp out street crime and anti-social behaviour - an irony not lost on the victim.

"It's a great start to the campaign. The local MP gets robbed at knifepoint. I assume the event wasn't organised by the council's press department.

"It goes with the territory in an area like this. It was not enjoyable but four yobs are not going to force me off the streets.

"It all left me feeling very angry."

Scotland Yard said Mr Banks had given a full statement and urged witnesses to come forward.

Although police do not have detailed descriptions of the attackers, Mr Banks told them the leader was a 6ft 1in Afro-Caribbean, aged 15 to 17.

"It was obviously a nasty incident," said a spokeman. "Mr Banks was hit on the left side of his face but he did not need medical attention."

Anyone with information should contact Plaistow Robbery Squad on 020 7275 5710 or anonymously Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111.

fields.headline: Tighten shipping controls, EU told
fields.standfirst: Toxic spill: French call for tougher rules on tankers
fields.trailText: France called for tight European controls on shipping yesterday after dangerous chemicals began leaking from the tanker Ievoli-Sun, the day after she sank off Alderney with a 6000 tonne cargo.
fields.body:
France called for tight European controls on shipping yesterday after dangerous chemicals began leaking from the tanker Ievoli-Sun, the day after she sank off Alderney with a 6000 tonne cargo.

President Jacques Chirac went to Cherbourg to talk to marine officials, after being told that the Italian registered Ievoli-Sun was barely seaworthy before she left Fawley, Hampshire, for Yugoslavia.

Earlier President Chirac had called Romano Prodi, the president of the European commission, and other European Union leaders to demand rapid introduction of severe new controls, including a ban on single hull tankers.

While he was at the French port, a minesweeper that had located the ship was taken out of the area and other shipping warned to stay clear because of a risk that leaking styrene could explode.

The Ievoli-Sun, lying upside down in about 90 metres of water, had a large hole in the hull which had opened while she was being towed on Tuesday.

The sinking, less than a year after the fuel tanker Erika went down and caused hundreds of miles of pollution along the French coast, has exposed serious faults in inspection procedures.

The French transport minister, Jean-Claude Gayssot,said that if reforms promised after the Erika disaster had been in place now the Ievoli-Sun "would have been banished from the seas".

However, according to the minister, Italy and Greece had opposed the changes.

Although the Italian ship was only 10 years old, there have been a number of reports that she was poorly maintained.

The captain of the tugboat Abeille-Flandres, who went aboard, said the ship was rusty and in poor condition.

His opinion confirmed other reports, including an official inspection in Holland on October 26, after the ship was detained in the port of Moerdijk for four days because of problems with watertight doors and the electrical circuit.

This was the third time she had been stopped in Dutch ports because of her suspect condition.

The Dutch said faults were repaired before the Ievoli-Sun left for Fawley, after being chartered by Shell and Exxon-Mobil to carry chemicals to Bar in Yugoslavia.

But France has asked Italy for explanations on the Ievoli-Sun's record and the inspections by the Rina verification company in Italy, which also gave a seaworthiness certificate to the Maltese-registered Erika.

The Erika was given a fairly high mark for safety by Rina, which was much more critical of the state of the Ievoli-Sun.

French authorities have been told that the Naples-based tanker, which belongs to a family-owned fleet, only just scraped through a seaworthiness test despite lengthy repairs.

Greenpeace's French spokesman, Bruno Rebelle, criticised the French government, which holds the European presidency, for not rushing through reforms which would automatically ban ships that had twice failed inspectionprocedures.

"France and Europe are stuck between attempts to improve security and the need to maintain a competitive fleet," he said.

fields.headline: Mandelson admits hype was mistake
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Labour had contributed to the fall in its standing among the public by exaggerating the speed with which it could deliver change, Peter Mandelson admitted yesterday.
fields.body:
Labour had contributed to the fall in its standing among the public by exaggerating the speed with which it could deliver change, Peter Mandelson admitted yesterday.

Himself sometimes called the King of Spin, the Northern Ireland secretary conceded that, in New Labour's early days in power, "the enthusiasm of our rhetoric did not help".

"Not yet chastened by the sheer hard work and grind of government, we were all a bit guilty of letting some of our sense of the possible get out of sync with the pace of change on the ground."

But, he said, the recent poll recovery would continue so long as the party renewed itself and adopted a more ambitious second term manifesto, one that addressed the breakdown in social cohesion and the fear of crime. He said these issues of social dislocation were "eating people's souls".

The government needed to address the disaffection of the young by rebalancing the curriculum, increasing parental responsibility, and spreading prosperity. The important task was to reignite youth's interest in education, he suggested, referring to the recent film: "Not everyone could become a Billy Elliot, but the government needs to do more to provide after school clubs and vocational education."

Mandelson is one of a series of Labour election strategists who have admitted the government is struggling to find a "vocabulary of achievement" that does not alienate voters.

Giving the Herbert Morrison lecture at Westminster, Mr Mandelson (a grandson of the postwar Labour home secretary) admitted that his party was going through "testing times", since the size of the government's majority had inflated expectations as to the speed with which it could deliver on its commitments.

"The truth is that a massive majority does not actually make solving the problems of the NHS easier or quicker, it merely means there are fewer tight votes in the Commons", he said.

The party had learned lessons about government, "about the balance of listening and leading, about the need not to over-claim, about the great potential but also the impatience of the British people. And the constant conversation we need to keep having with the public, in language that makes an emotional and not just a political connection between government and governed."

However, he said, there was only one question that mattered: "Why was it that, after 1945, a great Labour government that achieved so much in its first term, failed to meet the challenge of renewal and allowed its huge majority to melt away and be followed by 13 years of Tory rule? And how can we be sure to avoid the same fate?

"Competent implementation of a victorious manifesto is a necessary but not sufficient condition for future success. We have to keep thinking and re-thinking our ideas. We have to hatch new policies, bold strokes and forward positions that keep us ahead of the times".

He said lack of social cohesion and fear of crime in cities was one great issue to address in the second term - theft, intimidation, abuse, vandalism or burglary. "It is what people are talking about - either because they are experiencing it, or hearing about it, or reading about it. And it is eating into their souls."

fields.headline: Vote-trading websites close
fields.standfirst:
www.voteswap2000.com
Special report: the US elections
Net news
fields.trailText: Internet sites that arranged vote trading between supporters of presidential candidates Al Gore and Ralph Nader have been closed down following pressure from election officials and the offices of state attorney generals.
fields.body:
Internet sites that arranged vote trading between supporters of presidential candidates Al Gore and Ralph Nader have been closed down following pressure from election officials and the offices of state attorney generals.

But some sites are still offering the chance to swap votes so that Mr Gore benefits in close-run contests while Mr Nader is assured of votes in states where the result is a foregone conclusion.

The vote-swap plan emerged earlier this week. Under the scheme, a Nader voter in a state such as Oregon, where Mr Gore desperately needs votes, would be paired with a Gore voter in Texas where Bush is a certain winner.

This would benefit both sides in that Mr Gore would profit in Oregon while Mr Nader would still move towards his goal of 5% of the vote nationally. Reaching that figure would guarantee him electoral funding at the next election and elevate the Green party, for whom he is running, to a much higher national profile.

The flaw in the plan is that it is entirely dependent on mutual trust, as there is no guarantee that either side will do as they have promised.

Dave Stewart of the Pacific Green party in Portland, Oregon, said yesterday that he believed the vote-swap idea was part of a Gore "dirty tricks" campaign.
