webTitle: Nader defies Gore to fight to the finish

fields.headline: Nader defies Gore to fight to the finish
fields.standfirst:
Rivals head for Oregon, where votes for the Green candidate threaten to let in Bush

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The sign inside Ralph Nader's Portland headquarters reads: "This is not a fumbling little operation; it is the home of the next major political party in the state of Oregon and we're on the move."
fields.body:
The sign inside Ralph Nader's Portland headquarters reads: "This is not a fumbling little operation; it is the home of the next major political party in the state of Oregon and we're on the move."

Such has been the success of the Nader campaign in the state that both Al Gore and George W Bush were in town on Tuesday to woo the undecided voters of this maverick Pacific coast state.

Oregon voted heavily for Bill Clinton in 1996 and it should have been a Gore stronghold this time, but local polls have shown the two main candidates neck and neck and Mr Nader, the Green candidate, on up to 10%, with his supporters including disillusioned Democrats.

So in the early hours of the morning the Gore campaign plane touched down at Portland. The weary vice-president appeared later for a local school meeting.

Key states

This week the Gore team has noticeably stepped up its attacks on Mr Nader, who continues to worry the Democrats in key states including Washington, Wisconsin and California, in addition to Oregon.

Although nationally he is polling between 4% and 5%, Mr Nader could tilt the balance in those states which account for a crucial 83 electoral votes.

Behind-the-scenes approaches to Mr Nader to ask his supporters to back off in borderline states have been rebuffed. A group of environmentalists and abortion rights activists have been in Portland urging wavering voters to stay with Mr Gore for fear that Nader votes will open the door to Mr Bush.

"The Gore people are trying a lot of dirty tricks," said Dave Stewart, who heads the Pacific Green party's Nader office. He paused to answer the phone and assure a volunteer that she could bring her dog with her to the office as long as it was well-behaved.

He said that support for Nader was holding up despite a barrage of pro-Gore ads from environmental groups such as the Sierra Club in the local alternative press. "The closer you get to Washington," he says of the Sierra Club, "the more conservative you get - too many visits to the White House, too many three-piece suits."

Countering the pro-Gore ads are, bizarrely, commercials for Mr Nader placed by the pro-Bush Republican Leadership Council. The ads, which are running in Oregon, Wisconsin and Washington state, show clips of Mr Nader attacking Mr Gore and are aimed at people who would never dream of voting Republican but might move their vote from the vice-president to the Green candidate, thus helping the Republicans steal the state.

Mr Nader himself has unveiled a new television ad, attacking the two main candidates, which has been given free publicity on several news programmes. It features children describing what they want to do when they grow up. "I want to be lied to," says one."I want to vote for the lesser of two evils," says another.

Nowhere in the election does the Nader factor loom larger than in Oregon, and his refusal to bow out of the race has provoked passionate responses. His supporters have called him a "post-industrial Quixote" and a "Robespierre who uses class actions instead of the guillotine."

But the New York Times has accused him of "wilful prankishness...he calls his wrecking-ball candidacy a matter of principle but it looks from here like ego run amok."

His supporters in Portland have no doubt about where they stand. "He lives like a monk and works like a slave for the people," said Dr Barbara Leigh-Chapman, a 61-year-old lifetime Republican who had switched to Mr Nader and claimed that at least nine Republicans neighbours in Lake Oswego had done the same.

"A lot of older Republicans are voting for him because they think in terms of their children and grandchildren and what's happening to this country."

Another supporter, Steve Amy, who had arrived to assemble placards, said: "Of all the campaigns, we are the true believers."

Mr Stewart said that most of the committed Naderites in Portland were independents, with dissident Democrats outnumbering dissident Republicans by up to three to one.

Responding to criticisms from the Democrats that Mr Nader played little part in the civil rights movements of the 60s, Mr Stewart said: "You can't do everything. Because of Ralph Nader the Safe Drinking Water Act and the Freedom of Information Act were passed, he's got more legislation passed thathan Gore or Bush."

Local support

On the streets of Portland, Mr Nader is also doing well. Outside Powells bookshop, Chester Sadowski, a former construction worker, 50, said he had voted for Mr Clinton last time but added: "Gore's a wimp and Bush is just about money - Nader's the only one with principles."

Under a grey sky at the Coliseum, where Mr Nader had earlier drawn an audience of 10,000 paying $7 (£4.80) each, the crowds gathered to see Mr Bush, the man they clearly believe is only a week away from being the new president. They warily eyed the Naderites with their green placards proclaiming "Bush And Gore make me want to Ralph".

Some Bush fans chanted back "Go, George, Go!" but the mood was mainly good-natured, not least because many Republicans see the Naderites as their enemy's enemy and thus their friend. One woman carried a "Greens for Gore" slogan but mainly it was the Naderites who heckled the Bush supporters.

It is not only for the Nader factor that the Oregon race is under national scrutiny. Voters in the state are taking part in the first ever presidential ballot conducted entirely by post and they will have had their ballots for 18 days by the time polling closes at 8pm on Tuesday.

The argument for a total postal vote is that it will increase votes cast. Arguments against include the potential for fraud.

Courtney Scott, a photographer who is campaigning for Mr Nader, said that it was unclear which of the parties might benefit from the postal experiment. "One real worry is spousal coercion," she said.

Oregon is extremely civic-minded; the presidential election turnout has not dropped below 71 % since 1972, around 20 percentage points higher than the national average.

Mr Gore does have some fans. There's a sticker in the window of the 24 Hour Church of Elvis where you can wed for $25. Stephanie Pierce, who presides in briskly manic fashion over the church and who put the sticker up, said: "I think presidential elections are more important than just making a statement but it is much harder to take a nuanced stand."

Nader supporters are already planning a "victory night" party, victory being 5% of the poll nationally which would give Mr Nader the federal funding to run a much bigger campaign in four years' time.

webTitle: Never mind the policies, voters crave a president of character

fields.headline: Never mind the policies, voters crave a president of character
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: A strange dichotomy has come to dominate the 2000 election. While Al Gore is winning the battle for the minds of voters, George W Bush is capturing their hearts.
fields.body:
A strange dichotomy has come to dominate the 2000 election. While Al Gore is winning the battle for the minds of voters, George W Bush is capturing their hearts.

We have seen this consistently through the campaign - voters have nodded their heads in agreement with and approval of Gore's policies, then turned off their television sets and immediately told their local pollsters they were voting for Bush.

The roots of this strange behaviour lie in the public reaction to Clinton's unimpeachment. While Americans learned more than they cared to about their president's sex life, their opinion of William Jefferson Clinton, the man, dropped dramatically and seemingly permanently.

But as the nation remained prosperous, at peace, and moving ahead, they said, in the next breath, that he was doing a good job as president. They felt that Bill Clinton was a good president but a bad man.

Never before had these two qualities been separable. But, even today, while 63% of Americans approve of the job Clinton is doing as president, only 42% see him favourably as a person. Thus, a new political phenomenon is unfolding on the other side of the Atlantic ocean - the separation of the ideas of competence and character.

Once they went hand-in-hand. If the public felt a political figure was doing a good job, they assumed he was a good person. If they began to feel he had let them down they drew negative conclusions about him politically as well as personally. But, beginning with the Clinton impeachment proceedings, these two ideas - job performance and personal integrity - became separate. In fact, where Clinton was concerned, they got a divorce.

Now, the same separation of job performance and character lies at the heart of the 2000 race for US president. Voters agree with Gore, but they like Bush. They would rather have Gore's policies but Bush's character. While the vice-president echoes their views, the Republican candidate elicits their admiration, affection, and trust.

Every nation's politics marches to the beat of its own recent experience.

After Richard Nixon's scandals, Americans wanted integrity above all else and voted for Jimmy Carter. After Carter's incompetence and weakness, they wanted decisiveness and direction and voted for Ronald Reagan.

The negative parts of the Clinton legacy, his scandals, leave Americans wanting a man of character, judgment, maturity, and an almost disinterested integrity. They find it in George W Bush.

Gore, sullied by association with Clinton and crippled by a stunning inability to convey his innate warmth and wit over the camera, falls wide of the mark.

Yet it is the positive aspects of Clinton's record, his successes more than his failures, that drive the voters into the arms of Bush. If crime were skyrocketing, unemployment high, inflation looming, a budget deficit crippling the economy, then voters would want a man with whom they would agree on these momentous issues. It is the very achievements of Clinton that leave them uninterested in what would otherwise be burning issues like crime, welfare, fiscal policies, foreign affairs, and social programmes.

Ungrateful for Clinton's accomplishments and unforgiving of his failures, Americans want the opposite of Bill Clinton for their next president. If he was a good president but a bad man, they want a good man to succeed him and they are not terribly worried about whether or not he will make a good president.

In deciding to stick with Clinton through scandal, America's head triumphed over its heart. In backing Bush and rejecting Gore, the heart is winning the day.

Dick Morris was chief strategist for President Clinton in his successful 1996 bid for re-election. He is head of www.vote.co.uk

fields.headline: Led by the nose
fields.standfirst:
When law officers saw my report, they dropped this secrets trial. But they should never have begun it

Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: The collapse of the planned Official Secrets Act trial of former Lieutentant- Colonel Nigel Wylde should have been foreseen within days of the ill-thought-out dawn raids on him and former Sunday Times chief reporter Tony Geraghty two years ago.
fields.body:
The collapse of the planned Official Secrets Act trial of former Lieutentant- Colonel Nigel Wylde should have been foreseen within days of the ill-thought-out dawn raids on him and former Sunday Times chief reporter Tony Geraghty two years ago.

Geraghty's book, The Irish War, contained extracts from classified army documents such as the 1997 Military Surveillance Strategy Northern Ireland. In the sections the army did not like, The Irish War mentioned their Caister/ Crucible computers, which contain intelligence data on most people living in Northern Ireland; the Vengeful computer, which tracks vehicle movements around the province; and the Glutton TV camera system, which scans and automatically reads number plates of vehicles at locations as far apart as Derry, Dover and Gretna Green.

But the MoD knew that the passages quoted from army documents would have given no aid to terrorists. Within three weeks, top Ministry of Defence civil servants concluded that the information disclosed was more of an embarrassment than a serious operational compromise. It presented no threat to lives.

The raids were inspired by fears that Geraghty possessed copies of the documents he had cited in his book. These did contain more secrets of Ulster spying. But after a squad of MoD police had turned over his country cottage for an entire day, they knew he didn't have any documents. Instead, they found notes of mere conversations, in which Wylde had given him limited information.

At this point, sanity should have prevailed. It didn't. The Labour government allowed the MoD police to push them into sanctioning the first Official Secrets Act charges against a journalist and a source since the last Labour government did so, 22 years earlier. Then, it was I and two others who faced trial for two months at the Old Bailey in the so-called ABC case (we were acquitted or discharged on all counts).

The attorney general eventually withdrew his approval for the Geraghty prosecution. But until the plug was pulled yesterday, Nigel Wylde was still facing a long trial. Well into six figures of public money has been wasted in dealing with lurid MoD allegations that what Wylde told Geraghty put both innocent civilians and soldiers' lives directly at risk.

The trial judge, Mr Justice Moses, had spotted the likely flaws in the MoD case. At a preliminary hearing in August, he suggested: "It is going to be like the ABC trial, is it not? Actually if you bother to look you can find all this anyway." The prosecution looked mystified. The defendant had to tell them what the ABC case was.

The issue that turned the tide in the ABC case was the government's farcical attempt to rename a key army witness "Colonel B". Next week, the Wylde prosecution was due to apply for an order to turn two key army witnesses against Wylde into "Major A" and "Major B".

They had also proposed to apply for evidence from them and the defence's expert witnesses to be heard in camera . I was one of those two defence experts. Last week, I submitted a 75-page report and 700 pages of exhibits, explaining why there was nothing in The Irish War that the Provisional IRA did not know or had not worked out for itself, 20 years ago. In a letter yesterday, prosecutors explained that the decision to drop the case was made after reading that report. The Vengeful computer was discussed in the London magazine Time Out as long ago as 1980. The next year, the IRA captured its operational instructions. It obtained an up-to-date set in January 1998. Details about Crucible had been revealed in a 1992 book, Big Boys Rules. Its author, BBC reporter Mark Urban, cleared his book with the MoD.

Many people in the army, the MoD and the intelligence services knew all about these compromises and previous disclosures. Yet nobody told the attorney general, until prosecutors took him my report on Tuesday. Why not?

After the ABC case, an eager young barrister wrote a monograph for the National Union of Journalists about the mistakes of the government, and the stupidity of the Official Secrets Act. His name was Tony Blair. As a newly elected MP four years later, he called on me at home, seeking copies of classified papers we had been leaked from the Bank of England.

Not long after, I was bearded by Arthur Davidson QC, the solicitor general at the time of the ABC case. He apologised, saying: "It was the worst mistake of my career." The government, he said, had been led by the nose by the security services.

One consequence of the abandoned case is that, as a court expert, I have had to be supplied with piles of classified paperwork about surveillance in Northern Ireland, plus a safe in which to keep them. They contain more information about the subject than Tony Geraghty ever knew. I am enjoined to silence about information that is not already public - which is exceedingly little. There is more information about surveillance centres in Ireland on Sinn Fein's website than in five volumes of alleged British government secrets.
Duncan Campbell (not the Guardian's US correspondent) specialises in intelligence journalism

fields.headline: Yesterday
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: Good day
fields.body:
Good day

Former Japanese prisoners of war: Tony Blair indicated that compensation for survivors of second world war far east camps could be announced next week in Gordon Brown's pre-Budget report.

Winner of day

Lord Carnarvon. The Queen's racing manager, speaking in the Lords, welcomed a government concession to exclude racehorse gallops from right to roam legislation. The crossbencher said it would have been "extremely dangerous" if the public crossed gallops as a result of their greater freedom to walk over heath and downland.

Dry day

webTitle: Matalan will double stores to rival M&S

fields.headline: Matalan will double stores to rival M&S
fields.trailText: Matalan is to double the number of its stores over the next six years as the discount retailer seeks to lure customers from rivals.
fields.body:
Matalan is to double the number of its stores over the next six years as the discount retailer seeks to lure customers from rivals.

The out of town, "value for money" chain yesterday claimed it was already the country's sixth largest clothing retailer, up from 10th last year after grabbing customers from catalogue companies and stores such as Bhs, Littlewoods and C&A.

Matalan cited statistics showing it sells its clothes, a mixture of its own brand and others such as Playtex and Falmer, at least 50% cheaper than rivals such as George in Asda, Next and Marks & Spencer.

The plan to open a further 8.5m square feet of new retail space would mean that only the troubled M&S had more sales space than Matalan - still 52%-owned by founder John Hargreaves.

Ian Smith, the finance director, said Matalan aimed to increase the number of its stores to 240 in six years from the 121 it will have by the end of this year.

The company, which yesterday reported a 72% rise in pretax profits to £35m for the first half of the year, also plans to diversify into financial services, offering discount credit cards to its 5.2m "members" though Yorkshire Bank. Personal loans and insurance are also expected to be offered, and it is developing a website.

Mr Smith said its stores had reported a 32.8% rise in like for like sales in the first six months. Sales would have been £4m higher had it not been for the fuel crisis earlier in the year which deterred customers from reaching its stores.

He attributed Matalan's success in attracting customers, at time when many rivals were feeling the pain on the high street, to "outstanding value for money, scale and range". The George label in Asda is 59% more expensive than its clothes, while Next is 151% more expensive and M&S 145% dearer, according to independent research cited by Matalan.

One leading investor said Matalan was an example of a company which had a "good concept". He said: "They make it difficult for rivals to compete by running more cheaply in out of town centres and having a high turnover of stock."

Mike Godliman, a director retailing consultancy firm Verdict Research, said: "People are prepared to buy from discounters, even ABC1s. The goods are very fashionable and they get new stock in frequently."

Matalan said that its 5.2m members, who pay a £1 fee to join, had a demographic profile which "broadly reflects that of the UK in general". It is using its database to target people which are not already customers and is also spending more on television advertising than it was last year.

Matalan's tightly held shares yesterday rose to a new closing high of 703p, up 53p.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: 180 jobs axed at Rolls-Royce
fields.body:
180 jobs axed at Rolls-Royce

Aero-engine maker Rolls-Royce is to close one of its factories with the loss of 180 jobs. The composites manufacturing plant in Derby, which makes glass fibre and carbon fibre jet engine parts, will close by the middle of next year.

Rolls announced that the work will be contracted out to Austrian firm Fischer Advanced Composite Components. The move is expected to save £3m a year for the next five years.

Luminar opens 40 new clubs

Luminar, the nightclub operator which doubled in size with the acqusition of Northern Leisure in the summer, is planning to open 40 new outlets next year. Expansion plans were announced yesterday following a trebling in pre-tax profits from £4.3m to £13.2m which sent the share price racing to 695p, up 30p.

Axa loses court round

The Consumers' Association yesterday won the first round of its legal battle against insurance group Axa's plans for dividing up £1.7bn in surplus cash.

The association said the insurer was not offering its 660,000 policyholders a fair share of the so-called "orphan assets", and yesterday the high court ruled that Axa should pay £100,000 costs so that policyholder Stuart MacWhirter's challenge can be properly heard in court.

The association has been helping Mr MacWhirter, a chartered accountant in London, to take his case to court after he objected to the way Axa is planning to distribute the surplus money.

Lynx errors found

Shares in British financial software firm Lynx Group were hit yesterday after the company said it had uncovered accounting errors and issued a profits warning. It expects to make not less than £10.5m profit compared with £11m last year. Analysts had been expecting profits of £10.8m to £12.3m for the year to September 30.

The company said the £10.5m figure did not include £5m in accounting errors in its Value Added Distribution business. The division's finance director resigned after the company uncovered the mistake which went on for a number of years.

Lynx shares ended up 0.5p at 111.5p after pulling back from large early falls.

Centrica buys Avalanche

Centrica, the ever-expanding energy, home and roadside services group, paid £114.5m for Canada's Avalanche Energy.

In August the group became the latest British utility to seek greater earnings outside the sway of British regulators by buying Direct Energy in Calgary for £406m.

Avalanche, a small, independent producer, owns fields in Alberta, accounting for 90% of its assets. Most of the gas is uncontracted, giving Centrica direct access.

The acquisition, due to be completed by the end of this month, brings Centrica close to its target of owning 20% of the gas it supplies to its Canadian customers.

webTitle: Byers under fire for soft pedalling on bosses' pay

fields.headline: Byers under fire for soft pedalling on bosses' pay
fields.trailText: The government came under fire last night for having delayed legal measures to give shareholders more say over boardroom pay for up to three more years.
fields.body:
The government came under fire last night for having delayed legal measures to give shareholders more say over boardroom pay for up to three more years.

Accusing ministers of a "deafening silence" over their initial plans to curb directors' excessive pay, David Gould, head of investment services at the national association of pension funds, NAPF, said it could be as late as 2003 before they were implemented.

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary - who once raised the prospect of directors being forced to stand for re-election every year - is now understood to favour a much milder measure to ensure shareholder control over boardroom remuneration.

Giving the government's long awaited response to an 18-month consultation period in the new year, he is expected to abandon a once favoured option of forcing a vote each year at annual company meetings on their remuneration committee reports.

Legislation has been ruled out of December's shortened Queen's speech to placate industry and the City before the general election. Amid signs of cabinet splits on the issue, Mr Byers is instead likely to favour measures to shorten the notice period - now six weeks - for shareholders to table resolutions at annual meetings.

Industry sources said this could involve pre-publication of reports on firms' websites, enabling shareholders to see remuneration committee reports early and table critical resolutions.

Mr Byers' friends think this will achieve the same effect as forcing annual shareholder votes but Mr Gould rebutted this, saying firms were under no legal obligation to publish remuneration reports annually.

Ministers have been encouraged by evidence such as the shareholders' revolt against a £10m package to Vodafone's Chris Gent to believe the campaign against boardroom excess has borne fruit. "When we started hardly anybody turned up for annual meeting votes," one Whitehall source said.

But Mr Gould disputed the feeling that the issue was "no longer hot". He said: "We have not yet been able to demonstrate a very clear link between enhanced pay and performance." Rewards for failure had, however, gone down as directors' contracts had shortened to around two years.

Other shareholder groups are more sanguine about the issue, arguing that legislation may be unnecessary.

webTitle: UN welcomes Yugoslavia and furls Tito's flag

fields.headline: UN welcomes Yugoslavia and furls Tito's flag
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Yugoslavia has been accepted as a member of the United Nations as a reward for its people's decision to vote Slobodan Milosevic out of power.
fields.body:
Yugoslavia has been accepted as a member of the United Nations as a reward for its people's decision to vote Slobodan Milosevic out of power. The security council has agreed unanimously to admit Yugoslavia even though the new president, Vojislav Kostunica, has not formally accepted the jurisdiction of the UN-appointed international criminal tribunal which indicted his predecessor for war crimes.

Diplomats said the decision followed heavy pressure from America's UN envoy, Richard Holbrooke. He also persuaded other UN members, in particular Bosnia, Croatia, Macedonia and Slovenia, not to tie the issue to outstanding property claims arising from the dissolution of the former Yugoslavia.

No progress was made on the tangled financial and legal question of the Yugoslav succession while Mr Milosevic was in power. These governments had been hoping that Mr Kostunica could reopen matters such as the seizure by Belgrade of most of the old Yugoslav embassies around the world as well as the assets of the old National Bank of Yugoslavia and the airline, JAT.

The need for the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia to apply for UN membership stemmed from a resolution of the general assembly in September 1992 which followed the breakup of the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia. It ruled that the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, comprising Serbia and Montenegro, could not automatically continue the membership of the former Yugoslavia.

The UN's 1992 decision was important since it meant the new FRY could not claim to be the state from which the other republics had seceded, but that it was also a new creation. This has profound legal implications for the status of Kosovo, which never joined the new FRY by consent.

Paradoxically, however, the old flag of President Tito's Yugoslavia was allowed to go on flying outside UN headquarters in New York as though the old state still existed.

Lawyers are expected to argue for months over the details of the succession but Mr Holbrooke cut across them with the decision to rush Mr Kostunica's application for membership at full speed.

"This is a great day for democracy - in the Balkans, in Europe - and a great day for the United Nations," he said. "Eight years of sterile, stupid argument over Yugoslav membership in the United Nations is over. That terrible flag of Tito's flying on First Avenue comes down. It's a tremendous day."

Mr Holbrooke met the new Yugoslav president at a meeting of Balkan leaders in Macedonia last week and reportedly came away highly impressed.

In spite of the US haste in welcoming Mr Kostunica, there is concern in several European capitals over the new president's first steps in regional policy.

Croatian officials point out that there are more Croats than Serbs in detention in the Hague thanks to their government's willingness to co-operate with the tribunal since the death of Franjo Tudjman, the nationalist leader. They wonder why Mr Kostunica is being embraced so quickly without more movement by him to hand Serb war criminals over.

Western European governments are also unhappy with Mr Kostunica's clumsy visit to Bosnia last week when he went to the Bosnian Serb entity before travelling briefly to the capital, Sarajevo. The prospect is growing that the hardline nationalist party, the SDS, once led by indicted war criminal Radovan Karadzic, may do well in next week's Bosnian elections. Although Mr Karadzic no longer has direct influence over the party, some diplomats fear that Mr Kostunica may increase Belgrade's links with the SDS.

There is also concern over his criticism of the UN-run local elections in Kosovo as invalid. He based his argument on the fact that the Serbs of Kosovo chose to boycott them. Diplomats are surprised that a constitutional lawyer such as Mr Kostunica should imply they were illegal. In political terms, his remark was a disturbing sign that he feels a need to put Kosovo on his list of priorities when there are major internal issues, such as the economy and the energy crisis, to deal with. Mr Kostunica has also started off poorly with Montenegro, although he did make the gesture yesterday of travelling to Podgorica for talks with President Djukanovic for a meeting of the supreme defence council.

Montenegro is calling for a complete overhaul of the federation. One new Montenegrin demand was for a separate seat in the United Nations as a sign that Serbia and Montenegro are both sovereign states.

The American rush to give Mr Kostunica UN membership was partly designed to head off the Montenegrin demand.

webTitle: Back in the black - Hamleys cuts pay off

fields.headline: Back in the black - Hamleys cuts pay off
fields.trailText: Hamleys has clawed its way back into the black for the first half of the year through selling higher margins toys and chopping senior jobs and perks.
fields.body:
Hamleys has clawed its way back into the black for the first half of the year through selling higher margins toys and chopping senior jobs and perks.

But the company based around the famous Regent Street store is warning that trading conditions remain tough, with a fall in tourist numbers and no obvious big sellers for Christmas.

The City marked up the shares 2.5p to 133.5p but one of the followers of the stock, Seymour Pierce, has cut its full year profit estimates from £4.5m to £4m. In the six months to September 23, profits before tax touched £9,000 compared to a loss of £2.6m - despite continuing refurbishment work at its Regent Street base.

Group like for like sales were unchanged, with the recovery in profits coming from the increased sale of own brand goods and cheaper sourced goods.

Simon Burke, who came from Virgin to take over as chief executive last year, plans to take out £500,000 of costs this year. Mr Burke has been acting chairman of Hamleys since the retirement of Howard Dyer - who left amid complaints of corporate excess.

A new chairman is expected to be appointed and there will be a further assault on corporate waste, both at Regent Street and inside its Toystack outlets.

Mr Burke was "pretty pleased" with the financial results in the first half because the market had been difficult - in part due to a 10% reduction in European tourists coming to London.

But he expected to make further progress in the second half: "Margins moved up strongly from 49.6% to £53.4% and I will be disappointed if we do not improve this by a further two points in the second half."

fields.headline: Kostunica frees Kosovo activist
fields.standfirst: Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: A prominent Kosovo Albanian human rights activist has been released from jail in Serbia, prompting hopes that more political prisoners, estimated to number about 1,000, may soon be released.
fields.body:
A prominent Kosovo Albanian human rights activist has been released from jail in Serbia, prompting hopes that more political prisoners, estimated to number about 1,000, may soon be released.

Flora Bravina, a 50-year-old paediatrician and longtime opponent of Serbian rule in Kosovo, was released on the orders of the Yugoslav president, Vojislav Kostunica.

She was arrested by Serbian police in Kosovo during last year's Nato bombing campaign and transferred to prison in Serbia when Yugoslav forces withdrew from the province.

"Justice has been served," said Mrs Bravina's lawyer, Branko Stanic, as she was driven out of a women's prison in Pozarevac.

The order for her release was brought to the prison by the president's own legal adviser, Filip Golubovic.

In December last year, Mrs Bravina was charged with terrorism and sentenced to 12 years in prison, based on what the court alleged were links between her and the Kosovo Liberation Army.

That sentence was quashed by the Serbian supreme court earlier this summer. A new trial was ordered and was due to take place on November 16.

The campaign for the release of Mrs Bravina and hundreds of other political prisoners has dominated the political debate in Kosovo over the last year, and President Kostunica has been under pressure from the west to free them.

Some prisoners were released while Slobodan Milosevic was still in power, but hopes of more progress on the issue were raised when Mr Kostunica took over. Kosovo's three leading Albanian parties mentioned the issue of prisoners in their first response to the political changes in Belgrade.

A motion to enable their relese is expected to be tabled before the Serbian parliament soon. Initially the prisoners' status was linked to progress on finding around 1,000 Serbs who went missing in Kosovo during and after the war.

The head of the UN Mission in Kosovo, Bernard Kouchner, welcomed Mrs Bravina's release, adding that she had been "sorely missed" and that she should never have been sentenced to jail.

He also urged Mr Kostunica to go further and ensure the release of the remaining political prisoners. That, he said, "would be a major stride towards meaningful dialogue and...peace".

Mrs Bravina had earlier told her family that she would not leave jail unless her fellow inmates were released too. This prompted concern among some of the new Yugoslav government's advisers. The US and British governments have called for all political prisoners to be set free.

fields.headline: Letter: Peter Huntingford
fields.trailText: Peter Huntingford (Obituary, October 30) was a remarkable doctor, not least because he identified more with his patients than with his medical peers.
fields.body:
Peter Huntingford (Obituary, October 30) was a remarkable doctor, not least because he identified more with his patients than with his medical peers. For a BBC2 television documentary in the mid 1970s, he was filmed in his shirtsleeves, sitting on the floor of a North London house with a group of leading feminist health activists, arguing (and mostly agreeing about) the politics of obstetric care. It's hard to imagine another consultant obstetrician then - or now - being prepared to open himself to that kind of lay debate.

Indeed, most of his fellow obstetricians of the time were still unreconstructed defenders of medical (and male) power. A registrar in one of his antenatal clinics, when asked why he had chosen to specialise in obstetrics, replied that he liked having women as patients because they laughed at his jokes. To doctors like that, the power-sharing Peter with his matinee idol looks was unfathomable.

Although an early and staunch advocate of natural childbirth, Huntingford was ready to put women's preferences first. When a woman who had had a gruelling first labour came and asked him for a fully interventionist second one, epidural and all, he respected her decision.

He was also unusual in understanding the social aspects of obstetrics.He would tell medical students that a mother's social class was more important than her age in shaping her baby's health, long before most obstetricians were prepared to concede the fact.

Nor did he lose interest in babies once born. During a ward round one day, he was perturbed by the persistent sound of a baby crying. Finding the cot, he picked the baby up, soothed it and drew the staff's attention to its sopping wet nappy. It's an indictment of traditional consultant behaviour that the medical students were agog.

But, although Huntingford was extraordinarily engaged as a doctor, there was always something elusive about him. One sensed that he found intimacy difficult and his exclusion from the medical establishment in some sense gratifying. He chose the role of outsider.

fields.headline: George Armstrong
fields.standfirst: Professional footballer who played with courage and generosity
fields.trailText: George Armstrong, the former Arsenal winger, one of the heroes of their famous 1971 League and Cup double side, and latterly reserve team coach, has died suddenly after collapsing on the club's Hertfordshire training field, aged 56.
fields.body:
George Armstrong, the former Arsenal winger, one of the heroes of their famous 1971 League and Cup double side, and latterly reserve team coach, has died suddenly after collapsing on the club's Hertfordshire training field, aged 56.

He was Arsenal to the marrow, making 621 first-team appearances in a 15-year playing career, to be surpassed only by the present Leeds United manager, David O' Leary with 722 and now Tony Adams (624).

In an age when the traditional winger was due to disappear, "Geordie" Armstrong, as he was always known, was the winger par excellence, able to play on the right or the left, two footed, and an unselfish creator of chances for other people with his accurate crosses.

Born in Hebburn, County Durham, Armstrong went to Highbury straight from school, discovered by Arsenal's north-eastern scout. He played his initial game for the first team in 1961, and 10 years later was a salient figure in the team which became only the second of the 20th century, after Tottenham, to win the FA Cup and League double. That season he figured in every one of the 42 championship games, and was on the right wing at Wembley, the only real winger in the Arsenal side for the winning cup final against Liverpool.

He was no giant, standing a mere 5ft 6in and weighing just over 11 stone, but courage was never lacking; not when he was playing with the local Leslie's Boys Club, nor in his long professional career.

Typically, in the cup final, Armstrong popped up on either flank and very nearly scored when, on the far post, he surged powerfully in from the left to meet a right-wing cross from John Radford. Ray Clemence, the Liverpool goalkeeper, catapulted across goal to parry the ball.

In 1970, he had won a medal in the European Inter Cities Fairs Cup, and the following season scored one of the two goals whereby Arsenal, in the same competition, beat Lazio 2-0 at home. In 1972, he was on the losing Arsenal side in the FA Cup final against Leeds United. He also played in two losing League Cup finals, in 1968 and 1969.

In 1977, he left Arsenal to play for Leicester City, and finished his career at Stockport County. He then became a coach with steady success, cutting his teeth in Kuwait, before returning to coach at Aston Villa and Fulham. Almost inevitably, perhaps, he returned to Highbury, brought back in 1990 by his former team mate George Graham who said: "He was such a thorough professional and a great help to me at Arsenal. As soon as I knew he was available when he was out in the Middle East I jumped at the chance to bring him back."

Armstrong proved outstandingly successful at nurturing young talent. Ray Parlour, a current first-team player and an England international, was one of his protegés in the reserve team, as was the Scottish striker Paul Dickov, who has gained honours this season with Scotland, as a Manchester City striker. The centre backs Andy Lininghan and future Northern Ireland international Stephen Morrow, also came under his aegis.

Money meant little to him and he was critical of the attitude of many modern players. One who knew him well at Arsenal observed that "football flowed out of him". He was humorous, modest, unfailingly genial, and survived the various changing of the guard at Highbury in recent years.

He was never a prolific goalscorer, getting just seven in that 1970/71 championship season and 70 in his Highbury career. Typically perhaps, his speciality was in creating goals for colleagues.

He is survived by his wife Marjorie, and their son and daughter.

George "Geordie" Armstrong, footballer, born August 9 1944; died November 1 2000.

fields.headline: Alfred Hancox
fields.standfirst: Engineer and early champion of environmental awareness
fields.trailText: Alfred (Hank) Hancox, who has died aged 80, was recognised for his many contributions to combustion and fuel engineering. Originally seen as essentially an energy-saving exercise, his work is now recognised as a vital precursor of current urgent ecological concerns.
fields.body:
Alfred (Hank) Hancox, who has died aged 80, was recognised for his many contributions to combustion and fuel engineering. Originally seen as essentially an energy-saving exercise, his work is now recognised as a vital precursor of current urgent ecological concerns.

Hank Hancox was born in Oldbury in the West Midlands and left school at 14. He entered a seven-year apprenticeship with Edward Danks Boiler Manufacturers. On the completion of his indenture, he continued to attend night school until the age of 28, when he attained membership of the Institute of Mechanical Engineers. At the same time, he went to work with the then major tube manufacturers, Stewart and Lloyds, and participated in the company's war effort.

In 1947, he laid the basis for his career by moving to the then ministry of fuel and power, heading a mobile testing station charged with improving, on a national level, the efficiency of fuel use. While the ministry's overt intention was the saving of fuel, an increasingly important side effect was the direct and indirect reduction of pollution.

Essentially, Hank enjoyed a roaming brief as an inadvertent environmental agency. In Scotland, his first investigation led to a long-term and fruitful relationship with Peter McGeoch, the managing director of a Clydeside chain-maker, whose love of the Scottish outdoors meshed perfectly with Hank's, and resulted in a prompt move to Glasgow.

From 1951 he lived the rest of his life in Scotland except for a two-year interruption due to a posting to Newcastle. Inevitably, his ability and dedication led to his appointment as Scottish manager of the ministry of fuel and power, subsequently devolved and renamed the National Industrial Fuel Efficiency Service (Nifes).

In 1970, aged 50, he took the daring decision to set up his own consultancy with which he continued to be in close contact, long after his retirement in 1985. Hank was an outstanding and highly innovative contributor to the expanding field of combustion engineering, where his rare amalgam of theory, practice, knowledge and intuition came to creative fruition.

A pragmatic and intellectual problem solver, he enjoyed helping colleagues, patiently passed information and discoveries to the less experienced. In the 1960s and 70s the rapid technical changes resulting from the replacement of coal burning by oil and gas not only provided additional commissions, but an opportunity for Hancox to engage and develop his great love of tall chimneys. The complexity of chimney design and function, massively enhanced by fuel changes, involved, among other problems, higher temperatures, condensation and more demanding pollution standards.

Hank had a lifelong love of the outdoors. As a boy, he saved earnings from a paper round to buy a bicycle. An idealistic Old Labour man, cycling and youth-hostelling influenced and expressed his political and social development and attitudes. In England he biked everywhere, from the Lake District to Lands End; in Scotland, he skied, sailed and hillwalked, no longer a solitary cyclist, but surrounded by a family.

The tall industrial chimney was a comparable opportunity for unharnessed climbing. He found the mixture of physical effort and courage, practicality and wonderful views, irresistible. His interest resulted in unusually ambitious papers to the Institute of Energy during his chairmanship (1972/73). He co-founded the International Chimney Symposium in 1973 and chaired its second meeting in Edinburgh.

Unsurprisingly, he remained remarkably fit and healthy into old age. At 75, on the 50th anniversary of his first of many mountain ascents, he easily got to the summit of Ben Lomond. Physically undiminished, he acquired an allotment to practise organic gardening. In pursuit of lifelong and energetic DIYing, his self-built allotment hut gained the attention of the BBC which used it for a Rab C Nesbitt episode. Characteristically, he donated the fee towards a composting toilet for all the gardeners.

He leaves behind a beloved and environmentally improved Scotland and is survived by two daughters from a previous marriage, and by his wife, Sonja, two sons and a daughter.

Alfred Leslie Hancox, engineer, born September 18 1920; died September 28 2000

fields.headline: Irene Ivison
fields.standfirst: Child protection campaigner
fields.trailText: Her work in the field of child prostitution made her a key figure during government consultation on the recent national plan against the sexual exploitation of children.
fields.body:
In 1996 Irene Ivison, who has died aged 54, set up the Coalition for the Removal of Pimping (Crop), an organisation that was to be a major influence on public policy and practice throughout the UK and beyond. Her work in the field of child prostitution made her a key figure during government consultation on the recent national plan against the sexual exploitation of children.

Her involvement stemmed from a personal tragedy. In 1993, her daughter, Fiona, was murdered at the age of 17 by a "punter", having been exploited into prostitution by her older "boyfriend". Ivison had not known that Fiona had been working as a street prostitute for three weeks before her death, although she had spent the previous three years battling with police and social services to try and stop the abusive relationship in which her daughter had been involved since the age of 14.

Ivison was born in Oxford, but moved to Sheffield to attend university and train as a physiotherapist. There she met and married her husband and had three children. After Fiona's death she turned into a formidable campaigner: described by one senior police officer as "a woman who re-acted to her daughter's death with intelligence, sense and an extraordinary lack of bitterness".

In 1997, her book about her daughter, Fiona's Story, was published. It won praise from professionals and activists in the area of child protection and criminal justice. A year later she helped to set up the UK's first re-education programme for men caught using street prostitutes. By describing the life and death of her daughter, she appealed to the men to stop and think about the reality of prostitution for the women.

Organising conferences and seminars on child prostitution, writing articles for the local press and appearing on television and radio, Ivison became influential in the recent change of direction taken by the police and social services: child prostitutes are now seen as victims, not criminals.

In 1997 she organised a major national conference on the issues of pimping. It resulted in the government putting the issue high on the agenda. Ivison was consulted by the department of health and the home office and helped to draft the National Plan to Prevent Sexual Exploitation of Children and the Sexual Offences Review.

Ivison's death is tragic on many levels, not least for the young women and children in prostitution who have lost such a forceful advocate. She was widely respected even by those who disagreed with her.

Her husband pre-deceased her. She is survived by her two remaining children.

Irene Ivison, activist and campaigner, born March 5 1946; died October 20 2000.

fields.headline: Airline to handcuff unruly passengers
fields.trailText: Passengers enjoying Swissair's cabin service next year should not be surprised if they see flight attendants wrestling rowdy passengers to the floor and tying them up.
fields.body:
Passengers enjoying Swissair's cabin service next year should not be surprised if they see flight attendants wrestling rowdy passengers to the floor and tying them up.

The airline, widely regarded as a backbone of Switzerland's tourist industry, said it would supply plastic ties to cabin staff next year and authorise them to restrain any passengers endangering flight safety.

"Staff training will begin in the next days with instructors from the police force," Rainer Meier, a Swissair spokesman, said yesterday. The airline is drawing up guidelines to set out exactly when flight attendants can try to make use of the new manoeuvres.

"Before we get out the handcuffs, there are other, gentler measures," he added.

There were 502 cases involving "unruly passengers" on Swissair last year, nearly double the number recorded in 1996. The figure includes people persistently smoking in the toilet.

In several instances planes have been diverted and crew members have suffered minor injuries. Female staff in particular are increasingly the targets of physical harassment.

Earlier this year a flight from Moscow to Geneva was disrupted by Spartak football supporters travelling to a match in Spain. With half of the passengers involved in a brawl, cabin crew struggled to follow current practice which involves isolating individuals and speaking to them to calm them down.

Swiss police confiscated the supporters' vodka and eventually let them take a connecting flight to Spain after they promised to calm down. Swissair said alcohol was frequently a cause of trouble.

Although the practice of restraining unruly passengers is common in the United States, it is still rare in Europe.

But Riet Niggli, of Switzerland's cabin staff union, warned that it was a dangerous practice "not recommended by police forces all over the world".

webTitle: Networkers for whom the web is not enough

fields.headline: Networkers for whom the web is not enough
fields.standfirst:
Adobe has trained its sights on a digital publishing opportunity worth $64bn a year
Net news
fields.trailText: While the media industries have come a long, long way over the last couple of centuries, computer publishing has, arguably, moved just as far within a significantly shorter timespell. There are, however, also signs that for some firms it may not be moving fast enough.
fields.byline: John Cassy in San Jose, California
fields.body:
While the media industries have come a long, long way over the last couple of centuries, computer publishing has, arguably, moved just as far within a significantly shorter timespell. There are, however, also signs that for some firms it may not be moving fast enough.

Adobe Systems has had to evolve through several seismic technological shifts since opening its first office in Silicon Valley in 1982.

First came its pioneering desktop publishing product, Postscript, which enabled anyone with a personal computer and a printer to publish a magazine or newsletter from their home.

The arrival of the internet then forced Adobe to adapt its software to the demands of customers who wanted to spread their corporate message on to the web.

Now the proliferation of internet-enabled devices that allow content to be delivered any time to any place has forced the San Jose company to shift its focus once again to the "third wave" of publishing: network publishing. Chief executive and co-founder John Warnock, 52, claims it will dramatically change the way content is created, managed and delivered.

"Leveraging the internet, Network Publishing represents the third wave of publishing - following desktop and web publishing," he said. "It's the era of creating visually rich, meaningful content that is managed and delivered reliably wherever the user wants, whether it's a web page, printer, cellphone, handheld device, PC or internet appliance."

Mr Warnock said customers were no longer prepared to make do with a simple website. They want their corporate messages delivered to customers and mobile workforces regardless of when or where they are in the world.

Adobe has struck the first of what it says will be several partnership agreements with distributors like Nokia, Hewlett Packard and RealNetworks. Its role will be to automatically repurpose content to fit televisions, PCs, or far smaller mobile phone screens before it is sent or streamed direct to the user.

Adobe estimates that the whole business of the "paperless network publishing space" will be worth $64bn per year by 2004.

Through products including Photoshop and Acrobat it currently generates annual revenues of around $1bn and is America's third largest software firm. Its shares have risen 10 times in the past two years.

The last year has seen concerted moves into electronic books where it is going head to head with Microsoft and several smaller specialist firms.

"We don't believe students and professionals should have to carry 20lb of books and documents," said Mr Warnock.

Acrobat, which allows documents to be electronically transmitted in PDF (portable document format), is fast becoming a standard application for business. Cutting out print, paper, design and mail costs also makes economic sense.

Adobe is banking on ambitious forecasts for the take up of internet-enabled mobile phones and broadband services to the home.

Mr Warnock is forced to admit that the 300m internet-enabled mobile phones that Nokia believes it will ship next year is an "unrealistic figure".

Last year Adobe managed a new professional publishing tool to take on market leader Quark, but first-year revenues were 40% below projections.

The company has found to its cost what happens when products run late. In 1998 a key piece of software was delayed and, combined with cooling market conditions in Japan, revenues and the share price tumbled. Several senior executives had to be cleared out before stability returned.

The pitfalls of failing to deal with "disruptive technologies" are plain to see just a few miles north of Adobe's headquarters where Xerox, one of the great firms of the 1980s, is struggling to stay afloat. "We'll keep on throwing technology at it until we get it right," said Mr Warnock.

Chief executive and co-founder John Warnock, 52, claims it will dramatically change the way content is created, managed and delivered. "Leveraging the internet, Network Publishing represents the third wave of publishing - following desktop and web publishing," he said. "It's the era of creating visually rich, meaningful content that is managed and delivered reliably wherever the user wants, whether it's a web page, printer, cellphone, handheld device, PC or internet appliance." Mr Warnock said customers were no longer prepared to make do with a simple website. They want their corporate messages delivered to customers and mobile workforces regardless of when or where they are in the world. Adobe has struck the first of what it says will be several partnership agreements with distributors like Nokia, Hewlett Packard and RealNetworks. Its role will be to automatically repurpose content to fit televisions, PCs, or far smaller mobile phone screens before it is sent or streamed direct to the user. Adobe estimates that the whole business of the "paperless network publishing space" will be worth $64bn per year by 2004. Through products including Photoshop and Acrobat it currently generates annual revenues of around $1bn and is America's third largest software firm. Its shares have risen 10 times in the past two years. The last year has seen concerted moves into electronic books where it is going head to head with Microsoft and several smaller specialist firms. "We don't believe students and professionals should have to carry 20lb of books and documents," said Mr Warnock. Acrobat, which allows documents to be electronically transmitted in PDF (portable document format), is fast becoming a standard application for business. Cutting out print, paper, design and mail costs also makes economic sense. Adobe is banking on ambitious forecasts for the take up of internet-enabled mobile phones and broadband services to the home. Mr Warnock is forced to admit that the 300m internet-enabled mobile phones that Nokia believes it will ship next year is an "unrealistic figure". Last year Adobe managed a new professional publishing tool to take on market leader Quark, but first-year revenues were 40% below projections. The company has found to its cost what happens when products run late. In 1998 a key piece of software was delayed and, combined with cooling market conditions in Japan, revenues and the share price tumbled. Several senior executives had to be cleared out before stability returned. The pitfalls of failing to deal with "disruptive technologies" are plain to see just a few miles north of Adobe's headquarters where Xerox, one of the great firms of the 1980s, is struggling to stay afloat. "We'll keep on throwing technology at it until we get it right," said Mr Warnock.

webTitle: Leader: What Napster did cannot be undone

fields.headline: A pact with Goliath
fields.standfirst:
But what Napster did cannot be undone

Net news
fields.trailText: Napster's termination of its "free-for-all" approach to online music by doing a deal with media giant Bertelsmann looks like David selling his soul to Goliath for a quiet life. But it does not mean the end of swapping music (or films, or books or anything else that can be digitised) on the internet.
fields.body:
Napster's termination of its "free-for-all" approach to online music by doing a deal with media giant Bertelsmann looks like David selling his soul to Goliath for a quiet life. But it does not mean the end of swapping music (or films, or books or anything else that can be digitised) on the internet. Napster, headed by Shawn Fanning, a 18-year-old college drop-out, started life as an "us versus them" move to swap songs without charge on the internet. In two years, it has become the most spectacularly successful phenomenon in the brief history of the world wide web. More than 38m people around the world have downloaded the software enabling them to swap music files from their hard disks without paying.

Not without reason, the music industry has been apoplectic. The big corporations, fearing their royalties would disappear down a web plughole, ganged together to sue Napster (even though sales of CDs continued to rise during Napster's ascent). Now, one of them, Bertelsmann, has broken ranks to a buy a stake in Napster and to negotiate royalty payments through a membership system. The trouble (for them) is that Napster has already spawned dozens of similar "peer-to-peer" (P2P) services, which avoid legal pitfalls by dispatching their files direct from computer to computer instead of shunting them through a central server.

No matter what happens to Napster, napsterisation will march on. If music can cut out the computer in the middle, then so can films, books, audio and electronic commerce - a warning to all the business-to-business electronic market places now being constructed. Millions of Napster's devotees may now migrate to other P2P sites with the feeling that the pioneer has sold his soul. They have no objection to artists being rewarded for their copyrights. But many will feel that this is just another way for corporate middlemen to cream off a disproportionate share of artists' income. This war is only just beginning.

fields.headline: Anxious times for the revolution
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: British companies are experiencing a "climate of anxiety" over their role in the e-commerce revolution, according to research published yesterday.
fields.body:
British companies are experiencing a "climate of anxiety" over their role in the e-commerce revolution, according to research published yesterday.

A survey of 300 companies of different sizes and across a range of industries found that fewer than half (46%) were pursuing, or had implemented, an e-commerce plan. Of this minority, 84% had their own website but only 2% used the site for online transactions, according to E-Business Review magazine.

David Bicknell, the magazine's managing editor, said: "It is clear that UK plc lacks confidence about its preparations for the e-economy.

"Our research suggests that perhaps the main constraining factors are still the lack of skilled individuals to make e-business in the UK happen and a general lack of knowledge. Until we have a genned-up, e-skilled workforce, the climate of anxiety about moving forward will continue to grow."

The survey also found that 31% of executives responsible for e-commerce felt their companies had been losing interest in the internet and were falling behind rivals. Only 22% felt they were ahead of competitors.

In focus group research, banks, building societies and retail chains were among businesses which confessed to soft pedalling on e-commerce. They were still monitoring their websites, and the broader online market, rather than offering transactions over the web or linking up key partners or suppliers, the research showed.

Some organisations added that e-business was now low on their corporate priority list.

Among the concerns voiced were difficulties in acquiring and keeping skilled staff, problems integrating websites with established departments and the marketing costs of a high-profile web presence.

Some firms had experienced difficulties after leaving online strategy to their marketing departments, with IT personnel given responsibility only for implementation.

But Martha Bennett, vice-president of research in Europe for Giga Information Group, said that the pendulum swing away from e-commerce belied the business opportunities still available on the web.

"There is a golden opportunity right now, especially for existing companies that have perhaps been a bit slow in adapting to the internet," she said. "It is the perfect time for them to recruit the much needed technical staff and get their websites working for them.

"We need to get out of the mind set of thinking about on and off-line companies. Firms with strong existing brands can easily benefit from from the the internet as an additional channel of trade.

"There is evidence emerging that those companies with a wide variety of transaction channels tend to be the most profitable."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Australia horse cull condemned
fields.body:
Australia horse cull condemned

Animal welfare groups and local people yesterday condemned the "barbaric" shooting of around 620 wild Australian horses, after marksmen in helicopters left bodies scattered across the Guy Fawkes national park, 300 miles north of Sydney.

The New South Wales environment minister, Bob Debus, ordered a review of such aerial culls.

Patrick Barkham, Sydney.

Chechen rebels kill 14 Russians

Rebels ambushed a police convoy on a road in eastern Chechnya, leaving six Russians dead, officials said yesterday.

Eight more Russian servicemen died in rebel attacks around the breakaway republic, an official of Chechnya's pro-Russian administration in Gudermes said.

AP, Nazran.

Diplomatic boost for Iraq

The Jordanian prime minister, Ali Abu al-Ragheb, arrived in Baghdad yesterday, Iraqi officials said.

They said Mr Ragheb, the highest-ranking Arab official to visit Iraq for a decade, was accompanied by seven ministers. The trip is aimed at expanding bilateral ties.

Reuters, Baghdad.

Iran tries to make US pay

Iran's parliament voted yesterday to allow courts to impose punitive damages on America for "terrorist" acts, such as the US navy's shooting down of an Iran Air plane in 1988.

The move comes after the US agreed to pay huge damages to victims of Iranian "state-sponsored terrorism".

Reuters, Tehran.

fields.headline: Hillary's race gets tighter
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Hillary Clinton and her opponent in the contest for a seat in the United States senate were engaged in a frantic scramble to get out the vote yesterday as yet another poll suggested that the race is in New York is becoming tighter.
fields.body:
Hillary Clinton and her opponent in the contest for a seat in the United States senate were engaged in a frantic scramble to get out the vote yesterday as yet another poll suggested that the race is in New York is becoming tighter.

Most polls during the past month have shown Mrs Clinton beating Rick Lazio, her Republican opponent, comfortably, but that has changed this week. Now both sides acknowledge that next Tuesday's vote will be decided by the team which is most effective in mobilising its supporters.

"It is critical," said Bill Dal Col, Mr Lazio's campaign manager. "It is absolutely the whole race."

The matter has been complicated by the absence of both Al Gore and George W Bush in New York: neither is campaigning here because they know it is all but certain that Mr Gore will carry the state in the presidential election on the same day.

Only 44% of the electorate went to the polls in New York four years ago. If Democrats, who have 2m more votes in the state, assume that the presidential election is a foregone conclusion and stay away, Mrs Clinton's chances will be damaged.

"There is a real lack of urgency at the top of the ticket," said one of her advisers. "Too many people see this as a risk-free election." Both candidates, whether talking to students or to commuters at railway stations, have been pressing supporters to remember to vote.

President Bill Clinton, who has made several appearances backing his wife and will spend more time in New York than anywhere else before polling day, told a meeting at a church in Harlem: "You've all got your minds made up: you're going to vote. So we are having this event for people who aren't here. Make sure anyone you can find is there next week."

The latest of the oscillating polls shows Mrs Clinton leading 47-44, down from 50-43 the previous month. But those who are undecided went up to 9% from 6%.

"It still looks like Hillary v Hillary," said Maurice Carroll, director of the Quinnipiac University Polling Institute, acknowledging that the vote is fundamentally a referendum on the Democratic candidate.

"Lazio's vote has barely changed. The movement was away from Mrs Clinton to undecided," Mr Carroll said. "The good news for Lazio is that Clinton is losing ground. The bad news for Lazio is that he's barely gaining. The bad news for Clinton is that she's dropped below that magic 50% mark. The good news is that she's on the up side of a real squeaker."

The previous day's polls pointed in opposite directions. One, conducted for the New York Times/CBS News, showed Mrs Clinton ahead by eight points; the other, by the Zogby polling organisation, gave Mr Lazio 47.8% and Mrs Clinton 42.9%. "Basically, what you have here is a very close race, too close to call," said John Zogby. "When all is said and done, it's probably a one-point race."

fields.headline: Israeli troops 'shot dead'
fields.standfirst:
Major gun battle on outskirts of Bethlehem sparks fears of escalation as rights group urges restraint

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Two Israeli soldiers were reported to have been killed yesterday in a gun battle which looks certain to trigger a further escalation in the Middle East's unrelenting cycle of violence and reprisal. Two Palestinians, including a policeman, died in the fighting which raged for several hours in al-Khader, a Palestinian village on the outskirts of Bethlehem.
fields.body:
Two Israeli soldiers were reported to have been killed yesterday in a gun battle which looks certain to trigger a further escalation in the Middle East's unrelenting cycle of violence and reprisal. Two Palestinians, including a policeman, died in the fighting which raged for several hours in al-Khader, a Palestinian village on the outskirts of Bethlehem.

Villagers took cover behind walls as heavy fire from all directions hit the main street. At least 12 Palestinians and four Israeli soldiers were wounded. Two Israeli helicopters fired machine guns as they evacuated the army casualties, who had been trapped for almost an hour.

Last night, an Israeli army spokesman declined to comment on the incident, or to confirm the soldiers' deaths. Correspondents at the scene, however, said they had seen the bodies.

The prime minister, Ehud Barak, called a special meeting of his security cabinet to discuss what his aide, Danny Yatom, described as "a very negative jump in the scope and severity of events".

Earlier in the same area, say Israeli police, Palestinian gunmen fired on the Jewish settlement of Gilo and Israeli troops responded by firing at the adjacent Palestinian district of Beit Jala.

Gilo, occupied by Israel in 1967 and annexed to Jerusalem, has been a regular trouble spot since the violence erupted five weeks ago.

In Gaza, where tens of thousands of mourners attended funerals of four Palestinians killed on Tuesday, two Palestinians, aged 15 and 17, were shot dead yesterday during stone-throwing clashes with soldiers at the Karni crossing on the Israel-Gaza border.

During the funeral processions there were shouts of "revenge" and calls for a "day of heightened escalation" on Friday.

Meanwhile, Israel's elder statesman, Shimon Peres, said he would shortly hold talks with the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat - the first high-level meeting between the two sides for six weeks.

Mr Peres, who was jointly awarded the Nobel Peace Prize with Mr Arafat for earlier peace efforts, is believed to have a better relationship with Mr Arafat than Mr Barak has.

But although Mr Peres said he would be seeking Mr Afarat's commitment to last month's Sharm al-Sheikh truce agreement, his expectations were not high. "I just think that, even when there is shooting, we need to talk," he told Israeli army radio.

Mr Arafat yesterday met the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, in Gaza city, and called for greater European involvement in peace talks.

"We are looking for a German stance, a European stance to push the peace process forward, to protect the peace process," he said.

The Palestinian negotiator Saeb Erekat is due in the US today for meetings with the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, and the US secretary of state Madeleine Albright. His visit follows a trip to Washington by Israel's acting foreign minister, Shlomo Ben-Ami.

Mr Erekat said he would urge Mr Annan "to provide immediate international protection for our people and to promptly set up an international inquiry into the massacres committed against the Palestinians by Israel".

He said he would ask the US to intervene to lift what he described as Israel's siege and to press Israel to ease tension by withdrawing troops from the entrances of Palestinian cities.

Israel's Likud leader, Ariel Sharon, said yesterday that he did not believe that the peace process was dead, but "I don't believe we can reach a permanent agreement".

He said that the issues of Jerusalem, security in the Jordan river area, and the right of return claimed by Palestinians made a permanent settlement impossible. Instead, he suggested, "I recommend a long-term interim agreement with no timetable".

In a sign of growing Jewish distrust of Israel's Arab citizens, the Israeli army said yesterday that it plans to erect electrified fences around some villages to protect them from "hostile" neighbours. Weapons storage rooms and firing posts would also be provided.

The army has drawn up a list of villages to be fortified, which all lie within Israel's 1967 boundaries. Those selected are in Galilee or close to the occupied West Bank, and are near to Arab villages or in isolated areas where they could potentially be cut off.

The plan still needs to be approved by a ministerial committee.

Arab citizens, who make up about 18% of Israel's 6m population, have largely stayed out of the recent violence - though 13 of them have been killed since the intifada began.

Simultaneously, the Damascus-based Fatah Uprising group, which broke away from Yasser Arafat's mainstream Fatah movement in 1983, announced that a group called the "Omar al-Mukhtar Forces" would be carrying out attacks within Israel as part of the militant arm of Fatah Uprising.

It said the aim would be "to strengthen our struggle inside our occupied land and meet all the needs of resistance and secure its continuity and momentum".

Although Omar al-Mukhtar Forces has existed for about two years and has claimed several attacks inside Israel, its connection with Fatah Uprising had not previously been known.

fields.headline: Hurricanes and hot air
fields.trailText:
Tristan Clayton's letter defining hurricanes (November 1) is incorrect. Hurricane has two senses in meteorology: first the type of revolving storm he refers to; and secondly a wind of force 12 on the Beaufort scale, which was originally described as "that which no canvas can withstand". The reference to a hurricane in 1987 refers to the latter. A strong gale is only force nine on the Beaufort scale, which was most certainly exceeded in 1987.
JK Jackson
Hatch End, Middx
fields.body:
Tristan Clayton's letter defining hurricanes (November 1) is incorrect. Hurricane has two senses in meteorology: first the type of revolving storm he refers to; and secondly a wind of force 12 on the Beaufort scale, which was originally described as "that which no canvas can withstand". The reference to a hurricane in 1987 refers to the latter. A strong gale is only force nine on the Beaufort scale, which was most certainly exceeded in 1987.
JK Jackson
Hatch End, Middx

 I'm glad to see the campaign for easily visualised measurements has moved on to include units of weight and volume, but the latest announcement is rather lacking in precision. If a roomful of air weighs as much as a pile of bricks (Tornadoes put experts in spin, October 31), how many of these piles of bricks would it take to cover an area the size of Wales?
Colin Campbell
Basingstoke, Hants

 Good grief. The two most dangerous men in the world are combining forces and you put the story in the financial pages. No, not Saddam and Gadafy - Gates and Murdoch (Gates to buy $1bn Sky stake, October 31). It's got to be the end of civilisation, wouldn't you say?
Sean Maffett
Bourton-on-the-Water, Glos

 Re Pat Parkin-Moore's letter (November 1): I am no expert on men's dangly bits, but I would be surprised if many filled a double D-cup!
Ricky Gilby
Hull

 Your article (DTI raids tobacco giant, October 31) says that the issue was disclosed in the Guardian "last January". I seem to recall that this disclosure was in January 2000. Does this mean that January 2001 is "this" January and "next" will imply 2002?
F Garrity
Glasgow

fields.headline: Sold out
fields.trailText:
Whilst shopping in our local "shopping mall", I partook of refreshments in the "food court", which was amply decorated with banners wishing me a "happy halloween". When asked for directions to the toilets, I was directed by a "team member" to a door emblazoned with a sign reading "wash rooms". To those who say that the UK is the 51st state of America, I say, "Get in line, Buddy!"
Stephen Lane
Clonee, Co Meath
Stephen.Lane@newireland.ie

fields.headline: Rock's off
fields.body:
Caroline Sullivan's assumption that "after years of domination by dance music, rock is making a comeback" (Rock fizz, November 1) is way wide of the mark. According to the last round of ABC figures, the two main dance music monthlies (of which Ministry is one) posted combined increases of over 30%, and now rank second and third behind Q as best-selling titles in the music sector; Q suffered a 4.1% loss. Fellow "rock" titles such as Select, NME and Melody Maker suffered even worse. With more evening and weekend dance music radio shows being scheduled, and the US at last embracing dance culture in the way Europe has over the past decade, dance music's sphere of influence can only widen.
Stephen Worthy
Ministry magazine
sworthy@ministryofsound.com

fields.headline: Dumb and dumber
fields.trailText:
Peter Ford (Letters, November 1) is correct to point out that William Caxton was not the "father of printing". But neither was Gutenberg. Johannes Gutenberg, if he existed at all, may have been the first man in Europe to print from moveable type, but the Chinese were printing from woodblocks at least 1,000 years before. Actually, the Koreans have a good claim to have invented moveable type (from cast bronze) by 1377, when a Buddhist devotional text was printed at the Hungdoksa monastery near Cheong ju, at least 23 years before Gutenberg was born. Oh, and Caxton wasn't English, he was Flemish.
Dr Iain Stevenson
City University
W.I.Stevenson@city.ac.uk

 Joan Smith celebrates the fact that we are now all atheists (Comment, October 30) by quoting Shelley's proud entry in a register in 1816 in Greek proclaiming himself an atheist. This event has been recorded, among others, by both Richard Holmes in his The Pursuit and in Miranda Seymour's recent biography of Mary Shelley. Though they disagree about the nature of the book Shelley signed - variously recorded as a hotel register and a visitor's book - they both agree that it was in fact Byron who crossed out the signatures, not Southey. Southey was only responsible for spreading the scandal of this event around London (the Lakeland poets used to call him "Mouthey Southey"). Furthermore, the event took place not in Locarno but in Chamonix.
Karen Anthony
Bury, Lancs
