fields.headline: Charges dropped in secrecy case
fields.standfirst:
Colonel accused of supplying information to author hits out

Special report: freedom of information
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Britain's increasingly derided secrecy laws were dealt a huge blow yesterday when prosecutors dropped charges against a retired army officer who had been accused of passing information to a journalist about surveillance operations in Northern Ireland.
fields.body:
Britain's increasingly derided secrecy laws were dealt a huge blow yesterday when prosecutors dropped charges against a retired army officer who had been accused of passing information to a journalist about surveillance operations in Northern Ireland.

The humiliating decision was made days after the Ministry of Defence insisted that key evidence in its case against Lieutenant Colonel Nigel Wylde should be heard behind closed doors - a move the Guardian planned to challenge in the courts next week .

Lt Col Wylde was charged under the Official Secrets Act last year with providing information to Tony Geraghty for his book, The Irish War, which describes the growing use of computers by military intelligence in identifying targets. The systems "provide total cover of a largely innocent population", the book says.

Evidence the MoD wanted to be heard behind closed doors included everything relating to "damage assessments". Initial MoD assessments concluded that the book did not endanger any operations, an admission which suggested that the disclosures were merely embarassing.

Yesterday, the crown prosecution service told Lt Col Wylde's lawyer and director of the human rights group Liberty, John Wadham, that it intended to offer no evidence in the case. The reasons, said Sue Taylor, CPS London division head, was a report by an expert for the defence, the freelance journalist Duncan Campbell.

"Having received the advice [of counsel] and reviewed the case, we decided there was insufficient evidence for a realistic prospect of conviction," a CPS spokeswoman said.

Mr Campbell showed that all the material Lt Col Wylde was accused of passing to Mr Geraghty was already in the public domain. Some had been contained in a briefcase which was mislaid by an intelligence officer in 1998 and was subsequently published in the Sinn Fein weekly, Republican News.

The CPS said it had told Lord Williams, the attorney general, about its decision as a "matter of courtesy". However, the Guardian understands that Lord Williams had taken a close interest in the case.

Weeks ago, Lt Col Wylde and his defence team warned that the case had striking parallels with the 1977 ABC secrets trial, in which Mr Campbell was a defendant and which proved politically embarrassing to the then Labour administration.

Lt Col Wylde, 53, holder of the Queen's Gallantry Medal for defusing unexploded bombs in Northern Ireland and now a computer consultant, said last night that thousands of pounds of taxpayers' money had been wasted on the case. "This decision is a victory for freedom of speech." he said.

Mr Wadham added: "This case is another nail in the coffin of the Official Secrets Act. The act is flawed and needs to be reformed. When Labour was in opposition it opposed the act in principle, and many current ministers voted against it, yet the attorney general seemed happy to use it against my client."

Lt Col Wylde and Mr Geraghty were arrested in December 1998, two months after The Irish War was published. The MoD made no attempt to stop the book. Charges against Mr Geraghty were dropped by Lord Williams last December.

The MoD claimed that Lt Col Wylde had handed Mr Geraghty five documents, a claim they denied. Evidence that this was not so was the fact that Mr Geraghty had taken shorthand notes of the information.

Mr Geraghty described how" in Northern Ireland...at least 1m names are now on some security agency's computer". Two other computer systems provided "total cover of a largely innocent population".

Another high profile secrets case, the prosecution of the former MI5 officer David Shayler, is still scheduled to go ahead. The CPS wants all, or part of, the trial to be heard in secret. The move wil be challenged by the Guardian on November 9.

fields.headline: Highlands
fields.trailText: Next year, through the Highland Biological Recording Group, I hope to coordinate a survey of freshwater fish. The idea came about after a telephone call from neighbours a mile up the strath. There's a burn running past their house, and they watched a heron catching what they thought were eels, and then the following day a curlew was at the same spot, again looking as if it was catching eels. Something didn't seem quite right, and when the neighbour went to look, there in the shallows were brook lampreys.
fields.body:
Next year, through the Highland Biological Recording Group, I hope to coordinate a survey of freshwater fish. The idea came about after a telephone call from neighbours a mile up the strath. There's a burn running past their house, and they watched a heron catching what they thought were eels, and then the following day a curlew was at the same spot, again looking as if it was catching eels. Something didn't seem quite right, and when the neighbour went to look, there in the shallows were brook lampreys.

For me the interest was that the burn is part of the River Nairn watershed, which means that brook lampreys must be in the river a field from our house. Despite having caught salmon, brown trout and eels in the river, I had no idea that lampreys could be there.

One of the problems with a freshwater fish survey is that, as with other groups, there's has been a lot of translocation with some species, while in other instances a few, such as pike, perch and minnows, that aren't native to the Highlands, have been accidentally or deliberately introduced. I'd assumed that these introductions were of recent origin, and was taken aback when, by chance, I found out this wasn't the case. I'd been looking at the numbers of feral goats kept in parishes in the 18th century by referring to the First Statistical Account written in 1791 to 1799: pike were already in a number of lochs in these parishes. As for the perch and minnows, these have come from anglers using them as live bait to catch large ferox trout or even pike; any bait left over would just be dumped in the loch.

webTitle: Time at last for whole truth to be told

fields.headline: Time at last for whole truth to be told
fields.trailText: Now this business has finally gone too far. It started with accusations against Pakistanis; then it was extended to other assorted foreigners; now, for the first time, an England player has been directly implicated. The noise you heard yesterday was the sound of indignation roaring out of the shires.
fields.body:
Now this business has finally gone too far. It started with accusations against Pakistanis; then it was extended to other assorted foreigners; now, for the first time, an England player has been directly implicated. The noise you heard yesterday was the sound of indignation roaring out of the shires.

The allegation against Alec Stewart was in fact a very minor detail in the Indian police report. But in Britain parochial interest has obscured the truly sensational suggestions: that Mohammad Azharuddin has actually admitted being corrupt, and that Brian Lara now stands accused.

Match-fixing is a crime especially associated with the incessant, contrived and context-free one-day international tournaments that fill every spare space in the cricketing schedule to provide cheap TV programmes. Azharuddin has played more of these than anybody else. If he falls, it is the damnation of an era, not just a person.

Still, there is something peculiarly shocking about the naming of Stewart. In an unheroic era for English cricket, he has been a staunch and soldierly symbol of defiance. Though his name has been whispered for some time, it is still a bit like reading a headline saying Pope In Sex Shocker. Not him too, surely?

Well, I hope not. I have met hundreds of professional cricketers and can only think of three who have written a thank you letter for some small service rendered. Alec was one of them. The Stewarts are a fine, close-knit family who have stood for many of whatever virtues remain in English cricket.

Even if the allegation is true, then in itself it amounts to nothing criminal. This was 1993, when a fixer in India was simply a bloke who might know how to buy a bottle of whisky or a train ticket. If a bookmaker asked for information, so what? It would have seemed no different than putting one's name on top of a bit of ghost-written garbage in a newspaper - money for old rope, but hardly reprehensible. Alec would have had an extra reason not to be suspicious: though his father was also an England cricketer, his grandpa was a bookie.

It was 1998 before anyone began to realise that Indian bookmakers were engaged in entrapment. Giving harmless information to them was the first dip of the toes into a murky river swirling towards destruction. Soon, they start to make other, more dangerous, requests. And there are no thank you letters.

Stewart has denied everything, point-blank, and so far there is no corroboration. This makes things simpler. You cannot rely on solitary denunciations. Whatever Lord MacLaurin might have said about people being guilty until proved innocent, it is obviously right that Stewart should continue playing - unless and until there is serious evidence against him.

If he is lying, it is a different matter. Something that is hardly even a misdemeanour then becomes wholly felonious. After years of cover-ups at every level, it is crucial that cricketers and cricket at last tell the whole truth.

fields.headline: Silly money
fields.standfirst:
The government appears to be beating a retreat from its promises to end the scandal of excess boardroom pay. It should think again.
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The government has got itself in a tangle over boardroom fat cats - just as the Tories did in the early 90s.
fields.body:
The government has got itself in a tangle over boardroom fat cats - just as the Tories did in the early 90s.

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, has been beating a steady retreat all year from his threat to stop the scandal of soaring boardroom pay. Now the DTI says there will be no action this side of the election and when legislation does emerge it will be a long short of the tough measures promised as recently as this spring.

Mr Byers appears to have been caught in the Blair/Brown crossfire, with the prime minister winning this battle in the interests of preserving what is left of the government's business-friendly image. This is actually a mistaken concern. Most business people are embarrassed, if not horrified, at being associated with the headline-making pay deals, which do not reflect life outside the elite.

But the problem of excessive pay for top directors will not go away. It haunted John Major and has defied all attempts at voluntary regulation.

The facts speak loudly. The remuneration of plc directors has risen well above that of any other group for more than a decade. It has been out of line with any relevant indicator, whether that is company profits, share prices, average earnings, or even the pay of managers in the economy as a whole.

These rises, mainly in bigger companies, are driven by the "incentive" schemes supposed to align the interests of directors with those of their shareholders. It is not just about share options or one-off handouts to people such as Chris Gent, boss of Vodafone, who received £10m for winning the takeover battle with Mannesman.

Basic pay in these boardrooms has repeatedly risen by more than the increases they have handed out to their staff. Recent research from the pay specialists Incomes Data Services found that chief executives of the top 100 public companies received a 10% increase in basic pay last year. That is before bonuses and share packages which also add a much higher multiple of basic pay than for the rest of the workforce. Cash rises over the past year are shown in the graphic. It is the same year after year.

Ironically, previous attempts to curb excessive pay are partly responsible. The Cadbury committee, whose remit was more about board structure than how much directors were paid, began a process of formalising directors' pay bargaining. Its 1992 report called for boards to set up remuneration committees consisting mainly of non-executive directors, to stop chief executives awarding themselves huge rises.

The rises continued, however, culminating in the embarrassing public row over the pay awarded to Cedric Brown by the newly-privatised British Gas board.

The next attempt to deal with boardroom excess was under the former Marks & Spencer chair, Sir Richard Greenbury. He pushed an egalitarian argument that directors should broadly get the same rises as they gave to their staff, but this was too much for the CBI, the City institutions and the Institute of Directors. The Greenbury committee wanted to tilt the balance towards performance-related payments by introducing schemes based on long-term targets instead of free share options.

As it has turned out, new schemes have been piled on top of old ones, and performance-related pay has risen as a proportion of the total earnings - but increasing the total, not reducing the guaranteed basic.

The Cadbury and Green bury codes are enshrined in the stock exchange requirements for public companies. But despite this decade of semi-official attempts to deal with the fat cat issue, it continues to provoke controversy and embarrassment for government.

There are two reasons. First, remuneration committees have become a cosy club of non-executives sitting on each others' boards and handing out similar pay deals. Their failure suggests a need to take pay out of the hands of directors and give shareholders the power.

Greenbury wondered whether the reports of remuneration committees should be voted on separately by shareholders at the annual meeting. It decided against giving shareholders this power, arguing that if they were upset they could vote against the relevant directors' re-election. This is the issue which Mr Byers has been struggling with. His first instinct was to require a vote at the annual meeting on the pay of individual directors. But now it seems the Blairite fear of antagonising business will permit only minimal improvements.

It is likely to be made easier for shareholders to get a resolution on pay on the agenda at the annual meeting. But investors will have to wait for this to be included in a company law bill, which is unlikely to be enacted until at least 2002.

The City has, it is true, started to act without new law. But it is a delusion to expect the City - where multi-million pound bonuses are de rigeur - to police boardroom pay in this piecemeal fashion.

A systematic approach is needed to deal with routine excess. The government could of course threaten to tax fat cats until the pips squeak (unlikely, to say the least). Short of that, boards need to know they will have to justify pay packets in public. That means forcing companies to put pay policies to the vote. If they want to pay people like Chris Gent outside the approved policy, they would have to seek permission from shareholders.

Roger Cowe writes on business and society rogercowe@netscapeonline.co.uk

The next attempt to deal with boardroom excess was under the former Marks & Spencer chair, Sir Richard Greenbury. He pushed an egalitarian argument that directors should broadly get the same rises as they gave to their staff, but this was too much for the CBI, the City institutions and the Institute of Directors. The Greenbury committee wanted to tilt the balance towards performance-related payments by introducing schemes based on long-term targets instead of free share options. As it has turned out, new schemes have been piled on top of old ones, and performance-related pay has risen as a proportion of the total earnings - but increasing the total, not reducing the guaranteed basic. The Cadbury and Green bury codes are enshrined in the stock exchange requirements for public companies. But despite this decade of semi-official attempts to deal with the fat cat issue, it continues to provoke controversy and embarrassment for government. There are two reasons. First, remuneration committees have become a cosy club of non-executives sitting on each others' boards and handing out similar pay deals. Their failure suggests a need to take pay out of the hands of directors and give shareholders the power. Greenbury wondered whether the reports of remuneration committees should be voted on separately by shareholders at the annual meeting. It decided against giving shareholders this power, arguing that if they were upset they could vote against the relevant directors' re-election. This is the issue which Mr Byers has been struggling with. His first instinct was to require a vote at the annual meeting on the pay of individual directors. But now it seems the Blairite fear of antagonising business will permit only minimal improvements. It is likely to be made easier for shareholders to get a resolution on pay on the agenda at the annual meeting. But investors will have to wait for this to be included in a company law bill, which is unlikely to be enacted until at least 2002. The City has, it is true, started to act without new law. But it is a delusion to expect the City - where multi-million pound bonuses are de rigeur - to police boardroom pay in this piecemeal fashion. A systematic approach is needed to deal with routine excess. The government could of course threaten to tax fat cats until the pips squeak (unlikely, to say the least). Short of that, boards need to know they will have to justify pay packets in public. That means forcing companies to put pay policies to the vote. If they want to pay people like Chris Gent outside the approved policy, they would have to seek permission from shareholders. Roger Cowe writes on business and society rogercowe@netscapeonline.co.uk

webTitle: Which hot new film will be the biggest British hit by the end of 2001?

fields.headline: The price is right
fields.standfirst: Which hot new film will be the biggest British hit by the end of 2001?
fields.trailText: Which hot new film will be the biggest British hit by the end of 2001?
fields.body:
Edges Of The Lord Evens

Slap Her, She's French 2-1

Revolution Now 2-1

Diary Of A Sex Addict 3-1

At the so-called London Screenings, buyers and sellers have been gathering to strike film deals for the coming year. At this stage there is very rarely a finished product, and buyers must predict what's likely to succeed based upon a show reel or a script. Which films are causing the biggest buzz?

Fox Searchlight has bought Slap Her, She's French, which begins production next month. It's a comedy about a French foreign-exchange student who comes to a small Texas high school, befriends a classmate and practically takes over her life; Piper Perabo is due to star.

"It sounds as if it has a tongue-in-cheek humour that's very popular at the moment," notes Andy Clifton, Ladbrokes' entertainment odds compiler, adding that it must get good odds because of the distribution clout of Fox.

Miramax has picked up Edges Of The Lord, written and directed by Yurek Bogayevicz. It centres on a young Jewish boy (Haley Joel Osment) who is sent by his parents to live with a Catholic priest (Willem Dafoe) during WWII.

"At the moment there are quite a few successful films where child actors are playing serious roles," Andy points out. "It also helps that Osment can really act."

Columbia TriStar's Diary Of A Sex Addict, starring Rosanna Arquette and Nastassja Kinski, tells the story of a restaurateur whose addiction to sex causes his life to spiral out of control. "Nastassja Kinski will certainly attract the thirtysomething males", says Andy.

The comedy Revolution Now, about a delusional man determined to bring down what he believes to be a corrupt government, "has a theme that's been done to death in the last few years," notes Andy. "Although David Arquette, Mira Sorvino and Anna Paquin are in early talks to star, it might need more than that to stand out from the pack."

webTitle: Last night's TV: Heaven can wait

fields.headline: Heaven can wait
fields.trailText: Josie's Journey | Back To The Floor | Rick Stein's Seafood Lovers' Guide
fields.body:
It was a moment when the air was filled with hats and hurrahs. (The decline of the hat has deprived us of several ways of expressing delight and distaste.)

In Josie's Journey (BBC1) Shaun Russell was coaxing his daughter Josie to attend a garden party in a good cause. He is a man for whom the word noble seems made-to-measure. She is the sole survivor of a murderous attack on her mother and sister. Their headstone is plain Welsh slate. Old roses scattered unregimented petals on the grave. Shaun said "I chose a simple gravestone, not a fancy one at all. I didn't put much on it either." It simply records the names of Lin, Megan and Lucy, the dog killed with them. "It was beyond me to think of anything more to say."

Camera and sound backed off as he wept... I sometimes think that a suitable sort of epitaph for a media celebrity would be Fade Sound And Vision, a phrase you see on a shooting script. Josie and Shaun have become, willy-nilly, media celebrities.

Which is why they were invited to the garden party. He said "Josie, listen! They were very good to my dad when he was depressed, before he committed suicide. So your gran thinks it would be nice to do something back for them." This was laying it on a bit thick, like the caption in Charlie Chaplin's autobiography: "This is where we lived next to the abattoir before mother went into the asylum."

Chaplin exploded into comedy and so, now, did Josie. She said "Six hours in a car. I'm not going. It's going to be so boring ."

Shaun Russell wore that be-nice-to-me look which would have been irresistible to an older woman. "Just think how much my mum has done for me." "You go then," said Josie. "I'm not going." ("Parents are difficult..." she added in a throwaway line to a friend.)

It's Shaun's triumph that he's raised a perfectly normal adolescent who shouts "Yee-ha!" when he is nervously balanced on a pony and who thinks parents are difficult.

We all loved an open-air Dallas wedding. Shaky vows exchanged under the shaky pergola. The bijou pool into which Clive Barnes invariably knocked JR. Astonishingly, it turned out in Back To The Floor (BBC2), there really are weddings like this. Many, in the Sandals resort on Antigua. The holiday company's MD Steve Garley went undercover to inspect their wedding operation.

Sandals Antigua specialises in package weddings. As Andy and Sharon, a newly arrived pallid pair said, "It's a bit like Butlins with palms" (Andy) and, "It's a conveyor belt" (Sharon). Steve, a believer in the personal touch, made their day by laying on their favourite drink, chilled Guinness.

As a trainee, it was his job to sell couples at least £350 of those little extras which mean so much. Here he is, failing to interest Martin and Suzanne in a bedroom treat called an escapade: "There are candles, petals all over the floor of the room and balloons. It's really romantic and the price is about $100."

The balloons got me. Were you supposed to burst them? And at what point?

Steve's failure to flog the escapade got a crisp response from wedding coordinator Ezra. "Steve, have you any idea what we're supposed to be doing here?" Less a question than an exclamation. "What I'd do, I'd get them apart from each other. You have to seem like their best friend, and you want what's best for them. So you say to Martin..." (her voice took on the tone of a dove asking another dove for the loan of a fiver till Friday) "...Martin, have you thought of sending Suzanne some flowers?"

Steve gave it a go. "Martin, don't you think you ought to give Suzanne something for her special day in her room?" (Such improper overtones that it seemed the ideal moment for Martin to knock Steve into the bijou pool.) "What do you think about a dozen roses?" Martin thought he'd think about it. Steve held no grudge against the man. "Twelve roses for 80 quid! Who's going to buy that? Why don't they sell local tropical flowers?"

At last he wrenched off his whiskers and stood magnificently revealed as managing director of The Rest Of The World. Moral of the series is that nowadays nobody knows what the boss looks like.

"The only acceptable British picnic is whelks with vinegar and pepper, in the car, parked on a seafront somewhere with headscarves on and the windows rolled down." Jeremy Round, as quoted by Rick Stein in Rick Stein's Seafood Lovers' Guide (BBC 2).

webTitle: Britain in grip of worst floods for 50 years

fields.headline: Britain in grip of worst floods for 50 years
fields.standfirst:
Under water: Widespread dismay as floods on a par with those of 1947

Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: A large part of Britain remained in the grip of the most widespread floods in 50 years as forecasters last night warned of more misery to come.
fields.byline: Jeevan Vasagar, Helen Carter, Emma Brockes, Geoff Gibbs, Martin Wainwright
fields.body:
A large part of Britain remained in the grip of the most widespread floods in 50 years as forecasters last night warned of more misery to come.

The number of severe flood warnings fell yesterday to 14, but the environment agency said that for many people things would get worse.

Sir John Harman, chairman of the agency, said: "On the Severn, and possibly in Yorkshire, flooding will get much worse. We are already dealing with floods which are probably the most widespread since the great floods of 1947, and, in some places, as severe. Countless people and business have been affected. The misery is set to continue."

The Met Office has forecast prolonged and heavy showers for the remainder of the week. Up to an inch of rain was predicted for the already waterlogged south east of England last night. More heavy rain will hit Wales and the north today.

The Midlands was worst hit yesterday as the Severn flowed at 10 times normal levels. Hundreds fled homes and businesses across the region.

Shrewsbury was cut off by road and 200 householders were evacuated, some by boat. In Bewdley, Worcestershire, and in towns further downstream, the Severn was not expected to hit peak levels until later this week.

In Yorkshire, high water levels threatened the Archbishop of York's official residence, Bishopthorpe Palace. A flotilla of small boats evacuated 37 pensioners from the City Mills elderly people's flats in York, while amphibious Army vehicles took children to school at Fulford.

John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, yesterday bemoaned the crumpling of Britain's infrastructure - the road closures, power cuts, and rail cancellations in the face of extreme weather. He insisted that the nation must be better prepared in future. He has already called for meetings with local authorities, the environment agency and emergency services next month, to consider practical proposals such as expanding Victorian-era storm drains and burying power lines underground.

"We all want to see our country better placed to deal with extreme weather events, which we can now expect to be more frequent," he said.

Meanwhile, police searching for a man who was swept away by a river on Monday said they believed that he would not be found alive. Ian Tompkins, 28, plunged into a tributary of the River Nene in Northamptonshire to rescue his partner and their two dogs. If his body is found, it will bring the number of people killed to eight.

On Bardsey island, off north Wales, a group of holidaymakers was hoping to be rescued quickly, after rough seas imprisoned them for five days. The nine adults and eight children arrived on the island 12 days ago for a half-term break. After several failed efforts to dock a rescue boat this week, coastguards feared that the group's food rations would be running low and prepared to mount an airlift from Anglesey. A break in the weather would make sea rescue more likely.

On most rail routes, the trains were running yesterday, Railtrack said. But many services were restricted to emergency timetables in place since the Hatfield train crash. Some services have been cancelled or delayed due to flooding and track damage.

The AA said motorists faced numerous delays, although most main roads were operating normally. In north Yorkshire, the A19, A169 and A59 were closed and some Midlands roads flooded. The A617 between Kelham and the Newark bypass was closed and other B roads were affected. The A56 at Colne and the A59 between Chatburn and Gisburn, Lancashire, also flooded.

Insurers advised home-owners living in flood-risk areas that they could find their premiums being significantly increased next year.

fields.headline: 5 days to go
fields.standfirst:
On the stump yesterday

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: George W Bush
fields.body:
George W Bush

A "Victory 2000" rally in Duluth, Minnesota, followed by another in Des Moines, Iowa, claiming he would "upset conventional wisdom" and sweep the traditionally Democratic west coast states of California, Oregon and Washington

Al Gore

On the offensive in Bush's vulnerable underbelly, Florida, talking social security at a civic centre in Tampa, before moving on to the next largest swing state, Pennsylvania, where he was due to attend a rally with a country singer, Jimmy Buffet. He was countered by the Bush campaign with General Norman Schwarzkopf

Football news

The result of the National Football League Washington Redskins' final home game before a presidential election has accurately predicted the electoral outcome for the past 15 contests. History has proven that if the Redskins win, the incumbent will stay in the White House; if the Redskins lose, the opposition party gains control in Washington. The Tennessee Titans visited Washington this week, and won 27-21.

Bad news for Gore.

webTitle: Bribery claims put game on trial

fields.headline: Bribery claims put game on trial
fields.standfirst: Indian report links some of world's greatest players with bookmakers
fields.trailText: Vivek Chaudhary on the Indian report that links some of world's greatest players with bookmakers.
fields.body:
When R.N. Savani, joint director of India's Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI), the country's federal police, marched across the well-manicured lawns of the Indian parliament building earlier this week the posse of journalists that chased him had only a slight whiff of the explosive nature of the document he held in his hand.

Fending off questions, the official darted into a corridor and scurried up a stairway, marching purposefully into the office of the Indian sports minister, Sukhdev Singh Dhindsa, handing him a 162-page document.

There was little time to fully digest it because the prime minster, Atal Bihari Vajpayee, had demanded to see it as soon as it arrived. It did not take long for the two men to realise that they would not be able to keep the report a secret. Given the importance of cricket to their people, they reasoned, the people had a right to know.

For the first time, a leading cricketer had admitted match-fixing; bookmakers gave details of matches they paid to have fixed and how much they paid players. Nine former Test captains from outside India were named, as were five Indian players, including Mohammad Azharuddin, one of the country's most celebrated batsmen and former captain.

Azharuddin, a hero to millions of Indians, confessed in the report to attempting to throw three matches and to receiving money from a bookmaker.

Reeling

The report conceded that while India may be the epicentre of illegal betting and match-fixing in cricket, the problem is a global one for the game. In neighbouring Pakistan, where the England team is touring, English cricket officials were left reeling by the report, following claims that the former captain, Alec Stewart, had been paid £5,000 to supply information to a bookmaker in 1993.

Rumours that English players had been involved in match-fixing had been circulating within cricket for several years but none had ever been named and nobody had ever pointed the finger of accusation so publicly at any English player.

Even the world's most famous cricketer, the West Indian batsman Brian Lara was implicated, with one bookmaker alleging that he paid him $40,000 (£26,500) for playing badly in two one-day internationals in India in 1994.

Even before the report was made fully public yesterday, its contents had started to leak out and the denials were already being issued throughout the cricketing world. From Colombo to the Caribbean, the former great names of the sport expressed their shock and indignation at being implicated by Indian bookmakers.

"I'm shattered that my name is mentioned," said the former New Zealand batsman Martin Crowe who, claimed one Indian bookmaker, took $20,000 (£13,250). "I've never had any contact with these dudes (the bookmakers). It certainly never came into direct contact with the New Zealand cricket team at the time, but we did hear whispers of things from the sub-continent."

The former Sri Lankan captain, Arjuna Ranatunga, and his deputy, Aravinda de Silva, also denied any match-fixing. "Both players are now seeking legal advice," said a Sri Lankan cricket board offiical.

The CBI report into match-fixing started in May, after Indian police officers inadvertently uncovered match-fixing as they monitored the activities of two Indian businesmen, Rajesh Kalra and Sanjiv Chawla. During the surveillance operation, they recorded conversations between the men and the former South African captain, Hansie Cronje, where payments were discussed and how certain matches had to be lost during a tour to India.

Cronje, who was considered one of the most honest players in the sport, was stripped of his captaincy and is under investigation by South African authorities after confessing to receiving money.

Cronje's involvement, however surprising, fitted a wider pattern of players being named in match-fixing over the past few years. A number of Pakistani players had already been named before to the CBI report, while Australian players Shane Warne and Mark Waugh confessed to supplying information to a bookmaker in 1994. The pair were fined by Australian cricket authorities but not banned.

The Cronje scandal prompted Indian authorities into taking action and it is largely through their efforts that the lid on match-fixing has been lifted.

In a cricket-obsessed country like India millions of pounds are regularly bet on cricket matches. The bets are taken by businessmen working as illegal bookmakers who will also take wagers on how many wickets a team may lose, the number of runs a particular player may score or wickets he might take.

As the CBI report concedes: "Betting on cricket matches in India has attained a measure of sophistication and it has spread across the length and breadth of the country. The use of computer and mobile phones has given a major fillip to the racket."

While some of the players named in the CBI report have been accused of being paid to play badly, others like Stewart stand accused of supplying information. For bookmakers, gaining information on which team has won the toss or pitch conditions will affect the odds they set and this can make a difference between winning or losing large amounts of money.

The CBI based its report on the testimony of 16 Indian bookmakers who all confessed to being involved in match-fixing. One of the main names to emerge in connection with the players is Mukesh Gupta, a Delhi-based businessman and part-time bookmaker, who claimed that he paid hundreds of thousands of pounds to players in return for playing badly or supplying information.

Indian officials have conceded that there is not enough evidence in the report to bring criminal charges. It will now be sent to the world's cricket authorities, who will be responsible for taking action against any of the players named.

Final word should rest with the CBI report, which concludes: "Major corrective steps need to be taken to put cricket back on the rails."

From Colombo to the Caribbean, the former great names of the sport expressed their shock and indignation at being implicated by Indian bookmakers. "I'm shattered that my name is mentioned," said the former New Zealand batsman Martin Crowe who, claimed one Indian bookmaker, took $20,000 (£13,250). "I've never had any contact with these dudes (the bookmakers). It certainly never came into direct contact with the New Zealand cricket team at the time, but we did hear whispers of things from the sub-continent." The former Sri Lankan captain, Arjuna Ranatunga, and his deputy, Aravinda de Silva, also denied any match-fixing. "Both players are now seeking legal advice," said a Sri Lankan cricket board offiical. The CBI report into match-fixing started in May, after Indian police officers inadvertently uncovered match-fixing as they monitored the activities of two Indian businesmen, Rajesh Kalra and Sanjiv Chawla. During the surveillance operation, they recorded conversations between the men and the former South African captain, Hansie Cronje, where payments were discussed and how certain matches had to be lost during a tour to India. Cronje, who was considered one of the most honest players in the sport, was stripped of his captaincy and is under investigation by South African authorities after confessing to receiving money. Cronje's involvement, however surprising, fitted a wider pattern of players being named in match-fixing over the past few years. A number of Pakistani players had already been named before to the CBI report, while Australian players Shane Warne and Mark Waugh confessed to supplying information to a bookmaker in 1994. The pair were fined by Australian cricket authorities but not banned. The Cronje scandal prompted Indian authorities into taking action and it is largely through their efforts that the lid on match-fixing has been lifted. In a cricket-obsessed country like India millions of pounds are regularly bet on cricket matches. The bets are taken by businessmen working as illegal bookmakers who will also take wagers on how many wickets a team may lose, the number of runs a particular player may score or wickets he might take. As the CBI report concedes: "Betting on cricket matches in India has attained a measure of sophistication and it has spread across the length and breadth of the country. The use of computer and mobile phones has given a major fillip to the racket." While some of the players named in the CBI report have been accused of being paid to play badly, others like Stewart stand accused of supplying information. For bookmakers, gaining information on which team has won the toss or pitch conditions will affect the odds they set and this can make a difference between winning or losing large amounts of money. The CBI based its report on the testimony of 16 Indian bookmakers who all confessed to being involved in match-fixing. One of the main names to emerge in connection with the players is Mukesh Gupta, a Delhi-based businessman and part-time bookmaker, who claimed that he paid hundreds of thousands of pounds to players in return for playing badly or supplying information. Indian officials have conceded that there is not enough evidence in the report to bring criminal charges. It will now be sent to the world's cricket authorities, who will be responsible for taking action against any of the players named. Final word should rest with the CBI report, which concludes: "Major corrective steps need to be taken to put cricket back on the rails."

fields.headline: Runway doubt in Taiwan
fields.standfirst: Doomed aircraft 'hit something'
fields.trailText: Suspicion that the doomed jumbo jet in Wednesday's Singapore Airlines disaster in Taiwan may have used the wrong runway heightened the agony as rescue workers removed the final bodies from the typhoon-swept wreckage at Chiang Kai-shek international airport.
fields.body:
Suspicion that the doomed jumbo jet in Wednesday's Singapore Airlines disaster in Taiwan may have used the wrong runway heightened the agony as rescue workers removed the final bodies from the typhoon-swept wreckage at Chiang Kai-shek international airport.

The airport authorities and Singapore Airlines gave different versions of what might have caused the death of 79 of the 179 passengers and crew. Nearly all those who died were killed instantly, trapped in their seats as the plane burst into flames. The plane's fuel tanks had been full for the 15-hour flight to Los Angeles.

More than 50 survivors were in hospital in Taipei, some suffering from severe burns and smoke inhalation. More than 40 scrambled to safety, including the three cockpit crew. Only one person remained unaccounted for last night.

Yesterday morning emergency teams surrounded the crash site with a ring of parked trucks and cars to try to prevent the gale-force winds from disturbing vital evidence. The two "black box" flight recorders have been located.

The plane had slammed back on to the runway while taking off in appalling weather conditions, which were at first thought to have caused the crash.

But speculation mounted yesterday that the plane had hit an object on the scheduled runway, or might have taxied on to the wrong runway altogether, one that was out of service, its edges littered with construction equipment.

Taiwanese officials, on the defensive for keeping the airport open as Typhoon Xangsane drew near, insisted that wind speeds and visibility levels were within proper limits. They hinted at pilot error, suggesting that the plane may have swerved off its runway and on to the one which was under repair.

But a Singapore Airlines official said that the pilot, Captain CK Foong, a veteran with more than 11,000 hours of flying time to his record, "saw an object on the runway and he tried to take off and he hit the object". If true, this would suggest negligence on the part of the airport.

The airline said there was no evidence that the plane used the wrong runway. But, as daylight dawned, it became clear that the wreckage lay on a parallel runway to the one that Flight SQ006 should have used for take-off.

"We cannot tell at this stage whether he took the wrong runway, or veered off to the supplementary runway and then hit the equipment," said the airport's head of traffic control, Zhang Guozheng, yesterday.

There was speculation that the airport control tower would not be immediately able to identify a plane which had chosen the wrong runway, a mistake that would have been more easily made by a pilot in adverse weather conditions.

fields.headline: The chemical generation
fields.standfirst: Have man-made chemicals affected our fertility?  Saffron Davies  reports
fields.trailText: Have man-made chemicals affected our fertility? Saffron Davies reports
fields.body:
It reads a bit like a detective story, but there is not enough evidence to convict. We're talking about endocrine disrupting chemicals (EDCs), man-made chemicals that are additives in plastics, packaging, household cleaners, food cans, cosmetics and deodorants. Our crops are sprayed with pesticides, some of which are also classified as EDCs. Then there are the natural EDCs, grouped as phytoestrogens, which are found in plants and vegetables. Our lives are awash with EDCs, but the big question is whether or not they are affecting our fertility and our health.

The story began in the 1930s with the wide introduction of industrial chemicals that would "revolutionise" our lives. Between 1933 and 1938, the journal Nature published some short reports on the biological effects of several industrial chemicals. They had activity like the female sex hormone oestrogen, albeit much weaker than the natural hormone. Then, in 1938, Edward Dodds announced his discovery of a chemical, diethylstilboestrol (DES), that could mimic the action of oestrogen, and Paul Müller announced his discovery of a powerful new pesticide, DDT.

DES, was hailed as a "wonder drug" and DDT as a "miraculous pesticide". The two chemicals were not only structurally related, the pesticide also had weak oestrogenic activity. They were both found to feminise young male animals.

Fresh evidence of the decline of certain wildlife populations began to surface in the late 1950s. During the next 20 years, more and more field studies pointed to the possibility that man-made chemicals released into our environment could disrupt normal sexual development and hence the breeding competence of subsequent generations. For example, abnormally small penises were seen among alligators born in Lake Apopka in Florida, which had been polluted by an industrial spillage. Intersex or hermaphrodite fish were found in UK rivers receiving sewage effluent, and male sexual organs were found in female molluscs, particularly those living around harbours and marinas.

By the 1980s, concern resurfaced after studies on wildlife populations showed that pollution was affecting fertility and survival. A DDT-like pesticide was blamed for the decline in the alligator population and tributyl tin in anti-barnacle marine paint was linked with intersex molluscs. The only chemicals identified as possible causative agents for intersex fish living by sewage works were natural oestrogens and a synthetic oestrogen in the contraceptive pill secreted in urine.

More than 50 years later, the long forgotten evidence from the 1930s that industrial chemicals had oestrogenic activity resurfaced. Ana Soto and her colleagues, working in Boston on an oestrogen sensitive tumour cell line, suddenly found their experiments had all gone haywire.

After months of laborious detective work they discovered that the cause of the problem was plastic tubes. Without changing specification, the company supplying the laboratory plastics had added an oestrogenic alkylphenol, nonylphenol, to their products. This industrial chemical, also used in domestic products and cosmetics, was leaching into their culture solutions so that cells were growing like crazy. In California, by coincidence, David Feldman and his colleagues were also finding that their experiments were being contaminated by another plastic additive, bisphenol A. The list of EDCs was beginning to grow.

The media really latched on to EDCs when Niels Skakkebaek and his colleagues at the University of Copenhagen researched the scientific literature and found that all the published data suggested that average sperm counts had dropped by almost 50% between 1938 and 1990. Was this a result of pollution and increased testicular cancer, which has doubled in the last 20 years?

R ichard Sharpe, an expert in reproductive toxicology from the MRC reproductive unit in Edinburgh, believes the issue of declining sperm counts is a melting pot. "There is no overall standard for the accuracy of counting sperm in the first place, and different laboratories with different samples and different observers will, of course, come up with different results. And one has to remember that sperm counts also show a natural seasonal variation. Strictly speaking, there is, as yet, no definitive evidence for declining sperm counts. But that doesn't necessarily mean they are not declining."

Controlled laboratory studies have shown that EDCs can muscle in with the activity of sex hormones and, in high doses, can unbalance sexual development and function. At first they were all thought to be weak impostors of natural oestrogens, but it looks as though different chemicals may have different types of action.

However they act, EDCs have been causally linked to the rise in the incidence of breast cancer and a trend towards earlier puberty. But is the rise in breast cancer due to better detection over the years, and is earlier puberty due to better nutrition? These are ponderables without any direct evidence. Certainly no evidence to convict.

There are more than 80,000 man-made chemicals in everyday use and we don't know how many of them are capable of interfering with natural hormone functions in man or animals. According to a recent report on EDCs by the Royal Society, the US is to screen about 15,000 chemicals for endocrine-disrupting activity. Such tests, however, may not identify the long-term effects of these chemicals on reproductive development when cause and consequence may be separated by a considerable length of time.

"We don't know how these chemicals interact in our bodies, how our bodies degrade them, and what level of exposure is required before any adverse effects arise," says John Sumpter from Brunel University. He has spent many years surveying intersex fish in British rivers. "What happens in a test tube does not necessarily happen in real life, but we cannot dismiss the issue."

But "based on the evidence we have before us", reflects Richard Sharpe, "I would not discount the possibility."

fields.headline: Science update
fields.trailText: Death star in the distance | Fungus and the bogeyman
fields.body:
Death star in the distance
Japanese astronomers have spotted perhaps the biggest potentially hazardous asteroid yet. It could be around six miles across, in the same league as the one that spelt doom for dinosaurs 65m years ago. Its trajectory could bring it within 3million miles of earth once every five years. "We thought all earth-approaching asteroids larger than two or three miles across had been found," says Duncan Steel, the Salford asteroid expert. "It tells us there's a lot we still don't understand."

Fungus and the bogeyman
Metarhizium anisopliae, a naturally occurring fungus, doesn't hurt bees, beetles or butterflies, nor plants, mammals and people. However, it is hell on grasshoppers and their near relative, the desert locust. It is also the basis of a new biopesticide being sprayed over Niger. First reports are that, at $10 (£7) per hectare, it keeps the swarms down for three times longer than current chemical sprays. It took scientists at the International Institute of Tropical Agriculture in Nigeria more than 10 years to develop with an international consortium. They used a local strain of the fungus, but a similar formulation could be cooked up for wherever locusts lurk. The fungal spores, mixed in oil, have been trademarked Green Muscle.

Like a drug off the market
A wry twist for campaigners worried about the way pharmaceutical companies spend huge sums on drugs for the West, while not making drugs against diseases that kill in the developing world: Clinton White, of the Baylor College of Medicine in Houston, has been warning that drugs to treat schistosomiasis, a parasitic disease that can cause chronic liver damage and affects an estimated 200m people, were in short supply. There was demand in the US - but it was so low that manufacturers stopped making the praziquantel available in other countries. "Here we had a perfectly treatable infection and no access to a drug," says White. The maker has since agreed to resume production.

fields.headline: Fashion phone
fields.trailText: Ericsson is making an unashamed bid for the booming 18 to 25 year old mobile market with the T20, its new Wap (wireless application protocol) phone.
fields.body:
Ericsson is making an unashamed bid for the booming 18 to 25 year old mobile market with the T20, its new Wap (wireless application protocol) phone.

Launched this week with the help of members of the All Saints pop group, it boasts "real-time" Wap-to-Wap chat, the ability to send e-cards, horoscopes, news of clubs and gigs, plus compatibility with Ericsson's MP3 and keyboard add-ons.

The T20 has been designed in a choice of gaudy colours and can be worn as a fashion accessory on the arm or even leg .

To prove how global it is, the phone mimics Swatch's global internet time (a day is divided into 1,000 beats starting at 000 beats and ending at 999).

Weighing in at 124 grams, it is expected to hit the shops before Christmas selling at £19.99 on contract -a pre-paid version will follow later.

webTitle: The trick is in the timing

fields.headline: The trick is in the timing
fields.standfirst: Are humans apes that have never grown up? This depends on a gene, writes  Henry Gee
fields.trailText: Are humans apes that have never grown up? This depends on a gene, writes Henry Gee
fields.body:
Small children who are doubly incontinent can tell the difference between a triceratops and a tyrannosaurus. It is as if their brains have raced ahead of their widdly bits. Variation in developmental timing, in which different parts of a creature develop at different rates, is not confined to young humans. Ernst Haeckel, Darwin's biggest fan in Germany, recognised that the process could have been important in evolution, and named it "heterochrony".

For most of the past century, heterochrony has been seen as one of the most important agents of evolutionary change. In 1977, the Harvard evolutionary biologist Stephen Jay Gould published a book, Ontogeny and Phylogeny, in which he re-affirmed the theory.

It is easy to see why heterochrony is important: adult organisms represent the final working out of a long series of processes and events starting with the fertilisation of a single cell, the egg. In terms of embryology, it is hard to see how evolutionary change can occur without perturbing this process in some way. On the other hand, each stage of development depends critically on preceding events, so more than a little disturbance can be fatal. One way to nudge development into a different pathway is to alter not the nature of any developmental event, but its timing.

Classic cases of heterochrony in action include the axolotl, a Mexican salamander that becomes sexually mature while still in the larval stage. In 1928, the marine biologist Walter Garstang suggested that all vertebrates - backboned animals, including humans - were, in a metaphorical sense, axolotls. He supposed that, long ago, the tadpole-like larvae of sessile sea creatures, called sea squirt, could have become sexually mature, reproducing to create more tadpoles and eliminating the sea-squirt stage from their life history. These tadpoles evolved into the first fishes.

Closer to home, anthropologists looked at the human form and suggested that human adults have more in common with immature than adult apes. In other words, human beings are simply apes that never grow up. This idea is explored with grisly relish in the novel After Many A Summer, in which the fifth Earl of Gonister and his mistress, Kate, fed mostly on an elixir of raw fish guts, live for more than 200 years - and turn into apes. The author was Aldous Huxley, grandson of Thomas "Darwin's Bulldog" Huxley. The book is far from Aldous Huxley's best work, but is more fun than Problems Of Relative Growth, which explores some of the same themes. The author of that tome was Sir Julian Huxley, Aldous's more sensible brother. Heterochrony, it seems, runs in the family.

Heterochrony is less fashionable as an agent of change than it once was, but it is about to make a comeback. New work suggests that minced mutant roundworms, rather than fish guts, should be the entrée of choice for earls bent on immortality.

In Nature last February, Gary Ruvkun of Harvard Medical School and colleagues, working on the tiny laboratory roundworm called Caenorhabditis elegans, showed how worms cannot make the transition to adulthood from their final larval stage without a gene called let7. In worms, let7 encodes a relatively small molecule of ribonucleic acid (RNA) that binds to other genes implicated in developmental timing, controlling the passage between the larval and adult states. One of these genes is called lin41. In today's Nature, the researchers broaden their study. Animals as varied as fruit flies, zebra fishes, sea urchins - and humans - all have versions of let7. Fruit flies and zebra fishes have versions of lin41 that could be targets for the let7 RNA molecules.

The researchers go further, showing how let7 is expressed in many animals at key stages of development, often (but not always) at later stages, just before adulthood. In flies, as in roundworms, let7 is switched on in the last larval stage, just before the maggot becomes a pupa and turns into an adult fly.

Flies and roundworms are related - albeit distantly - but what about even more distant cousins? Humans, for example, do not have the distinct larval stages of flies and roundworms. However, given that let7 is often expressed later rather than earlier in development, it could be important that the human tissue with the lowest level of let7 expression is bone marrow, which consists of a large proportion of immature cells.

This research is tantalising rather than conclusive. There are plenty of "heterochronic" mutants in Caenorhabditis elegans in which development can be retarded or accelerated by altering the expression of genes such as let7.

However, nobody has even come close to doing this in flies. But this work points the way to investigate whether there is a direct connection between genes such as let7 and heterochrony - variation in developmental timing. If there is, the way will be open to start comparing the expression of "heterochronic" genes between species whose differences are thought to stem from heterochrony.

Fish guts or no fish guts, the expressions of genes such as let7 could explain why humans are far more different from chimpanzees than the gross difference in DNA sequence (around 1%) suggests.

 Henry Gee is a senior editor of Nature.

In Nature last February, Gary Ruvkun of Harvard Medical School and colleagues, working on the tiny laboratory roundworm called Caenorhabditis elegans, showed how worms cannot make the transition to adulthood from their final larval stage without a gene called let7. In worms, let7 encodes a relatively small molecule of ribonucleic acid (RNA) that binds to other genes implicated in developmental timing, controlling the passage between the larval and adult states. One of these genes is called lin41. In today's Nature, the researchers broaden their study. Animals as varied as fruit flies, zebra fishes, sea urchins - and humans - all have versions of let7. Fruit flies and zebra fishes have versions of lin41 that could be targets for the let7 RNA molecules. The researchers go further, showing how let7 is expressed in many animals at key stages of development, often (but not always) at later stages, just before adulthood. In flies, as in roundworms, let7 is switched on in the last larval stage, just before the maggot becomes a pupa and turns into an adult fly. Flies and roundworms are related - albeit distantly - but what about even more distant cousins? Humans, for example, do not have the distinct larval stages of flies and roundworms. However, given that let7 is often expressed later rather than earlier in development, it could be important that the human tissue with the lowest level of let7 expression is bone marrow, which consists of a large proportion of immature cells. This research is tantalising rather than conclusive. There are plenty of "heterochronic" mutants in Caenorhabditis elegans in which development can be retarded or accelerated by altering the expression of genes such as let7. However, nobody has even come close to doing this in flies. But this work points the way to investigate whether there is a direct connection between genes such as let7 and heterochrony - variation in developmental timing. If there is, the way will be open to start comparing the expression of "heterochronic" genes between species whose differences are thought to stem from heterochrony. Fish guts or no fish guts, the expressions of genes such as let7 could explain why humans are far more different from chimpanzees than the gross difference in DNA sequence (around 1%) suggests.  Henry Gee is a senior editor of Nature.

fields.headline: Web watch
fields.trailText: In the post | Surf safely
fields.body:
In the post
More than 18,000 post offices are going online following a deal between the Post Office and UK Villages, offering free websites to all 26,272 cities, suburbs, towns and villages in the UK. If it means more original local content, that would certainly help, since there seems to be a dearth of it at www.ukvillages.co.uk .

Surf safely
Anonymizer is known for letting users browse anonymously, but for best results, you need to pay for its premium rate service. SafeWeb offers a similar service free. SafeWeb "always encrypts and protects content [and] sanitizes dangerous scripts", it says, so presumably it will defeat most net censorship and monitoring programs.

Double vision
Authors, webmasters, press officers and teachers should enjoy the new service at FindSame. Paste in or upload a whole article or press release, or enter a website address. FindSame will search the web for anything containing at least one line the same, and you can view what it finds side by side with the original. It could find out which phrases in a press release appeared in print, where famous quotations have been used, and which authors are guilty of plagiarism.

Focus on this
Hewlett-Packard sent cameras to 100 people in various walks of life, and is putting on a show at www.hp.com/100cameras. So far, 80 photographers are online. The results are interesting, but the site is slow.

All in one
XOIP, pronounced "zoip", is another company providing a unified messaging service, and it is free. XOIP lets you send and receive faxes, hear and reply to your email by mobile phone, send SMS messages and receive voice messages. The service has been running in the Netherlands for about 18 months and is available here at www.xoip.co.uk

Get a buzz
What's the buzz today? Or more accurately, what was the buzz two days ago? Yahoo has launched a Buzz Index that doesn't just add up the most popular search terms but looks at the terms that have seen the biggest increase in searches compared with the previous day. The movers and leaders can be found at http://buzz.yahoo.com.

Side guide
Allyoguide is a browser add-on that pops up a side-panel in Microsoft's internet explorer for Windows, just like search, favorites or history. Allyoguide searches a directory of websites and shows a selection appropriate to the site you are viewing. www.allyoguide.com uses data from the Open Directory Project. It could use Yahoo, but Allyoguide's Steve Hanlon says the goal is for the service to build its own.

New and noted

 The Great Ormond Street Hospital for children has launched a charity site at www.gosh.org/homepage.htm

 The UK's waste management industry now has a portal at www.letsrecycle.com

 If you fancy being sherlock@bakerstreetw1.com , Streetnames is offering place-based email addresses at www.streetnames.com for £70.50. UK addresses (.co.uk ) cost £35.25 a year, inc VAT.

 The fight against age discrimination is championed at www.fifthmoon.com

fields.headline: What's new
fields.trailText:
Son of MP3
Watch out MP3. AAC (Advanced Audio Coding), widely tipped as its successor, will be coming to the UK early next year. Two manufacturers have announced that their new MP3 players will also be compatible with the new format developed by Dolby andSony, which offers higher quality music reproduction at lower bit rates. Its backers claim it is 30% more efficient than MP3.
fields.byline: Ashley Norris, Neil McIntosh  and Jack Schofield
fields.body:
Son of MP3
Watch out MP3. AAC (Advanced Audio Coding), widely tipped as its successor, will be coming to the UK early next year. Two manufacturers have announced that their new MP3 players will also be compatible with the new format developed by Dolby andSony, which offers higher quality music reproduction at lower bit rates. Its backers claim it is 30% more efficient than MP3.

Due in the stores in December is the AAC/MP3 Aiwa MM-EX300. The tiny £200 player features 32MB flash memory, sports a Multi Media Card upgrade slot and comes with rechargeable batteries, a neck strap and a USB connector.

Aiwa is also promising MP3 enabled CD players, ghetto blasters and in-car products for early next year.

S3 is also readying its range of players for the new format. Its Rio 600, which is on sale now, and the Rio 800, which is due in January, can both be upgraded to playback files encoded in AAC.

Late call
Philips is finally ready to join its rivals in offering Wap-endowed mobile phones. Due on sale next week is the Az@lis 238 pay-as-you-go model, while a contract model the Xenium 9@9 Wap will follow later in the month.

Pitched at business users, the Xenium 9@9 is a small dual band model with a talk time of seven hours and standby of 600 hours.

The phone features Philips' voice command function which can be used to access Wap sites as well as call numbers stored in the phone's address book.

Other facilities include a vibra alert, personal organiser options and emotion icons (smiley faces, beer glasses etc) which can be sent to other Philips phone owners as short text messages.

The phone will cost £100 and is available via BT Cellnet.

The pre-pay Az@lis 238 shares many of the Xenium 909 facilities, notably voice activated dialling and Wap connection, emotion icons and vibra alert. It has a talk time of up to six hours and 500 hours standby time.

Also new from Philips is a digital cordless phone sporting many features traditionally associated with mobiles. The £180 Zenia has a 200 name phone book, voice dialling and vibra call.

Snap and print
Canon unveiled its secret weapon in its campaign to dominate the digital camera market last week - a digital camera with an integral bubble jet printer.

Due in Japan next year and the rest of the world the year after, the Micro Bubble Jet Camera prints credit card sized images in under 60 seconds. It can store up to 300 images on its accompanying 48MB CompactFlash card and has a picture resolution of around 2 million pixels.

Snappers can also record sound with the image which is then stored on the actual print. The camera's UK price is expected to be in the region of £400.

At its expo in Paris, Canon also demonstrated a host of Bluetooth enabled products including a digital camera, PC card and printer, but refused to give any details of prices and availability.

Other prototypes on display included a 3D scanner, which features software that can take 12 2D images and re-configure them as a 3D colour image. Canon also highlighted its UCanTalk voice recognition software by showing voice-activated fax machines and PCs. (AN)

Macster ahoy

Apple Mac-toting music fans can now download a test version of the controversial music sharing program, Napster, and experience the MP3 phoenomenon first hand.

Napster is a catalogue of MP3 music files held in individuals' hard drives around the world. The service makes it easy to "share" music files between computers, putting a vast catalogue of music within a few mouse clicks.

But much of the music available via Napster is illegally copied from CDs, and that has lead to major record companies' continuing attempts to have the service closed down for copyright violation.

Mac users had, offically, been denied the pleasures of of Napster, although a clone called Macster did give them access to the service.

Macster has now been adopted as the official Mac client for Napster, meaning faster updates for Mac users.

You can download the Mac software from www.napster.com/mac. (NM)

Bluetooth arrives
Toshiba claims it is the first vendor to make Bluetooth wireless products commercially available In the UK - it has certainly been the first to ship working samples to Online.

The Bluetooth PC Card is a network card that enables a notebook PC to be linked wirelessly to other Bluetooth devices, including computers, mobile phones, handheld organisers and printers, when these become available.

It costs £125 plus VAT.

Toshiba was a founder member of the multi-vendor group that developed Bluetooth as an industry standard.

Chips chopped
Intel has slashed the price of its top-end processors to prepare the way for the Pentium 4, which is expected to appear later this month.

The price of Pentium III chips running at 800MHz to 1GHz has been slashed by more than 30%. Prices of low-end Celeron processors have also been dropped, the 700MHz Celeron version falling by 36% to $88, so now all Celerons cost less than $100 in quantities of 1,000 or more.

However, the prices of some low end chips were only cut by 5-7%. Intel is expected to announce 1.4GHz and 1.5GHz Pentium 4 chips costing $625 and $795 on November 20.

Lower processor prices should result in cheaper PCs in the shops.

First video cellphone
Geo Interactive Media, from Israel, and Samsung Electronics, from Korea, have announced the world's first commercial MPEG4 streaming video cellphone.

The phone uses Geo's Emblaze A2 video chip to play video streamed over GSM and CDMA mobile phone networks.

The speed, image size and quality depend on the network bandwidth available but Geo says the phone will work with "2G, 2.5G and 3G technologies". UK mobile phone networks are at the 1G (first generation) level with the first 2G systems based on GPRS (general packet radio service) just coming into use.

Notebook camera
Sony has launched a 45g video camera that will enable notebook PC users to take up videoconferencing, if they can plug it into a USB serial port.

The CMR-PC1 camera is designed to slot on to the top of the LCD screen and can be swivelled through 210 degrees to face away from the user.

It offers VGA resolution (640 by 480 pixels) and delivers up to 30 frames per second for only £99.99 including VAT.

See www.sony-cp.com/camera (JS)

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst:
Send letters to online.feedback@guardian.co.uk
Please include a full postal address and telephone number. Short letters stand a better chance of being published. No attachments, please.
fields.trailText: Your mail
fields.body:
Future shock?
I, too, feel sorry about the old man Douglas Rushkoff saw being humiliated when he tried to use a computer mouse like a TV remote control, and I have no sympathy for anyone who mocked him. But it's not because we're insecure that we find such things funny. The bloke who thought his CD tray was a cup holder remains funny, as does the one who tried to use the computer mouse like a sewing-machine foot control.

There has always been a difference between different types of technology. You couldn't use a seaport like a railway station, or a sewing machine like a knitting machine, or a fountain pen like a piece of chalk or a typewriter like a wax cylinder recorder.

Technologies have to be simple, amenable, not uncomfortable to use, not totally incomprehensible, I agree. But I'm sure that once it was all explained, the old man too would have given a wry smile.

Just because we're modern, we don't have to make everything like everything else. Standardisation is boring and life's rich tapestry would be that bit more fat-free if every type of technology had so carefully been "brought to the human", in Rushkoff's words, that there was not even the difference between a palm-top and a lap-top to divert us.

Very few of us are totally useless when faced with the shock of the new. Give us all credit for a bit of learning ability, Douglas.
Martin Hillman
martin@hillman.demon.co.uk

Betting worry
Your article about children being able to engage in pre-pay commerce on the internet (Online, October 26) is of concern for those of us trying to protect the vulnerable from gambling on the internet.

In a survey last year, 4% of teenagers claimed they would like to use their parent's credit card to gamble online. Innovations such as Splash Plastic will ultimately make it easier for those who are vulnerable to gambling to lose all their disposable income.

Innovations will almost certainly require a continuous review of gambling laws to take into account the rise of internet gambling.
Dr Mark Griffiths
Head of Psychology, Nottingham Trent University mark.griffiths@ntu.ac.uk

E-everywhere
Roddy Forrest (Online 26 Oct) asked if it is possible to send and receive emails from multiple ISPs through one connection. Jack Schofield replied that it wasn't. I think that Jack may be wrong.

Most ISP mailboxes are POP3 compliant, so you can pick up your email from any net connection as long as you know the server name, user name and password. Three solutions I use frequently are:

 Under Linux, fetchmail will deliver mail from any POP account into my local mailbox. My email program of choice, mutt, allows me to change the "From:" header to any values that I want.

 Under Windows the email program Eudora allows you do define "personalities". Each of these has its own POP connection parameters and associated email address to use on outgoing mail.

&##149; When travelling and reading/sending emails from cyber-cafes, I use Webbox, which allows me to read mail from up to five POP sccounts and send mail which appears to come from these accounts.
Dave Cross
dave@dave.org.uk

Not friendly
Thanks to Nigel Wilmott for a refreshingly honest appraisal of Linux's chances of taking over from Windows in general usage. It may well be a great OS but at the moment it's just too user unfriendly for the average home user.

Distributors such as Corel and Red Hat are doing their best to overcome this, by making the installation process smoother, and installing a GUI (graphical user interface) by default, but this is all just window dressing. In Linux the command line still rules.
Steve Jeffery
Steve.Jeffery@catalystuk.com

Nigel Willmott might consider buying a boxed set of a Linux distribution. If he wants to get Redhat he can, for a tenth of the price of a copy of Windows 95, buy a box which as well as CDs contains an installation manual and 60 days unlimited installation support.

As to network problems - networks tend to just work, so long as you're using an open protocol. If he is trying to get a closed Microsoft protocol to work, this can still be done, but he will have to install Samba, which, indeed, will be a lot of work. He might like to consider getting Linux to be his server (and he won't have to pay a penny more) and get Microsoft to fit in to its choices. That way Windows doesn't get a chance to scupper any other operating system interactions. Modems, again, should be no problem -so long as it is ISA, since no protocol has been settled on for PCI modems.

Perhaps he might also like to look in the many Linux newsgroups, where he'll find hundreds of people ready to help him out. Just a thought.
Ben Ross
guardianunlimited@house-hill.demon.co.uk

.it's a joke
What is Richard Heller on about (Online, October 26)? The whole point of regional-specific top level domains (like .uk, .au, .tv, .it) is surely for companies, organisations and individuals to allow the rest of the internet world to know where they hang out - not so some parasite can try to make up (not very) amusing names.

How intensely hypocritical, too, for him to brag about his own pointless and irrelevant registrations (why would a Lithuanian company be interested in "heartfe"?) then react with "fury" when someone else has beaten him at his own game or claim that such registrations are "for no good reason". Sorry? I fail to see a good reason for Mr Heller to register "makemoreca" anywhere at all.

And as for those pesky Italians - how dare they make it difficult for non-Italian companies to register a ".it" domain name! I suspect the embassy could have told him how but wisely chose not to. Next he'll be complaining he's finding it difficult to register a .gov.uk domain.

I suggest than when the state of Ontario gets its own top level domain, Richard registers "mor" before anyone beats him to the name that is rightfully his.
Antony Hawkins
A.D.Hawkins@sheffield.ac.uk

webTitle: Drugs: In the corridors of powder

fields.headline: In the corridors of powder...
fields.trailText: The distinctive chemical traces were, according to a senior German pharmacologist, enough "to make a sniffer dog bark". The samples had been tested by a respected institute and the scientists had no doubts: it was cocaine.
fields.body:
The distinctive chemical traces were, according to a senior German pharmacologist, enough "to make a sniffer dog bark". The samples had been tested by a respected institute and the scientists had no doubts: it was cocaine.

What is more, it was in large quantities and the tests established a very precise pattern of use: in the lavatories of the Bundestag, the parliament of the federal republic.

Officials last night expressed disbelief. The Berlin landmark was scarcely the place they expected to find bright-eyed sniffers and snorters. But checks on 22 out of 28 lavatories came back positive.

Embarrassed civil servants were last night attempting to arrange further tests after a television station, SAT-1, reported that the scientists had found the drug throughout the lower house of the German parliament.

Professor Fritz Sörgel, the head of the Nuremberg pharmaceutical institute which analysed the samples, said the tests had identified large quantities.

Most difficult to explain was the fact that the toilet used by visitors showed no traces of cocaine at all.

The German government's drug commissioner, Christa Nickels, said the tests were "questionable and dubious".

A spokesman at the Reichstag said the findings were "unbelievable". He also pointed out that a lot of people passed through the building every day and that there was no way of checking whether or not they were drug users.

It is true that reunified Germany's reinstated parliament building is frequented by security officers, journalists, cleaners and caterers as well as politicians and their staff.

But at the least it raises a suspicion that the loquacity of some MPs and the vigorous intensity of their speeches owes less to political passion than regular lines of star dust.

It remains to be seen if any politicians follow the lead of Christoph Daum. Appointed to coach the national football team before a cocaine test last month showed positive, he fled the country and has not been seen since.
