fields.headline: Stewart pleads innocence
fields.trailText: England's cricket establishment last night backed former captain Alec Stewart, who denied receiving £5,000 from an Indian bookmaker after being named in a police report that sent shockwaves through the game.
fields.body:
England's cricket establishment last night backed former captain Alec Stewart, who denied receiving £5,000 from an Indian bookmaker after being named in a police report that sent shockwaves through the game.

The England and Wales Cricket Board said Stewart had never met the bookmaker and was willing to cooperate with any inquiry.

The long-awaited report, compiled by India's Central Bureau of Investigation, confronted the international cricket authorities with their gravest crisis yet, appearing to confirm that match-fixing has been endemic in India - and ensnared cricketers from other Test countries, including England, West Indies and New Zealand.

Mohammad Azharuddin, a former Indian captain, admits his part in throwing three matches, while the former West Indian captain, Brian Lara, is also implicated.

Former Metropolitan police commissioner, Sir Paul Condon, head of the International Cricket Council's anti-corruption unit, is to investigate the claims against Stewart and eight other cricketers who are alleged to have been involved in match-fixing or supplying information to bookmakers.

The ECB promised full co-operation but said Stewart would not be suspended and would remain on the current tour of Pakistan.

According to the Indian report, Stewart was paid by Indian bookmaker Mukesh Gupta in return for supplying information on pitch and weather conditions during England's tour of India and Sri Lanka in 1993.

Hansie Cronje, the former South African captain banned for life, earlier admitted receiving £26,500 from Mukesh Gupta to fix a Test match.

The ECB said: "Alec Stewart has fully cooperated with the ECB over this matter, and has categorically denied to Lord MacLaurin, chairman of the ECB, and Tim Lamb, chief executive, that he has ever taken money from Mr Gupta or anyone else, for providing information related to a cricket match."

fields.headline: Gameplay performs
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: There was good news for shareholders in online computer games specialist Gameplay yesterday as prestigious investment bank Goldman Sachs began coverage of the firm.
fields.body:
There was good news for shareholders in online computer games specialist Gameplay yesterday as prestigious investment bank Goldman Sachs began coverage of the firm.

Goldman rated the stock as a "market performer" and said Gameplay traded at an unjustified discount to the European e-commerce sector.

In the longer term Goldman reckons the company is well placed to cash in on the emergence of digital distribution in the games industry. Gameplay customers can, for example, play many of its titles online, something that will improve as broadband communication technologies become the norm.

However, Gameplay needs to raise an additional £24m to see it through to profitability. Goldman estimates its £48m cash pile will run out in six to seven quarters.

Gameplay shares closed yesterday some 3.5p higher at 194.5p.

fields.headline: Nationalists defy Trimble's ban
fields.standfirst:
Republicans close ranks against move to punish IRA for arms delays

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Leaders of nationalist Ireland closed ranks yesterday to defy an attempt by David Trimble to ban Sinn Fein from attending a special cross-border ministerial council set up by the Good Friday agreement.
fields.body:
Leaders of nationalist Ireland closed ranks yesterday to defy an attempt by David Trimble to ban Sinn Fein from attending a special cross-border ministerial council set up by the Good Friday agreement.

Amid fears that the peace process could be unravelling, the Irish cabinet gave the go-ahead to its health minister, Micheál Martin, to join his Sinn Fein counterpart, Bairbre de Brún, at a meeting of the council tomorrow.

Seamus Mallon, the Social Democratic and Labour party deputy first minister in Northern Ireland's power-sharing executive, underlined his fury with the Ulster Unionists by announcing that he would clear his diary to attend the meeting in Enniskillen, Co Fermanagh.

Mr Trimble last night dismissed the meeting, which is meant to launch a cross-border food safety agency, as a "face-saving device" for Sinn Fein.

However, the decision of the Irish government and the SDLP to throw their collective weight behind Sinn Fein demonstrates the determination of nationalists to confront the Ulster Unionist leader. Mr Mallon, who decided to attend the meeting after a frosty meeting with Mr Trimble at Stormont yesterday, accused the UUP leader of "flying in the face" of the Good Friday agreement.

Mr Trimble sparked off the crisis on Saturday when he defeated a challenge from hardline unionists by pledging to ban Sinn Fein ministers from attending meetings of the north-south ministerial council. His move was designed to punish the IRA for its "failure" to live up to its commitments on disarmament.

Sinn Fein and the Irish government conceded yesterday that tomorrow's meeting would not be a formal meeting of the cross-border council because Mr Trimble, along with Mr Mallon, has the right to veto any minister from attending the body.

It will instead be a bilateral meeting which will discuss health issues, ranging from the new food safety agency to a cross-border campaign to warn women who are attempting to become pregnant to take folic acid as a precaution against spina bifida.

Ms de Brún said she was determined to press ahead with the Enniskillen meeting to show that Mr Trimble would not be allowed to "play party politics" with health.

Her remarks were echoed by Mr Mallon who said he would be attending tomorrow's meeting to protect the "integrity and operation" of the cross-border bodies. He also rounded on Mr Trimble for refusing to agree to an emergency meeting of the power-sharing executive to discuss the crisis.

"As it stands, the first minister is vetoing a meeting of one of the institutions - the executive - and vetoing attendance of the responsible minister at another institution, the north-south ministerial council," Mr Mallon said. "This flies in the face of a central element of the Good Friday agreement - that unionists and nationalists will operate these institutions in partnership."

The Northern Ireland Office declined to comment on the decision to go ahead with tomorrow's meeting, saying that the cross-border body is run by Dublin and by the devolved institutions in Belfast. However, some British sources suggested earlier in the week that it would be unhelpful if Dublin went ahead with the meeting.

The Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, will use a meeting in London today with the Irish foreign minister, Brian Cowen, to call for a balanced approach to the crisis.

Mr Mandelson will tell Mr Cowen that republicans need to reassure unionists by stepping up the disarmament process. Unionists also need to do more to reassure republicans that, if the IRA disarms, they remain committed to all the institutions set up by the Good Friday agreement.

webTitle: Loyalist feud claims its seventh life

fields.headline: Loyalist feud claims its seventh life
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: A man was shot dead in Belfast last night as the loyalist feud, which claimed two lives on Tuesday, intensified.
fields.body:
A man was shot dead in Belfast last night as the loyalist feud, which claimed two lives on Tuesday, intensified.

Two gunmen burst into the man's flat on the loyalist Rathcoole estate in north Belfast and opened fire shortly before 6.30pm.

The shooting was believed to have been carried out by the Ulster Defence Association in retaliation for the killing on Tuesday of the loyalist politician Tommy English by the rival Ulster Volunteer Force. Last night's attack brought to seven the number of men killed in the feud which erupted in August.

The leaders of the UDA and UVF yesterday called off peace talks which senior members had agreed after weeks of negotiations.

Meanwhile a police officer lay criticially ill in hospital after losing his leg to a bomb planted by dissident republicans in Castlewellan, Co Down. The device was hidden in a traffic cone which exploded as the officer moved it from the front gate to Castlewellan police station.

The married father of three, who is in his late 40s, was seriously ill in intensive care last night after a six-hour operation.

A second officer, in a nearby patrol car at the time of the blast, was treated for shock.

The attack, which was blamed on the Real IRA, raised fears that the dissident republicans, responsible for the Omagh bombing in 1998, are planning an escalation of their campaign. Yesterday was the first time they have inflicted severe injuries on an RUC officer.

A senior police officer in nearby Downpatrick recently warned of the threat from dissident republicans. Members of the Real IRA, the Continuity IRA and disaffected members of the Provisional IRA were said to have moved from Belfast to operate in the south Down area.

webTitle: Gay man's asylum bid lost as persecution plea fails

fields.headline: Gay man's asylum bid lost as persecution plea fails
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: A gay Romanian, who fled his country because of hostility to homosexuals, lost his battle for asylum in the high court yesterday because his treatment fell short of persecution.
fields.body:
A gay Romanian, who fled his country because of hostility to homosexuals, lost his battle for asylum in the high court yesterday because his treatment fell short of persecution.

Gabi Ragman, 25, left Romania for Britain after he was told he had brought shame on the university where he studied and would not be allowed to become a physical education teacher. But "uncaring and cruel" treatment suffered by gay people did not necessarily amount to persecution, Mr Justice Scott Baker ruled.

To be entitled to refugee status under the 1951 Geneva convention applicants had to show a "well founded fear of persecution". The judge rejected Mr Ragman's application for judicial review of an adjudicator's decision last year upholding the home secretary's refusal to grant him asylum.

Dismissing the challenge, the judge said Mr Ragman suffered insults and ridicule after it became known that he was homosexual. But the logical conclusion to the argument of his case was that "all known homosexuals" from Romania would then be entitled to asylum in the UK.

The judge said: "The right protected by the convention is not a right to practise as a homosexual. It is the right not to suffer persecution for doing so." This case demonstrated that there could "be various degrees of hostility towards homosexuals that nevertheless fall short of persecution".

Mr Ragman, who arrived in the UK in 1998, was regarded as a credible witness on the treatment he had received in Romania, the judge said. His problems arose in his final year at university when it became known that he was homosexual. The university's director called him to the front of an assembly of students and told him that he had brought shame on the institution.

It was decided by the college that Mr Ragman could finish his physical education course but would never be allowed to teach because he would be "a danger to children".

Romanian society was hostile to homosexuals, the judge added, and the public attitude there was that homosexuals were insane. Mr Ragman was insulted every time he left home, in a situation that resembled "a free theatre". There was no one to turn to for help.

The Romanian government had altered the law to allow homosexual acts between consenting adults in private because the country wanted to join the European Union, but society's attitude did not appear to have changed.

The adjudicator had concluded "with regret" that the hostility experienced by homosexuals in Romania, "uncaring and cruel though it is, is not of such a nature and severity as to amount to persecution". The judge said the court should not interfere with this conclusion.

fields.headline: Gromit boosts Wensleydale
fields.trailText: Britain's love affair with Wallace and Gromit has now helped the cartoon characters' favourite cheese make its mark as a national favourite.
fields.body:
Britain's love affair with Wallace and Gromit has now helped the cartoon characters' favourite cheese make its mark as a national favourite.

The irresistible rise of Wensleydale cheese has reached new heights with the takeover of its makers' only serious rival.

Less than 10 years after the Yorkshire village of Hawes rescued the Wensleydale creamery from closure by its then London owners, the cheesemakers have topped a five-fold expansion with the purchase of Fountain's Dairy at nearby Kirkby Malzeard.

The move will allow new facilities for Cranberry Wensleydale, a Gromit favourite invented after the firm's revival which now outsells all other blended British cheeses.

The merged companies will employ 175 people nine years after the Hawes workforce fell to a low of 11. The turnaround is one of the most romantic stories in the history of the cheese, whose many dramas go back to the French monks of Jervaulx abbey who developed Wensleydale in the 11th century.

Bankrupted three times in the past 60 years, the creamery survived such indignities as the dumping of five tonnes of unsold cheese down a local lead mine and the wartime diversion of milk to make chocolate for the armed forces.

The key figure in the cheese's modern history was Kit Calvert, a Wensleydale farmer and polymath who united warring local cheesemakers into a 1950s co-op which included both Hawes and Kirkby Malzeard. His spirit was invoked in 1992 when Dairy Crest, then the commercial arm of the Milk Marketing Board, decided to close down Hawes and make Wensleydale - unthinkably - in Lancashire.

Protests, including a stony-faced boycott of the cycling milk race which was sponsored by Dairy Crest and fortuitously passed through Hawes, led to a David and Goliath victory and the start of targeted marketing after a management buyout. The 340 tonnes produced annually by 11 staff when cheesemaking restarted in 1993 has grown to 1,500 tonnes, with 136 on the Hawes payroll.

Wallace and Gromit's enthusiasm for Wensleydale stemmed partly from Nick Park's own taste for the cheese and partly from the need for a wholly northern product.

webTitle: Populist's bid for top job hits sour note with Royal Opera

fields.headline: Populist's bid for top job hits sour note with Royal Opera
fields.trailText: Raymond Gubbay, renowned for staging operas that please the crowds, has failed to amuse the Royal Opera House, which has rejected his application for the post of executive director.
fields.body:
Raymond Gubbay, renowned for staging operas that please the crowds, has failed to amuse the Royal Opera House, which has rejected his application for the post of executive director.

Mr Gubbay, who has been a detractor of the ROH for most of the 30 years he has spent as an impresario, applied on behalf of his company, Raymond Gubbay Ltd, last month. Covent Garden invited applications after Michael Kaiser resigned in July.

The application included plans to limit the number of seats given to "friends", which account for 80% of tickets before they reach the box office, and to reduce prices and increase the number of shows.

Heather Newill, of headhunters AT Kearney, who were hired by the ROH to find an executive director, wrote to Mr Gubbay to tell him of the ROH's decision.

She said they decided it was "inappropriate for a company to run the Opera House," adding: "Should you wish to apply personally, they will consider your application in the light of the criteria they have drawn up for all applicants."

But Mr Gubbay said yesterday that he will not be reapplying for the job.

"Knowing the organisation as I believe I do, the rejection was not unexpected. A disappointment? No. I'm hardly under-employed," he said, adding that the reason for the rejection was a "cop-out".

"They don't want to have to address the issues I raised," he said. "At the very least they might have had the good grace to debate some of them.

"They should have called us in to explain exactly what we could do. I think I've succeeded in widening the debate. It's my understanding that much of what I said is being taken on board.

"The position of chairman as top dog looks like it might change and they're paying attention to seat pricing."

A spokesman for AT Kearney said: "We don't comment on confidential things like this. It's people's personal decision to put it in the public domain. That's up to them."

An ROH spokesman said: "A process is taking place now for shortlisting people and interviewing. The panel may well have made a decision within the next month."

webTitle: Life for father who killed as child begged for mercy

fields.headline: Life for father who killed as child begged for mercy
fields.trailText: A 34-year-old man who killed his former wife and their two young children in a frenzied knife attack was given three life sentences yesterday.
fields.body:
A 34-year-old man who killed his former wife and their two young children in a frenzied knife attack was given three life sentences yesterday.

After an eight day trial, Zainulabedin Zaidi was convicted of three counts of murder by a jury at Reading crown court.

Zaidi, a former banker, stabbed his ex-wife Shazia, 27, to death in front of their seven-year-old daughter Saba, and six-year-old son Zeeshan, before slitting both children's throats at their home in Great Hollands, Bracknell, Berkshire, on March 17 this year.

After the verdicts Detective Superintendent Trevor Davies, of Thames Valley police, dismissed Zaidi as "a pathetic excuse for a human being".

He condemned him for having pleaded not guilty when the evidence against him was so overwhelming.

The scene of crime had been "one of the most appalling sights I have ever seen", Mr Davies said.

During the trial the jury was played a tape of the 999 call made by one of the children during the killings. On the tape a child's voice was heard pleading: "Don't kill me, daddy", then telling the operator: "My dad is getting my mum and stabbing and killing me."

Zaidi, from Slough, Berkshire, was in a jealous rage after his arranged Muslim marriage had irretrievably broken down and his former wife had re-married in a secret ceremony, the court was told.

Adrian Redgrave QC, prosecuting, said Zaidi murdered his children "in cold blood" and that "the conclusion is in escapable - the child that was last to die must have witnessed not only the killing of their mother but also the other child".

After the killings, Zaidi bought a curry then sought refuge with a friend in High Wycombe, Buckinghamshire.

He was arrested the following day after nationwide appeals as to his whereabouts.

Zaidi refused to give evidence during the trial and refused to speak to detectives, constantly maintaining his right to silence.

During hours of interviews the only sentence he uttered was: "I did not murder my wife and two children."

Forensic evidence linked him to the murders - his former wife's blood found spattered on his shoes and watch.

The jury took two and a half-hours to return a unanimous verdict of guilty on all three murders.

Passing the three life sentences, Mr Justice Moses told Zaidi: "I am quite satisfied you came armed with a knife.

"Once in the house you stabbed and cut Shazia's throat. You then stabbed and cut the throats of your son and daughter. They knew what you were about to do."

Outside the court, Shazia's family issued a statement saying: "We are relieved that justice has been served, however this doesn't ease our grief of losing our three cherished loved ones.

"The only comfort we have is that they are happy together in heaven, in peace, and finally free from the misery and torment he brought to their lives."

Press Association

webTitle: Matthews family fights back in turkey tussle

fields.headline: Matthews family fights back in turkey tussle
fields.trailText: Feathers were ruffled in the £230m tussle for control of turkey producer Bernard Matthews yesterday when the founding family insisted it would not sell its 42% stake and devised a tax efficient offer to try to persuade shareholders to back their attempt to take the company private.
fields.body:
Feathers were ruffled in the £230m tussle for control of turkey producer Bernard Matthews yesterday when the founding family insisted it would not sell its 42% stake and devised a tax efficient offer to try to persuade shareholders to back their attempt to take the company private.

Bernard Matthews, the 70-year-old chairman and founder of the Norfolk company, is being thwarted in his attempt to take the stock market-listed company back into private hands by the threat of a higher bid from Sara Lee, US owner of Douwe Egberts coffee and the Wonderbra.

In an attempt to deter the Chicago company from tabling a formal offer in the next seven days allowed under official takeover rules, Mr Matthews and his advisers yesterday announced the terms of their £1.85-a-share offer. He said the structure of the offer - which allows shareholder to take stakes in his private vehicle - had been devised after requests from long-standing shareholders who wanted to retain their investment in the business.

The announcement of the offer, contained in the official document which set the 60-day takeover clock ticking, heaped pressure on the turkey firm's independent directors, former Anglia Television chief executive David McCall and former Hillsdown foods boss David Newton.

The two men, who are left with a key negotiating role, yesterday appeared to split from the executive of the company by saying that while they were recommending the offer by the Bernard Matthews Holdings Ltd vehicle, independent shareholders "may wish to await developments prior to deciding whether to accept the offer".

Sara Lee, which is being advised by Goldman Sachs, is now expected to table a formal offer of as much as £2 per share within the next 10 days to help it achieve its long-established goal of taking control of Bernard Matthews.

Mr Matthews was unrepentant last night. "We don't want to sell the company. We've got a jolly good company and very good management."

The offer document posted to shareholders yesterday offers 185p per share in cash, a 57% premium over the closing price in May when the idea of management buyout was first mooted.

The offer also allows shareholders to take shares in the private vehicle, allowing them to escape capital gains tax.

fields.headline: Land Rover agrees pay deal
fields.standfirst: Flexi-time suspended in inflation-beating deal
fields.trailText: Land Rover yesterday moved to secure industrial peace as it gears up for expansion by agreeing on an inflation-busting pay agreement for its 13,000 employees.
fields.body:
Land Rover yesterday moved to secure industrial peace as it gears up for expansion by agreeing on an inflation-busting pay agreement for its 13,000 employees.

Union leaders recommended the one year settlement that will give a 4.25% rise in basic pay from yesterday and a holiday bonus of £265 next summer in a package said to be worth 5.75%.

The company, which was bought by Ford in July for £1.84bn, also agreed to modify working week arrangements inherited from the previous owners, BMW, that prompted an unofficial, one day dispute at parts of its main Solihull plant last month.

Land Rover employees work a 37-hour week but are paid for 36 hours, "banking" the extra hour. Previously, staff could take the extra hours as seven days' additional holiday, but they can now take them in the form of extra pay.

The company has, under union pressure, suspended for three months an overall deal on flexible working time which enabled it to match the hours worked to peaks and troughs in demand.

Tony Woodley, the TGWU's chief car industry negotiator, said the suspension would enable both sides to remove any "abuses" in the scheme and develop a new one that would be acceptable to the workforces at Solihull and Gaydon.

"Flexibility has to be more user friendly, and under this agreement our members will be given a chance to review the deal without duress," he said.

Land Rover now produces some 180,000 units a year, including 80,000 of its bestselling Freelander model which it is about to launch in Japan and the US.

The company plans to increase annual output to 300,000 within the next five years, and Ford has set it the target of being back in the black by 2002.

Nick Caton, director of human resources, said yesterday's deal - to be voted on by the workforce in a ballot this week - provided "the flexibility and stability necessary to ensure the long term success of the company".

webTitle: Hepworth shares rally on talk of a takeover

fields.headline: Hepworth shares rally on talk of a takeover
fields.trailText: Shares in Hepworth, the heating and building materials group, soared yesterday after it said it had received a number of bid approaches.
fields.body:
Shares in Hepworth, the heating and building materials group, soared yesterday after it said it had received a number of bid approaches.

The board said that it was considering various ways to return value to shareholders, including making acquisitions or being taken over.

"We have had discussions with all sorts of people, including talks about a possible bid," a spokesman said.

Hepworth shares, which have fallen steadily over the past seven years from a peak of 498p, ended the day 47p higher at 241p.

Gruppo Riello, the heating company part owned by private equity firm Carlyle Group, and Carrier, the air-conditioning subsidiary of United Technologies, were reported to be among the potential bidders for the British group.

When Hepworth announced its interim results in July, the board said it was pursuing significant opportunities but if none were achievable in the year ahead, it would address the company's capital structure and look at other options.

The company, which had been selling operations to focus on its core business, had shown a slight improvement in profits at the half-way stage.

In a statement yesterday it said: "As part of the exploration of various options for delivery of value to shareholders, Hepworth is considering both acquisition opportunities and third-party expressions of interest in its business."

The company, which has about £190m in cash, is thought to be keen to preserve its independence by making a sizeable acquisition which would strengthen its heating equipment division which it sees as its core business

However it has made clear that it is not prepared to pay over the odds.

Since a new management team took over two and a half years ago, Hepworth has sold its air filtration business, its ladder business in France and its mineral and chemical operations. Analysts expect that it may also sell its building materials division, which largely makes pipes.

webTitle: Buffett picks up CGNU's rejected business

fields.headline: Buffett picks up CGNU's rejected business
fields.trailText: A firm run by legendary US investor Warren Buffett powered into the Lloyd's of London insurance market yesterday by buying an underwriting agency from CGNU, the newly merged insurance group.
fields.body:
A firm run by legendary US investor Warren Buffett powered into the Lloyd's of London insurance market yesterday by buying an underwriting agency from CGNU, the newly merged insurance group.

Shares in CGNU rose almost 4% to £9.58 on the announcement of the sale of Marlborough Underwriting Agency, even though the insurer revealed it would incur a £448m charge as a result of the move to pull out of the London market.

Mike Biggs, an executive director of CGNU, said the decision to sell Marlborough and quit Lloyd's was "completely consistent with our stated strategy".

Instead of underwriting insurance through the London market on a wide-range of commercial business, CGNU is now aiming to focus on "personal lines" such as house and car insurance as well as providing cover for small businesses.

The 340 people employed in the business were unlikely to be made redundant as a result of the sale, Mr Biggs said. "This is not a redundancy story," he said.

CGNU did not reveal the price paid by Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Group, which through one of its subsidiaries owns another managing agent at Lloyd's. Marlborough was originally purchased by the former Commercial Union, which merged with General Accident and Norwich Union to form CGNU, in 1997.

However, CGNU admitted that the sale of the business, and the other costs associated with pulling out of the commercial business, would hit its third-quarter profits by £448m, as one-off charge before tax. CGNU said it it had taken out £1bn extra of reinsurance from Berkshire Hathaway to cover it for any "adverse impact" on the run-off of its reserve claims of £1.2bn.

Mr Biggs said that the move to pull out commercial insurance and the potential risks associated with it would remove some of the volatility from its earning streams in the future. "This will improve the quality of the group's earnings going forward," Mr Biggs said.

Analysts said the sale effectively left CGNU without any on-going exposure to potential liabilities on the Lloyd's market, where much of the world's insurance policies are underwritten by managing agents through syndicates.

The Marlborough Underwriting Agency being taken over by Berkshire Hathaway was an agent for three syndicate which are still active and two which are in "run-off". The three active syndicates are underwriting exposure to marine and non-marine business and had a combined capacity for 2000 of £285m.

Updated figures on the business will be released to the market next week, but in the six months to the end of June, Marlborough reported a £31m underwriting loss and net written premiums of £162m.

The sale of the business had been expected for some time and the negotiations with Berkshire Hathaway are understood to have taken some time to reach conclusion. Berkshire Hathaway owns a number of insurance interests, including the GEICO car insurer in the US and General Re, one of the largest reinsurance business in the world and the owner of DP Mann, one of the largest syndicates at Lloyd's.

webTitle: Cantab says it has five potential suitors

fields.headline: Cantab says it has five potential suitors
fields.trailText: Hope is in sight for the beleaguered shareholders of Cantab Pharmaceuticals after the firm said yesterday it had received a number of approaches which could lead to a takeover bid.
fields.body:
Hope is in sight for the beleaguered shareholders of Cantab Pharmaceuticals after the firm said yesterday it had received a number of approaches which could lead to a takeover bid.

Shares in Cantab rose 23p, or 25%, to 115p, valuing the Cambridge-based vaccine specialist at £51m after its board said it was exploring approaches which might result in a takeover or merger. Sources close to the company indicated last night that at least five groups of "different shapes and sizes" had expressed an interest.

News of the approaches comes a week after the company parted company with its chief executive, Jurek Sikorski, and called in investment bank CSFB to advise on options for enhancing strategic value.

Mr Sikorski resigned after the failure in clinical trials of the company's leading product - a vaccine for genital warts - led to a two-thirds reduction in Cantab's share price.

Analysts were not surprised by the news and said the company would be attractive to either a gene therapy company or a life sciences outfit such as Baxter. The big US life sciences company recently bought a stake in Peptide Therapeutics, an erstwhile merger partner of Cantab.

They also suggested the possibility of a reverse takeover by the privately held British firm Microscience, whose backers include Apax Partners. Apax recently picked up a 9.1% stake in Cantab.

Despite the failure of Cantab's leading product, it has six drugs in preparation including a vaccine for nicotine addiction. It also has a cash pile of about £20m.

Its most promising product is a vaccine for herpes in phase II trials. Glaxo Wellcome was collaborating on the vaccine before regulators forced it to return the product in exchange for approving its merger with SmithKline Beecham.

Ian Smith, analyst at broker Lehman Brothers, put a value of 115p a share on the vaccine, saying: "It's not surprising people have expressed an interest, no one is denying they have interesting technology."

webTitle: Pass notes: Big Mouth Billy Bass

fields.headline: No: 1754
fields.standfirst: Big Mouth Billy Bass
fields.trailText: Big Mouth Billy Bass
fields.body:
Age: Eight months.

Appearance: Just a quiet little fish sitting peacefully on a wood-effect base. That's all. Just sitting there.

Doesn't sound like the usual brand of fun-packed target for Pass notes. Surely it does something? No, no. It just hangs there, quiet as you like. Why don't you take a closer look?

I see. The fish bursts into song when I break the electronic motion sensors, causing me to jump out of my skin as it serenades me with a rendition of Don't Worry, Be Happy and flicks its tail with alarming rhythmic regularity. Yes, rib-crushingly hilarious, isn't it?

Not particularly. Spoilsport. Looks like you'll be missing out on this year's big Christmas seller, then.

I managed without a Furby. Maybe, but this fish is going to be huge. It already has friends in very high places.

Harry Ramsden? Bigger still. Six of the blighters have made their way to Balmoral. "The Queen thinks Billy's a scream," revealed one royal insider. Her Majesty was introduced to the bass-voiced bass by the Princess Royal.

Bet Billy fitted right in with that family. He's also found a home in the White House: Clinton's a fan and gave one to that notorious master of mirth, Al Gore.

So it's the ideal present for a popular but fading politician to give to a colleague/rival prone to overt displays of affection with the missus and vote-wooing fibs? You could say that. But then again, John Prescott gave one to Tony Blair, so maybe you're way off the mark.

And did it do the trick? Tony has indeed stopped worrying and is happy. It's not clear, however, whether Prescott doctored Billy's other number, Take Me to the River. As head of the Department of the Environment, he would, of course, know that global warming means that the river can now come to you.

Do say: "Does he do scales?"

Don't say: "Oh cod, turn the volume down - that thing's giving me a haddock. Fetch a sturgeon."

Not to be confused with: Billy Hague.

fields.headline: At this price?  Deutsche Post
fields.trailText: German bankers and post office executives arrived yesterday for the first London roadshow in connection with the privatisation of Deutsche Post. The German government is selling up to 29% of the German post office in one of the biggest European offers this year.
fields.body:
German bankers and post office executives arrived yesterday for the first London roadshow in connection with the privatisation of Deutsche Post. The German government is selling up to 29% of the German post office in one of the biggest European offers this year.

While the bankers and others are bending the ears of the City's fund managers, they will also be feeling the pulse of the retail market. The Germans are hoping to repeat the success of the privatisation of Deutsche Telekom - and the British government's sale of British Gas - by attracting a large number of private investors.

Sources close to the flotation said the goal was to split the sale evenly between retail and institutional investors and make it as international as possible.

The international element is seen as important when the European commission is gearing itself up to curb postal monopolies. National post offices see overseas expansion as a way to replace lost monopoly income.

British Post Office executives have complained about the number of foreign operators queuing up to snatch its business. Among the would-be predators are Deutsche Post and its Dutch rival. Deutsche Post has been transforming itself from a bureaucratic local letters and parcels business into a leading international logistics group. It believes a widespread customer and shareholder base will be a ready market for new, and often internet-related, services.

The managers of the offer have pitched the terms to appeal to private investors. The price has been set at between €18 and €23 (£10.50-£14.50) a share, but retail investors applying before November 10 will get a €0.5 discount. They will also get a one in 15 share bonus if they hold the shares for two years.

Analysts estimate that these special terms plus the promised dividend, are worth 7% before allowing for any increase in the share price.

fields.bodyText: German bankers and post office executives arrived yesterday for the first London roadshow in connection with the privatisation of Deutsche Post. The German government is selling up to 29% of the German post office in one of the biggest European offers this year. While the bankers and others are bending the ears of the City's fund managers, they will also be feeling the pulse of the retail market. The Germans are hoping to repeat the success of the privatisation of Deutsche Telekom - and the British government's sale of British Gas - by attracting a large number of private investors. Sources close to the flotation said the goal was to split the sale evenly between retail and institutional investors and make it as international as possible. The international element is seen as important when the European commission is gearing itself up to curb postal monopolies. National post offices see overseas expansion as a way to replace lost monopoly income. British Post Office executives have complained about the number of foreign operators queuing up to snatch its business. Among the would-be predators are Deutsche Post and its Dutch rival. Deutsche Post has been transforming itself from a bureaucratic local letters and parcels business into a leading international logistics group. It believes a widespread customer and shareholder base will be a ready market for new, and often internet-related, services. The managers of the offer have pitched the terms to appeal to private investors. The price has been set at between €18 and €23 (£10.50-£14.50) a share, but retail investors applying before November 10 will get a €0.5 discount. fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Tokyo Story | Wild At Heart | Jackie Brown | Even Dwarfs Started Small
fields.body:
Tokyo Story

(Yasujiro Ozu, 1953)

6pm, FilmFour

One of the great Japanese director's finest works, full of the drama of family life. An elderly couple leave their quiet provincial home to visit their children in chaotic Tokyo, but find son and daughter far too busily self-centred to look after them. Beautifully portrayed and deeply affecting - simplicity bordering on the magical.

Wild At Heart

(David Lynch, 1990)

10.40pm, FilmFour

The horrible opening in which Nicolas Cage's petty crook Sailor Ripley smashes in the skull of a would-be killer sets the bizarre, dark tone of Lynch's sub-Blue Velvet tale. Cage and Laura Dern's Lula are lovers on the run through a weird American South - stalked by a hitman hired by the mother-in-law-from-hell Marietta (Diane Ladd). A road movie with a vengeance, it's full of Lynch's demonic humour, energy and disturbed violence, and won the Palme d'Or at Cannes. The ace cast includes Willem Dafoe's throbbing Bobby Peru and Isabella Rossellini as his hot girlfriend, Perdita.

Jackie Brown

(Quentin Tarantino, 1997)

11.50pm, Sky Premier

Pulp punk Tarantino's coming-of-age movie. An adaptation of Elmore Leonard's Rum Punch, it's an assured account of Pam Grier's middle-aged heroine, a stewardess with a past trying to make a living, then a killing, in a meticulously recreated 70s LA gangsterland. The music's soulful and the characters - Samuel L Jackson's deadly arms dealer, Bridget Fonda his stoned girlfriend, Robert De Niro's dim hood - are right on the money.

Even Dwarfs Started Small

(Werner Herzog, 1971)

12.45am, FilmFour

Proving he doesn't need Klaus Kinski to make absurd arthouse, Herzog crafts what must be one of the most obscure movies ever - an allegorical fantasy set in a parallel black-and-white universe populated entirely by dwarves, who stage a rebellion against their "captors". The film revels in chaotic set-pieces rather than considered storytelling.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Crossing Continents | Music Restored
fields.body:
Olenka Frenkiel brings to Crossing Continents (11.0am, Radio 4) a grim report from Uganda about the continuing activities of the Lord's Resistance Army under the leadership of the mysterious Joseph Kony. His ostensible aim is to create a Christian government based on the ten commandments. His actual record is one of appalling atrocity, including the kidnap of thousands of children, then forced either into military service or sexual slavery. Frenkiel talks to one 14-year-old who managed to escape.

Lucy Skeaping offers a lighter topic in Music Restored (4.0pm, Radio 3) where she explores with historian Mary O'Neill the emergence of the 12th and 13th century troubadours. The tradition seems to have begun in Poitiers and then rippled out as far as Italy and Catalonia. Many of its outstanding practitioners, like Guillaume IX of Aquitaine, were hardly the impoverished wandering minstrels of mythology.

webTitle: Work in progress: Matt Lucas, comedian

fields.headline: Work in progress
fields.trailText: Matt Lucas, comedian
fields.body:
Having already achieved more than I could have ever hoped in this risible industry, with its charlatan commissioning editors and parasitic producers, there's probably only one thing left that I want to do before I get six numbers and can thus afford to turn my back on the whole sorry lot. And that is to be involved in the writing of a stage musical.

Long before my screwed-up life provided me with the required number of neuroses to half-make it for about a month in the cut-throat world of cheap laughs, career-boosting benefit appearances and tawdry endorsements, I spent many an idyllic afternoon at the theatre with my mother or my dear, late grandma, watching musicals in the West End or skiving off school, snuggling up on the sofa in the shelter of my small but perfectly formed video collection.

I learnt at an early age that when all else is lost, when confusion and panic reign, everything is OK in Oklahoma! Like my other passion, Arsenal, the works of Loesser, Bart, Sondheim and - yes - Lloyd Webber have been there for me through thick and thin, while other friends have proved fair-weather. So it's with trepidation that I'm embarking on an attempt to provide some lyrics for a new musical. I've kind of bluffed my way into it, a bit like I did when I decided an interest in comedy might be enough to make me a good comedian. Oh, the arrogance! The naivety! As if being a trainspotter qualifies one to take the driver's seat.

Of course, I am aware that such news is no big coup. Greater comic talents than me, like Ben Elton and Jonathan Harvey, have recently opted to chance the same path. Forget rock'n'roll. It seems that comedy is the new Broadway, dahling.

webTitle: Comment: It mustn't be Bush or Gore

fields.headline: It mustn't be Bush or Gore
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: With five days to go, I have reached two firm conclusions about the US elections. The first: it mustn't be Bush. The second: it mustn't be Gore.
fields.body:
With five days to go, I have reached two firm conclusions about the US elections. The first: it mustn't be Bush. The second: it mustn't be Gore.

The reason it mustn't be Bush is that it would so much enthuse and empower a group of political forecasters I think of as the entrailists. Entrailists of earlier generations used the innards of newts, toads and bats, but with this lot, it's what their own guts tell them that counts. The leading protagonist in terms of the US elections is the columnist of the Spectator and the Telegraph papers, Mark Steyn. Since midsummer he has been asserting - with what friends would see as consummate courage and detractors as raving foolhardiness - that Bush cannot be beaten. On September 15, he even put figures on his prediction: Bush would take at least 378 of the 538 seats in the electoral college. "I figure my prediction can withstand pretty much anything this side of a third world war," he added. That figure of 378 was still his prediction last week.

If Steyn is even remotely right, two bad things will happen. First, he will become even more insufferable than he is now. Second, we shall see creeping out of their hidey-holes that tattered band of British entrailists who got things so wonderfully wrong in May 1997. First to emerge will be David Carlton of Warwick University who, having rubbished the polls throughout the campaign, denied that Labour could win. Behind him will be the substantial persons of Bruce Anderson of the Spectator ("I do not detect any sign of a Labour landslide. A hung parliament with the Tories on 315, Labour 304 and Liberal Democrats 12") and the Daily Mail's Simon Heffer ("I have never subscribed to the Labour landslide school of thought"). Do you wish to have these people feel that their methods work? If not, Bush has to lose.

But the reason Gore must lose is even more telling. His victory would vindicate and fortify an even more undesirable bunch than the entrailists: the political predestinarians. "According to half-a-dozen political scientists," the Washington Post reported this summer, "the die is all but cast". This fraternity - all in their different ways building on polling evidence but mixing in economic portents and voters' feelings about how well off they are compared to last year - were all agreed that Gore was going to win 53 to 60% of the total vote cast for him plus Bush. Conspicuous among them was Michael Lewis-Beck of the University of Iowa, who forecast Mr Gore winning 56.2% of the two-party vote. A modest man, he admits to having got things wrong in the 1996 election. He gave Clinton 54.8% of the two-party vote. The electors gave him 54.7%.

We have predestinarians here too. In recent months, the esteemed political analyst Peter Kellner has teamed up with their leading representative, Professor David Sanders of Essex University, to produce for the Observer a "Kellner-Sanders Index" which weights the opinion polls according to past performance and adds in such factors as consumer confidence. "Despite recent wobbles," Kellner wrote when they launched it on July 2, "Labour holds an 11-point lead and is on course for a big victory next year, unless Britain's economy hits trouble." Not as bold as Steyn, who requires a world war to upset his predictions, but still pretty confident stuff.

And they could very well be right. And yet I have before me the results of an exercise at the 1997 election when various pundits were asked by Reuter to forecast Labour's likely majority. At the top on 153 (26 short of the subsequent reality) came the master psephologist David Butler. The average of all participants was 92. But who is this down at the bottom, with only David Carlton beneath him? David Sanders, with a forecast of 55. What happened? Did the method misfire?

I suspect this kind of exercise somehow contrives simultaneously both to over- and under-value electors. It undervalues them by treating them as automata, as running on tramlines. It overvalues them by assuming they always act rationally, as reliable judges of their own self-interest. The US elections don't look that inspiringly rational to me. The most powerful elected job in the universe seems likely to go to a man who, though broadly recognised as nowhere near as good on the issues as Gore, is seen as much the more likeable guy. I heard this week of two seasoned academics who much to their own surprise are planning to switch to Bush. One because of the way that when Bush gave his answers in the first TV encounter, Gore let out such long superior sighs. And the other? He too has been reading, and writhing over, the predestinarians' boasts, and he's damned if he's going to cast a vote that would help prove them right.

fields.headline: Bid talk brews over S&N
fields.trailText: Apparently Brian Stewart, chairman of Scottish & Newcastle, cannot understand why the share price of his company is low.
fields.body:
Apparently Brian Stewart, chairman of Scottish & Newcastle, cannot understand why the share price of his company is low.

Despite being of one Europe's biggest beer companies and making more than £400m of profit last year the Edinburgh-based company has a miserly stock market rating and is not even a FTSE 100 constituent anymore - it was relegated at the last index review.

Indeed Mr Stewart's competitors cannot understand it either. However, instead of ruminating on the injustices of the stock market some are said to be preparing to do something about it.

According to the market gossips one of S&N's main rivals is poised to take advantage of its lowly share price by making a takeover offer. The names being mentioned in City dealing rooms yesterday were Dutch brewer Heineken and South African Breweries , 14p higher at 429p.

Heineken recently signalled its intention to expand further overseas and SAB, according to analysts, is desperate to muscle its way into western Europe.

For a predator intent on increasing its international presence the attractions of S&N are evident. Earlier this year S&N bought Kronenbourg from French beer manufacturer Danone for £1.7bn with the aim of making it into a global brand. It followed that purchase with the acquisition of a 49% stake in Central De Cervejas, a Portuguese beer company.

Moreover, S&N is also in the process of selling its leisure operations Center Parcs and Pontins, which in the past has been viewed by potential predators as something of a poison pill.

S&N refused to comment on the speculation but the shares closed 9.5p higher at 482p giving some credence to the story.

However, sources close to S&N indicated that US value investors were taking a keen interest in the group snapping up any stock on offer in the marketplace.

Leading shares meanwhile experienced another volatile session in which the FTSE 100 rose above 6,500, fell below 6,400, and then finished at a seven-week closing high.

At the close the FTSE 100 was 19.2 points higher at 6,457.6, while the FTSE 250 rose 53.8 points to 6,683.1 and the Techmark was 40.68 points better at 3,431.39.

Behind the volatility were wildly conflicting performances from the market's three biggest sectors: telecoms, banks and oils.

After a bright start, telecom shares lurched sharply lower after US company WorldCom, a big player in the long-distance telecoms market, cut its revenue and profit forecasts. Worst affected by the news were UK equivalents Energis , down 40.5p to 549p, and Cable & Wireless , off 45p to 930p. But there was also pain for Vodafone , 10p lower at 276.75p and BT , 18p weaker at 709p.

Nevertheless Telewest , the cable and telecoms company, managed to buck the trend putting on 11.25p to 125.25p as bid speculation continued to swirl around the stock.

The latest tale centred around an approach from Dutch group UPC. The more sceptical believed Telewest was looking cheap in the run up to third-quarter figures due later this month.

BP rose 12.5p to 597p, while Shell gained 7.5p to 562p. HSBC climbed 17p to 999p and Royal Bank of Scotland rose 23p to £15.70.

Also rising were fund management groups Amvescap , up 115p to £16.55, and Schroders , 58p higher at £13.05, both benefiting from positive comments made by Lehman Brothers.

IT services group Logica fell 104p to £19.35 on talk Morgan Stanley was trying to find buyers for a block of 4.7m shares.

Building materials group Hepworth leapt 47p to 270.5p on news of bid approaches.

Newcomer Charteris had a good debut run. Shares in the management consultancy closed at 116.5p, up 26.5p from their issue price.

webTitle: Rattle joins chorus to save opera

fields.headline: Rattle joins chorus to save opera
fields.standfirst: Axe falls on venerable Staatsoper as Berlin council bids to cut costs
fields.trailText: The British conductor Sir Simon Rattle yesterday joined more than 40 of the world's foremost musicians and performers in an appeal to save Berlin's most venerable opera company.
fields.body:
The British conductor Sir Simon Rattle yesterday joined more than 40 of the world's foremost musicians and performers in an appeal to save Berlin's most venerable opera company.

The city council is planning to merge the operations of the Staatsoper in east Berlin, which dates back more than 250 years, with those of the modern Deutsche Oper. The move could mean the loss of 77 jobs.

Berlin council says the move would also save DM20m (about £6m) a year. Opponents insist that savings would be less than half that figure.

Yesterday's appeal came in an open letter published by several Berlin newspapers. The signatories included the tenor Placido Domingo and the conductors Zubin Mehta, Pierre Boulez and Bernard Haitink. "As artists who know the Staatsoper, we appeal to you not to destroy the traditions that have been developed," they said.

At the heart of the debate is the threat which is posed to the Staatsoper's orchestra, the Staatskapelle, known as a leading symphony orchestra in its own right.

In the last eight years, under the musical directorship of the Israeli conductor, Daniel Barenboim, the Staatskapelle has virtually regained its position before the division of Germany as one of the world's leading musical institutions. Its pre-war directors included Richard Strauss and Herbert von Karajan.

Thanks to the relative isolation of former east Germany, the Staatskapelle has retained its distinctive sound. Mr Barenboim said recently that the orchestra's "unique sound culture" was a special reason for preserving it in a world where orchestral sound was virtually interchangeable.

The Argentine-born conductor yesterday piled on the pressure, describing the council's plans as "artistically and economically pointless".

Others, however, have argued that the duplication - a product of Berlin's cold-war division - has left the city with more culture than it can afford; and that opera, with its spiralling costs, is the obvious place to start the rationalisation process.

Under the plan put forward by the councillor responsible for the arts, Christoph Stölzl, the productions of a new, combined company would be shared between the two existing houses. The Staatsoper's majestic premises on the Unter den Linden would be used for most of the classical repertoire. Contemporary works and those by Wagner and Strauss would be staged in the Deutsche Oper, known to locals as "Sing-Sing" because of its stark granite facade.

Berlin's third opera, the Komische Oper, would not be affected by the plan.

Mr Barenboim, a conductor and pianist who is also music director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, signed a 10-year contract to run the Staatsoper in 1992. Last month, Berlin officials said he would not be renewing it because he wanted to shed the administrative side of his job. He claims otherwise.

Underlying the controversy is the issue of how the arts in Germany are funded. Most would agree that the Staatskapelle and Staatsoper form part of the nation's musical patrimony, yet they are bankrolled by the ratepayers of Berlin. At the same time, the huge potential for sponsorship has barely been explored.

Things are likely to remain that way until the German treasury offers tax breaks for cultural patronage.
fields.bodyText: The British conductor Sir Simon Rattle yesterday joined more than 40 of the world's foremost musicians and performers in an appeal to save Berlin's most venerable opera company. The city council is planning to merge the operations of the Staatsoper in east Berlin, which dates back more than 250 years, with those of the modern Deutsche Oper. The move could mean the loss of 77 jobs. Berlin council says the move would also save DM20m (about £6m) a year. Opponents insist that savings would be less than half that figure. Yesterday's appeal came in an open letter published by several Berlin newspapers. The signatories included the tenor Placido Domingo and the conductors Zubin Mehta, Pierre Boulez and Bernard Haitink. "As artists who know the Staatsoper, we appeal to you not to destroy the traditions that have been developed," they said. At the heart of the debate is the threat which is posed to the Staatsoper's orchestra, the Staatskapelle, known as a leading symphony orchestra in its own right. In the last eight years, under the musical directorship of the Israeli conductor, Daniel Barenboim, the Staatskapelle has virtually regained its position before the division of Germany as one of the world's leading musical institutions. Its pre-war directors included Richard Strauss and Herbert von Karajan. Thanks to the relative isolation of former east Germany, the Staatskapelle has retained its distinctive sound. Mr Barenboim said recently that the orchestra's "unique sound culture" was a special reason for preserving it in a world where orchestral sound was virtually interchangeable. The Argentine-born conductor yesterday piled on the pressure, describing the council's plans as "artistically and economically pointless". Others, however, have argued that the duplication - a product of Berlin's cold-war division - has left the city with more culture than it can afford; and that opera, with its spiralling costs, is the obvious place to start the rationalisation process. Under the plan put forward by the councillor responsible for the arts, Christoph Stölzl, the productions of a new, combined company would be shared between the two existing houses. The Staatsoper's majestic premises on the Unter den Linden would be used for most of the classical repertoire. Contemporary works and those by Wagner and Strauss would be staged in the Deutsche Oper, known to locals as "Sing-Sing" because of its stark granite facade. Berlin's third opera, the Komische Oper, would not be affected by the plan. Mr Barenboim, a conductor and pianist who is also music director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, signed a 10-year contract to run the Staatsoper in 1992. Last month, Berlin officials said he would not be renewing it because he wanted to shed the administrative side of his job. He claims otherwise. Underlying the controversy is the issue of how the arts in Germany are funded. Most would agree that the Staatskapelle and Staatsoper form part of the nation's musical patrimony, yet they are bankrolled by the ratepayers of Berlin. At the same time, the huge potential for sponsorship has barely been explored. Things are likely to remain that way until the German treasury offers tax breaks for cultural patronage.

fields.body:
"I remember when I first took her to all the designers, most of them just went 'yuck' "

Isabella Blow reveals how her fashion industry colleagues reacted to Sophie Dahl, Vogue

"I should have started lying about my age in my early 20s, but why shouldn't you show your body if everything is hanging in the right place? When I was 22, I had no reason to lie about my age. Now age risks being another limitation; you are pigeonholed"

Greta Scacchi, Hello!

"The presumption that the British public has been nursing a secret desire for media porn is fallacious. They presume we respond better to sexy ads for books or butter than we would to the traditional sort... Flat Eric didn't have any genitals, yet he was better loved than any of your Boddies or Baileys babes"

Charlotte Raven, The Face

"I love Smack the Pony. It's good to see women being silly and not having to address the fact that they're women. That was the problem we had. We wanted to be silly, like the men were being silly"

Jennifer Saunders, Time Out

"At parties, never stray too far from large groups of beautiful women. Avoid throngs of men... and you will quickly gain the reputation of a rogue and a playboy - and, in turn, power and respect"

Stuart Husband's tip for the Modern Machiavelli, Arena

"I don't want people to wag me around like a doll... It's upsetting to be treated like an object"

Star Wars' Natalie Portman on the pressures of fame, Empire

webTitle: French women are becoming more brave about being vulgaire

fields.headline: Rude awakening
fields.standfirst: They are seen as the sexiest women in the world, but the truth is they have always been surprisingly uptight about sex. Until now, that is.  Stephanie Theobald reports on a French revolution
fields.trailText: They are seen as the sexiest women in the world, but the truth is they have always been surprisingly uptight about sex. Until now, that is.  Stephanie Theobald reports on a French revolution
fields.body:
The French have always been good at sex as art. Like the best food, carnality is invested with intimations of the "au-delà" or the transcendental. Buggery, for instance, isn't just buggery. Done in the correct poetic framework it becomes Fauré's requiem, Renoir's umbrellas, the Versailles Hall of Mirrors, Last Tango in Paris.

A friend of mine once got picked up by a man in Paris on Beaujolais Nouveau night and was taken back to his studio where they engaged in anal sex. Afterwards, she said, he climbed down from the mezzanine bed, put on Dvorak and made leek soup, which they ate cross-legged on his wooden floor by the light of a candle.

For someone used to the English interpretation of joie de vivre - a package involving alcohol, swearing a lot, vomiting, then falling asleep on the job - living life like it is an endless New Wave film both fascinates me and makes me feel like kicking everyone hard. It's not that you want to go around acting like Saturday night in Pizza Hut all the time but after five years in Paris, I felt compelled to write a novel called Biche as a reaction to a city steeped in male myths of Hemingway and Miller taking "whores" to buggy hotel rooms, the Marquis de Sade and Georges Bataille churning out "intellectual eroticism" and singers like Serge Gainsbourg drooling through their Gauloises.

Looking for female vulgarity in Paris is like waiting for Godot: Juliette Greco was the plaything of the existentialists, Colette was basically in the pocket of husband Willy and although Simone de Beauvoir put it about a bit for a woman of her time, it was nothing compared with what Sartre got up to. Even French actresses have never really gone in for the casting couch system. If you are a French starlet, the deal is you remain faithful to a French "auteur".

Even when action does take place, it is done in such a goddam refined way. Take the American Natalie Clifford Barney, one of the most famous lesbians of the 1930s. Her literary salon welcomed guests such as TS Eliot, James Joyce, Djuna Barnes, Gertrude Stein and Dolly Wilde, the niece of Oscar. According to a new biography of Wilde, the women's extracurricular activities were as rampant as their literary ones, with Wilde having to perform "emergency seductions" when she got bored and Barney keeping lists of her conquests under the categories liaison, demi-liaison and aventure. This sounds promising until you read on and find out that Barney had a habit of delivering herself to potential partners wrapped up in a large box of white lilies and riding her glass carriage though the streets in the early hours to sing opera tunes under the balconies of other lucky lovers.

Ann-Marie Harper, a 33-year-old Englishwoman who has lived in Paris for the past eight years with Pierre, says her partner is often scandalised when he overhears her conversations with girlfriends. "He says: 'But why are you so vulgaire? You talk about cocks and things, you are very indiscrète.'

"Frenchmen seem to think it weird if you want to have a good time with other girls without them," Harper adds. "And they are shocked that Englishwomen drink so much." Alcohol, she adds, is probably at the heart of British joie de vivre.

Marie Darrieussecq, the first Frenchwoman novelist of recent years to write about sex as something dirty and unaesthetic, in her bestseller Pig Tales, agrees with the alcohol theory. She says she first noticed the difference between French and British versions of joie de vivre when, aged 14, she went to visit a penfriend in the north of England. "We went to the pub and there was this group of men having a stag party. The English get a little crazy when they drink. Suddenly a female stripper entered the room and began to do her act. Everyone thought this was very funny. In France this would never happen. Strippers in public are considered vulgaire."

The difference in approach to sex she pins down to the political climate of the 18th century. "In France, salon culture developed during a time of peace and leisure. There was time for refined flirtation and intellectual intrigue. England at the same time was more interested in fighting wars."

But it looks as though Godot might be around the corner after all. Darrieussecq mentions the recent kerfuffle caused by Baise-Moi, a film by her friend Virginie Despentes about two sexually predatory girls. It became a succès de scandale this summer when the far-right organisation Promouvoir banned it from cinemas in France, calling it obscene and anti-male.

Another film-maker, Catherine Breillat, has become known for her film Romance, about a woman who goes around Paris compulsively having sex to try to get over the love she feels for her boyfriend. Poetic sex is anathema to Breillat. "Even when sex is sordid," she recently told Liberation, "there is a beauty in the sordid. The so-called erotic is about humiliation of women. It is seen as acceptable because it is 'pretty'. Pornography is ugly. I prefer the ugly."

This autumn saw the release of a film Breillat made in 1975 (it was considered too risqué to show at the time). Called Une Vraie Jeune Fille (A Real Young Girl), it is about a teenager who can't stop thinking about sex. It opens at her bourgeois parents' house where the teenager is trying to masturbate under the dinner table with a spoon.

There are further signs that the French are becoming more brave about being vulgaire. The other contemporary author making a splash is Michel Houellebecq, a French Bret Easton Ellis. The French love their existential crises and this is what Houellebecq writes about - people having weird sex because their lives are so meaningless that that is all they can do (and even that they don't do very well).

Darrieussecq concludes that the trouble with the British is that they are too obsessed with sex per se. The true French lover, she insists, is an all-round sensualist. "I am just as interested in describing what a piece of chocolate tastes like as I am in evoking how a great orgasm feels."

 Stephanie Theobald's novel Biche is published by Flame, priced £10.99.

fields.headline: Fernando Gutiérrez Barrios
fields.standfirst: Mexican politician and chief of secret police who was privy to human rights abuses over several decades
fields.trailText: Mexican politician and chief of secret police who was privy to human rights abuses over several decades
fields.body:
Fidel Castro called him "the gentleman policeman". But Fernando Gutiérrez Barrios ("Don Fer" to his friends), who has died aged 73, had a darker side to his personality. The "best informed man in Mexico" - to some the country's very own J Edgar Hoover - Gutiérrez was "the man who knew most about the disappeared in this country," according to the veteran human rights campaigner Rosario Ibarra.

Born in the Caribbean coastal state of Veracruz, Gutiérrez entered the military academy at an early age and specialised in intelligence work. His father, a businessman, had also been in the army. By 1949 Gutiérrez had risen to the rank of captain, but the Mexican military - sidelined from politics since the post-revolutionary days - was no career for an ambitious young man.

Gutiérrez left the army and the following year joined the Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI), which under three different names had already run the country for over 20 years, and would do so for another 50, regardless of the true inclinations of the electorate.

Not surprisingly perhaps, the new recruit opted to stick to what he knew best, and in 1952 joined the Federal Security Directorate (DFS); in other words, Mexico's political police. His job was to investigate the PRI's opponents, but in 1956 he was called on to interrogate some rather unusual prisoners. Fidel Castro and his 26 July Movement - including Ernesto "Che" Guevara - had chosen Mexico as the ideal country in which to train and equip themselves for the overthrow of Cuban dictator Fulgencio Batista. They were under surveillance not only by the Mexicans but by Batista's intelligence service and the FBI. At the behest of Batista, the group was rounded up and questioned by the DFS, in preparation for what might have been their extradition to Cuba.

Details of the deal between Castro's group and the Mexicans remain unclear: Gutiérrez Barrios took them to his grave, and few other witnesses remain. But it is apparent that the Mexican intelligence agent and the Cuban revolutionary struck up a warm relationship which was to last the rest of Gutiérrez's life.

"He was a kind and gentlemanly policeman who conversed agreeably and even had some leftist ideas," Fidel would later say. Gutiérrez, for his part, said he never regarded Castro as a criminal, but a young man with ideals who planned to overthrow a dictator. The Cubans were released and went on to win their revolutionary war.

Gutiérrez visited Havana on many occasions, and when Castro attended the 1988 inauguration of President Carlos Salinas, he was personally attended by his former jailer. The two men even travelled to Tuxpan, in Veracruz, for a memorial ceremony at the spot where the revolutionaries embarked for their voyage to Cuba.

Back in Mexico, however, homegrown revolutionaries were unwelcome. Although the DFS and Gutiérrez gave a good deal of help over the years to leftist movements from elsewhere in the continent, they mercilessly repressed the Mexican left that emerged in the 1960s and 1970s.

In 1968, when security forces gunned down hundreds of unarmed demonstrators just prior to the Mexico City Olympics, Gutiérrez was director of the DFS. He then rose to under-secretary of the interior - retaining control of the political police - during the "dirty war" period of the 1970s, which left more than 500 disappeared prisoners whose fate remains unknown.

"What Fidel Castro saw as a friendly hand," said Rosario Ibarra, "was the hand of repression in this country. And death does not change a person's deeds." The DFS at that time ran a death squad known as the Brigada Blanca (White Brigade), whose activities were every bit as sinister as its counterparts in Central and South America. The difference is that in Mexico the truth about the period has yet to be publicly revealed. Gutiérrez Barrios, perhaps the most tight-lipped political figure in Mexico, knew all of it and never said a word.

His discretion and loyalty were rewarded with ever more senior positions. From 1986-88 he was governor of his home state of Veracruz, and when Carlos Salinas became president he appointed Gutiérrez interior minister. In 1993, however, as the time approached for him to nominate a successor, Salinas unceremoniously dumped him as minister in favour of the governor of Chiapas.

Gutiérrez, who in any event belonged to the "dinosaur" wing of the PRI from which the technocrat Salinas was attempting to distance himself, had committed the unpardonable sin of considering himself "presidenciable". His dismissal led to a period in the political wilderness.

Politics, however, was his life, and under Salinas's successor, Ernesto Zedillo, he staged a comeback. He was invited to run the PRI's first primary election (as perhaps the only man capable of keeping all the rival candidates under control) and stood for federal senator. On September 1, he was sworn in as a member of the upper house. Ironically, his unexpected death from a heart attack coincided with the removal from power of the PRI, which governed Mexico for virtually the span of his life.

Gutiérrez leaves a wife and four children.

Fernando Gutiérrez Barrios, secret policeman and politician, born October 26 1927; died October 30 2000.

webTitle: Taiwan air crash: 'I never could believe we would take off'

fields.headline: 'I never could believe we would take off'
fields.trailText: Passengers who miraculously escaped from the broken carcass of Singapore Airlines Flight SQ006 were soaked by torrential rain from an off-shore typhoon as they turned to see sheets of orange flame burst out from the fuselage behind them.
fields.body:
Passengers who miraculously escaped from the broken carcass of Singapore Airlines Flight SQ006 were soaked by torrential rain from an off-shore typhoon as they turned to see sheets of orange flame burst out from the fuselage behind them.

More than 40 passengers and crew scrambled clear of the wreckage late on Wednesday after the plane had lifted off, slammed back on to the runway, and sheared into three massive pieces. "I heard the sound of cracking when the plane started to take off," said survivor Yen Hui, who escaped with her husband. "Then the plane tilted left and, in a few seconds, balls of fire flew from the front part of the plane."

Those sitting in the upper cabin at the front had the best chance of escaping, as did the flight crew in front of them. Passengers in economy at the back of the plane found doors blocked as stewardesses struggled desperately to open them. Some managed to climb out through the jagged opening where the rear section had split from the central fuselage. Others were trapped by their seat belts as the flames engulfed the section. "We saw flashes of fire and the plane broke apart," one survivor recalled. "The flames came into the cabin; the smoke was everywhere."

Injured passengers were extracted through doors and rents in the fuselage before being swathed in bandages and rushed on stretchers to hospital. Yesterday morning, the rescue workers struggled on, linking arms to keep their balance in 90mph gusts of wind, as they searched for bodies. Paul Blanchon, 37, from Stokesley, North Yorkshire, was one of two Britons who survived. The other was Steven Courtney, 45. There was no word of the fate of the two other Britons believed to be on the flight - Margaret Blanche Rabley, from Risca near Newport in south Wales, and Hong Kong-based Tak Wing Loo.

Some wondered why the plane had even attempted to take off. "I never could believe we were going to take off," said Californian John Diaz. "By the time we got on the plane you could actually feel the wind shake the plane as it was parked at the gate."
